ShortDescription: Individual became unwell and passed out
FullDescription: Individual was working in the Store. While in a seated position the IP felt unwell and dizzy. A first aider was called and the IP fainted.  The Individual was placed into the recovery position, monitored and given O2 to promote his recoveryAn ambulance was called and the IP wa transferred to ARI for further examination.
ImmediateAction: IP transferred to ARI. P&O informed to provide further assistance or transport where required

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0090 PD Caron; tipped wiggle in ditch
FullDescription: A loaded articulating rock truck was travelling from the 7.5KM stockpile to multi-culvert stockpile. As operator moved over for oncoming rock truck, operator caught soft shoulder and tipped, coming to a rest in the ditch. No injuries sustained.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped, scene frozen and supervisor contacted. Canadian Model followed. Incident Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: Skid steer operator turned the skid steer while backing up between the solar modules and contacted a solar module causing it to break.
FullDescription: A foreman was operating a skid steer in Block 3 PCS 20 repairing rills between the solar modules when they began backing out of the array. During the backing operation, the operator attempted to maneuver the skid steer 180 degrees and contacted a solar module causing the module to break. A spotter was designated to the operation however they were positioned out of sight and ear shot of the operator. Actual and Potential A1 was selected for both as there were no injuries or potentially injury and the damage resulted in less than 10k.
ImmediateAction: The foreman/operator immediately stopped their equipment and notified their supervisor who in turn notified Wood HSSES and Project Management. The site Operation & Maintenance Contractor was notified as well. Operator credentials are suspended pending investigation. Post-accident drug test protocols initiated. Investigation is ongoing.

ShortDescription: Whilst leaving the parking area the ENHL-Bonatti Personnel bus hit a chevron safety sign damaging it
FullDescription: On the day of the incident, the ENHL-Bonatti personnel bus was leaving the CPF parking area in front of the main gate turning left into the main access road towards the camp to go and drop off people. Whilst turning into the road the driver did not observe the chevron sign on the corner next to the pavement and accidentally hit it with the back end of the bus when he turned damaging it. The sign had been damaged before by a condensate tanker turning in the same area. The driver was not using his side mirror when turning out into the road as he was looking for oncoming traffic from the right from the CPF and never saw the chevron sign.
ImmediateAction: Incident Investigation scheduled for the 1st November 2022Incident reported to Client and Project Management teamsWood will investigate but this was not a project related incident as the bus was transporting personnel to the camp although it did result in damage

ShortDescription: Worker at subcontractor injured fingers during use off drilling machines
FullDescription: During drilling off holes for installation off a ladder, IP (Aker Solutions) was going to change the drill. The drilling machine was mounted in a drill-mate and the space was narrow. To fasten the drill, IP held around the choke with his right hand,  while starting the machine with his left hand. The impact glove on his right hand was then caught by the drill, and followed the drill around. His little finger and pointing finger was then squeezed against the arm off the drill-mate and the two fingers was sprained. Through dialogue with IP and Medical expertise, suitable work tasks for IP was described and he has returned to work. See attached ppt for photo.Work was planned and approved by Aker Solutions accordingly to our contract model. Wood have the overall responsibility. The injury will be classified as B2 and no potential serious injury. Equinor has not reacted very negatively and currently no actions forced from Equinor other than light investigation with cause analysis and necessary mitigating actions. Aker Solutions will manage this and we will engage with them.
ImmediateAction: IP treated for injury and case reported to Ellis 26.10.22

ShortDescription: unloading a mini-digger it was noticed that the diesel cap had not been fitted before delivery causing a small spill.
FullDescription: Whilst the subcontractor was unloading a mini-digger it was noticed that the diesel cap had not been fitted before delivery causing a small amount of diesel to spill from the mini-digger tank. The spill was cleaned using the spill kits available and lay down area which had the drains covered as part of the laydown process was cleaned effectively.
ImmediateAction: Spill cleaned using spill kits on site. Roadway cleaned using road sweeper.

ShortDescription: Damper found to be pressurised prior to pre charging operations on Marnock chemical injection pump P81003A accumulator on the PDR
FullDescription: At approximately 1500hrs on Thursday 20th October 2022, pre charging operations on the dampers for the Marnock chemical injection pump P81003A dampers (VSP813250). The dampers were supplied by a SPX a subcontracting supply company. Durning the initial leak checks the mechanical technician opened the charging valve and immediately realised that the damper was already pressurised.  The gage was checked on the charging equipment which clarified that the was 47bar of pressure within the damper.  Due to the relatively small volume of pressure indicated that it was probably charged to a greater amount and lost pressure due to volume in the length of hose.  The offshore mechanical technician checked a further 8 and 4 were found to be charged to a lower level of between 21.8bar and 22.8bar and the reminding 4 were at zero pressure. SPX chemical pump company was contacted to determine 'as sent' status, this was inconclusive there were 9 more due for transportation, all 9 were removed from the supply vessel and as a precaution were sent to ASCO to allow checks to be conducted.  The accumulators are normally shipped at a preservation pressure of (< 1bar).  The appropriate dangerous goods paperwork for shipping pressurised equipment was also not completed.
ImmediateAction: All dampers were checked on site and all found not to be depressurised were de pressured. Containers with dampers from this manufacturer were removed from supply vessel and checked for pressurisation status.

ShortDescription: 8 Wood and 1 subcontractor staffs infected Covid-19 (Cumulative over the past week)
FullDescription: 8 Wood and 1 subcontractor staffs infected Covid-19 (Cumulative over the past week). All infected persons have been under home isolation and stable.
ImmediateAction: Infected persons have been isolated from work environment. Disinfected work area where necessary. Close contact tracing commenced. ATK test for a close contact person. Updated Covid-19 record.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee was detected as positive while in the hotel waiting for  embark.
FullDescription: One Wood employee was detected as positive while in the hotel waiting for  embark.
ImmediateAction: Isolation and medical recommendation.

ShortDescription: Excavator contacted head pulley on McCloskey screen plant
FullDescription: On 20 October 2022 at approximately 1100 SBI Mechanics arrived at the Ore Pad to replace a broken hydraulic line on the McCloskey 155 Screen Plant head pulley motor.  During the function test the mechanics discovered that the head pulley drive shaft had been bent.   SBI Mechanics contacted the site superintendent and safety and notified them of the equipment damage at approximately 1145.
ImmediateAction: The McCloskey screen plant was locked out and an investigation started. During the investigation, scuff marks  on the head pulley motor hardware and guarding were observed, indicating that metal to metal contact had occurred between the excavator and the screen plant.

ShortDescription: SIR - Worker reported K50 had been stolen from their personal wallet
FullDescription: Worker based in the LNGP travel office reported at the morning toolbox talk on 21st October that K50 had been taken from their personal wallet during lunchbreak on the 20th October.  The wallet was unattended inside their personal bag in the office while they went to the camp for lunch.
ImmediateAction: Due to the incident not being reported until the next day, no immediate action was taken at the time.  However, once it had been reported the following day all Wood employees in the support complex were addressed and advised to secure their personal valuables and to report any losses or suspicious activity immediately.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0088 HIPO; rock truck overturned
FullDescription: A loaded 40t articulating rock truck was travelling on HR5 from TMF Crusher to SR6 when operator failed to maintain control while navigating a corner. This resulted in rock truck tipping coming to a rest in the ditch. Light snow was falling, leading up to the event. Road conditions were icy at time of incident. No injuries sustained.
ImmediateAction: Scene was frozen and supervisor was contacted. Road conditions were addressed (graded and sanded). Canadian Model was followed. Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: IP (Indian expat) tested positive for COVID-19. Symptomatic.
FullDescription: The Ip was experiencing symptoms (cold like symptoms, back pain and fever) after which they reported to the PE clinic where they were assessed and tested for COVID-19 which yielded a positive result.
ImmediateAction: The IP was prescribed medication and is currently in isolation.  The PE medic and Hexagon PM will remain in contact with the IP.  The IP will be reevaluated for potential release from isolation by the medic after three days.

ShortDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
FullDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
ImmediateAction: IP is isolating offshore while awaiting a flight.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0089 MTC; foreign body left eye
FullDescription: On October 17th, IP was assisting a co-worker with welding a piece of metal under stairs when IP felt irritation in left eye. IP was wearing eye protection at time of incident.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and supervisor contacted. IP was taken to onsite PA who assessed and was cleared for duty. On October 18th IP continued to feel irritation in left eye. IP visited onsite PA and was sent to Timmins for further assessment. Foreign body was identified at Timmins hospital and removed. IP returned to work and back to full duties. Incident Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: Small contusion to right 5th digit (little finger)
FullDescription: On 19 October 2022 at approximately 1610 an SBI employee was cleaning out the screen deck on the triple deck screen plant located on the facility pad. The employee was wearing all required PPE. While cleaning / clearing debris the employee’s right little finger was pinched between the pry bar and the side rail of the screen deck resulting in a small contusion to the base of the right little finger. Basic first aid was provided, and the employee was released back to work.
ImmediateAction: The employee stopped work and immediately notified safety of the incident.  Basic first aid was administered and the employee was released back to work.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0087 FA NANJV; Laceration to lip caused by hose
FullDescription: While trying to separate two links of hose, one end contacted the worker's lip.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and supervisor contacted. IP was taken to onsite PA who assessed and cleaned. IP returned to work. Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: Employee was bolting intake panel to another intake panel and got right thumb pinched. Employee was wearing all PPE.
FullDescription: Crew was task to install intake hoods to intake  manifold. Employee was working from inside of structure installing bolts and nuts to fit up bird screen. Bolts were not lining up and employee was moving panel to adjust when fellow coworker on the outside pushed the panel and resulted in IP to have his thumb pinched causing a laceration. Actual versus potential, actual is a B2 - medical treatment/restricted work/moderate health effect. Potential is a B2 - medical treatment/restricted work/moderate health effect. Still under investigation. Will update Actual/Potential once treatment is rendered if needed.
ImmediateAction: Site first aid contacted Occucare and was advised to walk-in clinic but was referred to ER work front . The IP received medical treatment.  The work is shut down for investigation.

ShortDescription: During the running of an OPITO BOSIET course, the TEMPSC is boarded as a training scenario to abandon ship and set to see moving across the
FullDescription: During the launch of the TEMPSC and start up of the engine a small amount of smoke was visible from the rear of the vessel where several students were sitting. This was approximately 0910.On the vessel touching the water, a student (one of eight students in the lifeboat) tried to catch the attention of the assistant to ask if he could open a window next to her. He did not fully understand the request due to noise but proceeded to open windows on both sides of the vessel creating air flow. Further into the sail, (approx few minutes) the student then tried to catch the attention of the coxswain to again, ask if a window closer could be opened. The Coxwain was distracted with driving the boat so unfortunately did not fully comprehend her request.The conditions on the day were overcast and calm but inside at the rear of the vessel small amounts of smoke were initially visible until the windows were opened and fresh air blown around. Due to the small amount of smoke, this caused the student to cough and feel uncomfortable in the back and also the lack of communication by the crew members and unaware of the situation lead instructor.As a result of the above, when the vessel came to a stand still, the student lashed out verbally to both the lead instructor and the coxswain coughing and emotionally upset by the ordeal. Lead instructor calmed down the situation, asked if she was ok and monitored her throughout the rest of the day.
ImmediateAction: TEMPSC has been locked down and tagged out. The student was contacted for her health and apologies for the conduct and disappointment on her course.The TEMPSC was gas tested (un vented) to gain an initial result without doors) and a diesel mechanic has been booked to inspect the engine, exhaust system and work that was conducted the day prior.Quotes asked to engineer a system to lower the boat on land without the need to launch for future operations. (an OPITO requirement to launch)

ShortDescription: Employees tested positive for Covid 19
FullDescription: 6 employees teste positive for covid 19 from October 1st to October 19th
ImmediateAction: Quarantine al license.

ShortDescription: A sub-contract employee was sprayed with hydraulic fluid when a low-pressure hose connection came loose while driving piles.
FullDescription: A sub-contract crew were installing piles with a Vermeer PD 10 pile driver when a low pressure return hydraulic hose connection came loose. One of the employees that was standing in front of the equipment was sprayed in the face and torso with the hydraulic fluid. The equipment was immediately shut down.  The minimal amount of hydraulic fluid (1 pint-estimate) that was released to ground was removed and bagged for environmental disposal.
ImmediateAction: The employee was transported to the medical clinic where he was treated with first aid measures and released to return to work w/o restrictions. The hydraulic fluid that came into contact with the ground was removed and bagged for environmental disposal.

ShortDescription: Dirt shaker being moved by excavator tipped over
FullDescription: Wood employees were moving a dirt shaker from the north side of utility building using a 22 excavator with 1" wire rope and shackle.  To move this equipment, it needed to be raised >2 ft. from lift point so that back tires could come in contact with ground in order to roll.  When the equipment was raised, since the ground was at a slight incline, it rolled backwards and the tires on the north side went onto a big rock & shaker rolled over onto the south side.  South side is heavier side of shaker.  No injuries and spotters were in place to prevent encroachment of personnel during move.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped.  Diesel fuel leak contained. Team debriefed and planning started to upright equipment.

ShortDescription: During mechanical Excavation for the installation of the V-Drain at the IGF area the skid steer damaged the plastic cover of a cable
FullDescription: On the day of the incident, a skid steer was busy with mechanical excavation for the V-Drain in the CPF IGF area. The area had been cleared for mechanical excavation and an excavation permit was available. The cable in question is for an old street light circuit and was identified by the work crew. the work crew assumed that the cable was running all the way along the pipe rack and proceeded with the excavation as planned. The cable was exposed for about 2 meters and then deviated in the area where it was damaged to the inside path of the excavation. the operator of the skid steer placed the bucket and was stopped by the spotter when he saw the cable. The plastic cover was damaged, but no damage occurred to the armoring of the cable
ImmediateAction: The area was made safe. damage was assessed by the Client electrical team the following day and classified as minorLight circuit was disconnected as it is no longer in use and part of an old installation.Client and Wood Project teams were notifiedIncident investigation planned for the 01st November 2022

ShortDescription: Employee got knee caught up in between valve and scaffold pole.
FullDescription: Employee stated he was up on a scaffold and was moving a valve, as he was moving it, it shifted and his knee got caught in between scaffold pole and valve. He pushed the valve away and set his leg free. Potential - Employee had minimal health effects, received first aid could have been more significant but unlikely for a lost time injury.
ImmediateAction: Employee reported incident to foreman, then foreman reported to Dow operations. Wood HSSE was notified and then employee was taken to Occupational Medical Center.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee caused minor damage to a vehicle tipping the side by side into a hillside.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, October 18, 2022, at approximately 14:00, a Wood electrician was tasked with testing the cathodic protection on a pipeline right of way.   The EE was driving a Honda Pioneer 700 RTV side by side looking for a test point.   As he was driving down the south side of the right of way, the front right tire caught in a washout causing both front tires to turn hard to the left.   At the same time the front right tire dropped into the washout and as the EE was applying the brakes, the RTV slowly tipped against the dirt bank next to the right of way damaging the passenger side mirror. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the Pioneer is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the Pioneer is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: He contacted his supervisor and HSE.

ShortDescription: FAC - Lower back injury while lifting scaffold material from scaffold bucket.
FullDescription: FAC - At approximately 08:00hrs 18/10/2022, IP experienced lower back pain when lifting scaffolding equipment from a scaffold bucket.
ImmediateAction: IP reported event to Supervisor after lunch and then reported to the Medic for review.IP received first aid treatment (OTC medication).IP scheduled for precautionary follow up review on the 19th October.

ShortDescription: Damage to signage from elevated work platform (EWP).
FullDescription: EWP working in laydown yard has contacted signage that was stored in the slew zone of the EWP.
ImmediateAction: EWP stopped and turned off.Work stopped.HSSE and Supervisor advisedInvestigation commenced.

ShortDescription: NWR - IP reported to medic with irritation to left eye. Event occurred whilst IP was asleep,
FullDescription: On the 18th of October at approximately 16:00, IP (night shift electrical technician) reported to the medic with irritation to their left eye that occurred whilst asleep. It is believed that IP has inadvertently scratched their cornea whilst asleep.
ImmediateAction: Upon arrival at medic, IP was provided with prescription medication to use for 5 days and was provided with an eye patch to use for 24 hours. IP  has been stood down for 24 hours. No further action is expected unless condition worsens.

ShortDescription: Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
FullDescription: Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
ImmediateAction: IPs are isolating offshore while awaiting flight.

ShortDescription: Employee stumbled while walking to the printer and twisted her foot, Xray examination revealed a metatarsal fracture
FullDescription: IP was walking from her office to the printer which is located in the "Kitchen" general area, this requires to turn left after passing thru the entrance at this moment the IP mentions that she slipped and started to fall however was able to hold on to the edge of a table, this movement made her left foot turn on itself producing harsh pain.  Employee then went back to her office changed her shoes to a wider loose shoe and then went to the nearest First aid box (located in the same Kitchen area) and bandaged her foot up. IP called her personal Dr. and got an appointment for the same day at 3:00pm. Dr. Recommended to ice the foot and referred to X-ray the next day.  On the 19th in the morning employee went for Xray and then back to the office to pick up her laptop charger at this moment she informed with a written not to her supervisor that she had hurt her foot.  During the evening received confirmation from Dr. of a Metatarsal Fracture and referral to an orthopedic specialist.  IP mentions that there was no liquid or any material on the floor.
ImmediateAction: None, other than specified in incident description.  Employee did not consider injury to be work related and HSSE department was informed when employee submitted a non-work-related HEART report a week later.   After the HEART report was reviewed and escalated to CAIRS incident investigation commenced.  Employee has submitted 9 additional nonrelated HEARTS in 2022

ShortDescription: During  bolts flange tightening by a WGS mechanic, the wrench was released, generating the impact of the mechanic on the flange.
FullDescription: when tightening the bolts of the bridle, the spanner was released and IP collided with all his weight on the bridle, the shock resulted from pain in the ribs of the chest and a scratch in the head .
ImmediateAction: IP was evacuated to the level of the Fertial Arzew infirmary where he received first aid and evacuated to the hospital where he passed the radiological tests without detecting any fracture, the IP did not receive a stoppage of work, he just received first aid.The investigation was launched this morning at the head of our HSE department head, the work permit for the operation exists and the IP has been contacted and the latter has confirmed the circumstances and will send his report in writing, apparently and depending on the time of the accident the cause could be fatigue and lack of concentration.

ShortDescription: During the crane lifting of a an excavation king post a shock load was applied to a webbed sling which resulted in failure of the sling.
FullDescription: Cooling water repair projectTolent  - Civil work contractor contracted to SabicJN Piling – Piling specialist contracted to TolentWood – Appointed person, rigger and rigging equipment contracted to SabicMammoet – Supply and operation of 100Te crane contracted to SabicThe failure of the sling occurred following a shock load being applied to it. The operation was to install a king post as part of piling operations. Wood riggers were employed in the lifting/moving of the auger and king post upon request by the piling contractor.A Giken piling rig was positioned on its reaction stand ready to install the north side king post, the first of two such piles. The pre auger activity was completed in accordance with the method statement and the auger was removed and laid down. The king post was inserted into the hole until it grounded and then the Giken began to drive the pile down. The king post is approximately 11m long and at what I would estimate to be 2/3 installed the rig was unable to drive the pile any further due to an obstruction. At this point it was considered that refusal was  likely due to collapse of the augered hole at the bottom or a section of hard ground (rock) snagging the pileThe pile was removed and the auger reintroduced to clear the obstruction. The auger brought what looked like water, wet clay and gravel to the surface. The auger was removed and laid down and at approximately 17:00hrs the pile was reinserted through the Giken clamp mechanism and into the hole. The pile was lowered into the hole suspended on the 100Te crane. With what is estimated to be around 4m of the pile out of the ground(housed in the piling equipment) the pile grounded again and the weight came off the crane. Without warning and before the Giken clamp mechanism could get hold of the pile to continue driving operations, the obstruction in the hole gave way and the pile dropped into the hole. The shock load broke the sling at the mid-point (the sling was doubled to the hook) and the pile came to rest with what is estimated to be 2.5m still above ground.The post was housed in such a way that the only way that it could travel would be in a downward direction.
ImmediateAction: The king post was driven into its final position, this part of the operation did not include crane lifting activities, and operations were suspended. Communication was held the the crane hire company and they gave assurance that the shock load applied to the sling did not affect the integrity of the crane.  The sling was inspected by the lifting accessory hire company and they gave assurance that the failure of the sling was due to the shock load applied to it.   The documentation for the task was reviewed and the lifting operations methodology for positioning the gate post was revised. Following this revision all key stakeholders were part of a pre-start team brief and agreement was reached on the way forward to achieve a safe operation.

ShortDescription: Non work related - Foreign body in IP eye
FullDescription: It was reported to the Wood HSEA on Tuesday 18th September that a member of the Kaefer painting team had some dust in their eye. Whilst walking from the cabin to the NMT admin building IP reported some dust blowing into their eye due to the high winds. Due to the late reporting and the IP originally not being able to confirm exactly when this happened - it has been categorised as a non-work related incident.
ImmediateAction: Once incident was reported to the HSEA - HSEA advised that IP immediately leave site and seek medical treatment.IP sought medical treatment and their eye was subsequently flushed. IP's management informed.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee was tested positive for COVID while was in the hotel waiting for embark.
FullDescription: One Wood employee was tested positive for COVID while was in the hotel waiting for embark.
ImmediateAction: Isolation and medical recommendation.

ShortDescription: Forklift operator contacted top of box truck with boom causing damage to latching mechanism and camera system while unloading a truck.
FullDescription: Logistics employees were using a forklift to unload a box truck when the top of the boom contacted the top of the box truck. There was a spotter working with the forklift operator, but he was focusing on the mast and forks entering the truck and not the boom. The operator’s view was blocked and could not see the boom. The spotter was directing the operator to extend the forks into the truck when the boom contacted the truck. The operator had possession of the spotters training card when the incident occurred as per site policy. The door latching mechanism and rear camera system was damaged as a result of the incident. The actual and potential consequences were selected at A-1 as there were no employees in danger during the incident.
ImmediateAction: Incident was reported to supervision and safety department. An investigation was initiated. Post incident screening was completed.
WorkActivities: Field Work ,Forklift Operations ,Loading/Offloading of Cargo ,Material Handling/Storage ,Normal Operations ,Operating Equipment/Machinery

ShortDescription: Work being conducted out with of permit and RAMS
FullDescription: A permit was issued to conduct electrical work with clear stipulations and agreement at the point of permit issue. The planned work as agreed with the permit issuer was being completed at the point of a site visit but additional work, out with of the RAMS and permit was simultaneously being carried out. The additional work was not covered by the RAMS or the permit and the permit. The permit issuer stopped the job immediately to review the documentation and engage with the contractor management. A further exploration into the documents and the understanding of work, identified that work was being conducted without prior agreement or authorisation.
ImmediateAction: * Job Stopped, * Documentation reviewed, * Contractor interviewed, * Client informed,* RAMS reviewed and amended by contractor* Terms of reference issued for contractor to investigate failure to adhere to RAMS (have appropriate RAMS) and the permit.

ShortDescription: A watercart reversed into Building 2272 causing damage to the structure, watercart's support beam and dribble bar.
FullDescription: An employee wetting down ground for compaction, when a water cart backed into a building structure resulting to a minor damage of the building structure, the water carts support beam and dribble bar.
ImmediateAction: Ceased workReported to SupervisorEmployee taken to the site medic for D&A test.

ShortDescription: 10-inch brine pipe break
FullDescription: was performing a mechanical excavation task in the RWPL sector, when the operator is digging at 1.5 meters, a 10-inch pipe breaks, then water begins to come out -BRINE-
ImmediateAction: Warning to the security supervisor of Wood-LIVENT - Responsible for the sector and plant (LIVENT) * The excavation tasks are stopped. - Measures are taken to contain water and drainage begins. It begins immediately with the repair of the 10-inch pipe.

ShortDescription: Whilst examining internal weld route penetration in branch line unsupported Spray nozzle slipped and trapped hand between two flange faces.
FullDescription: A Pipefitter was working on refitting a Spray nozzle into a branch of 8DS5. He was having difficulty making it fit due to a Weld route penetration within and was having concerns about  the amount of material he had already removed by grinding from the nozzle. He had been working alone and was continually manual handling the Nozzle to and from the branch after the grinding process and checking if it would fit. The Nozzle would not pass the weld penetration within. He called the welder for an opinion as to where the injector was snagging. The welder took a torch light in his right hand and shone it into the branch. At this point his hand was now between flanges of the branch of 8DS5 and the unsupported spray nozzle which had been left in situ by the pipefitter. It was at this moment the Nozzle gave way and fell into the branch causing the Welder to trap his right hand between the two flange faces. This resulted in soft tissue injury to the Welders right hand confirmed by a visit to the local hospital. He returned to work following diagnosis and being advised to take paracetamol.
ImmediateAction: Onsite Fire and Safety attended to record evidence and administer First aid. 5 whys investigation made by  Fire and Safety. Mock set up created to understand Incident which was reported to Site Operations manager and checks made on welfare of I/P.

ShortDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
FullDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
ImmediateAction: IP is isolating offshore while awaiting a flight.

ShortDescription: Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
FullDescription: Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
ImmediateAction: IPs are isolating offshore while awaiting a flight.

ShortDescription: IP crushed & cut their ring finger while moving the grating panel they were in the process of fabricating
FullDescription: The IP, a Wood Plater, had been fabricating a small grating panel. Various edging bars and kick plates had been tack-welded onto the panel. A final piece of edging bar was required. The IP was in the process of manually handling the 48kg grating panel (with the assistance of a colleague) from the steel workbench to the ground level to access to the final corner. The IP had their fingers stuck through the grating and crushed / scrapped their ring finger between the grating panel and the edge of the steel work bench.Initial classification is based on the actual known severity at this moment in time which is a Medical Treatment Injury. This may progress to RWC or LWC once the IP has been assessed by the Occ Health Provider (ISOS)
ImmediateAction: IP stopped work and reported to the Medic.Medic provided immediate treatment and requested IP to report back again the following day.IP was re-assessed on Sunday and a decision was made to request the coastguard to assist with transporting the IP to Gilbert Bain Hospital in Shetland. This decision was made due to the fact the incident occurred over the weekend and there were no routine flights planned.IP received Medical Treatment in Gilbert Bain Hospital and was released fit to travel back to Aberdeen. The next available flight was Monday afternoon.IP will be assessed by Wood's Occ Health provider ISOS on Monday evening. Report severity will be updated following the results of the assessment if required

ShortDescription: Site wagon slipped from access route while accessing tower.
FullDescription: The site wagon driver has tried to manoeuvre the site wagon into a site access at PHB 45 , whilst doing so his wheels have come off the track and he’s slid due to ground conditions then was unable to get back up onto the track up the hill due to mechanical failure.
ImmediateAction: Recovered the vehicle. And all drivers re-briefed on TBT for importance of checking all sites before access for ground conditions and safe access.

ShortDescription: Person in camp tested positive to Covid 19
FullDescription: Person in camp tested positive to Covid 19. Required to isolate for at least 5 days.
ImmediateAction: Required to isolate for at least 5 days.

ShortDescription: Whilst placing a crate down that's was being transported by a FLT the crate toppled onto its side.
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: On Friday 14th October 2022, a delivery was received at the ASCO Wearhouse, Peterhead of a crate containing valve (HCV-204025, 20116999). The crate was transported into the warehouse by a forklift truck driver employed by ASCO.  The crate was lowered and placed on the ground, the forklift truck driver re positioned the forks at a different angle to move the crate again and that's when the crate overturned onto its left side.  There were no obvious signs of damage to the valve, and as a precaution the valve will be inspected prior to going offshore.  There were no personnel inured as a result of this incident
ImmediateAction: Reinspection of the valve to check for damage

ShortDescription: During air blowing activity, air hose dislodged from the hose tail adapter.
FullDescription: About 15 minutes into the air blowing activity, air hose dislodged from the hose tail adapter. Whip arrestor was installed correctly which arrested the hose from whipping. Nobody was injured.
ImmediateAction: Stopped work.Notified plant Shift Superintendent.Initiated investigation process.

ShortDescription: Crew was using an excavator to continue extending an excavation. The crew ended up striking an fiber optic line .
FullDescription: On 9/14/2022 around 1500 hours, the Wood crew struck and fiber optic line.  The crew earlier that day walked down the area to identify know lines in the area. After that the crew had their safety talk and began to continue extending the excavation using an excavator.  The operator had a spotter with them.  As the operator was unaware, they struck a line until they saw the fiber optic line.  The spotter did not see the line until it was exposed.  Work was stopped immediately and their supervisor was contacted.  The fiber optic line was not in service at this time. The fiber optic line was installed by a different contractor working under MDU. Actual and potential severity rating.  Actual is A1 for minor loss/damage/business impact (<10K).  Potential is A1 for minor loss/damage/business impact (<10K). This line strike is currently under investigation.
ImmediateAction: After the fiber optic line was struck, the crew immediately contacted their supervisor and safety was notified as well as MDU.

FullDescription: Employee went to fueling station to put fuel in the Skid Steer. On the way back he realized that he had left his wallet back at the fueling station and turned back to go get it. As he turned right , he struck a combiner pile.
ImmediateAction: Employee stopped operating and called Superintendent. Superintendent called safety. No injuries were substained.

ShortDescription: IP strained shoulder installing the slops heater
FullDescription: A Mechanical technician was installing the Slops Heater on the main deck on Friday 14th October. During this work scope the IP has adopted an awkward position to tighten the bottom bolts of the flange, by lying on his back on the deck. (See attached picture). As the IP was tightening the bottom bolts of the flange, he has felt a strain in his shoulder. The IP visited the Medic at around 18:00 and asked for paracetamol, which he was given. On Sunday 16th October the IP revisited the medic and asked for further pain relief, at which point the medic consulted the Topsides doctor, who agreed the IP could have Co-codamol. The co-codamol offered was over the counter strength 8mg/500mg. The IP returned to work with no further issue reported.
ImmediateAction: IP visited the medic x2 for treatment. IP returned to work with no further issue reported.

ShortDescription: Minor cut to left hand
FullDescription: IP incurred a minor cut to his hand on an access Gate #2 whilst trying to stabilize himself after he slipped on a very muddy surface whilst walking on an incline. He was on his way to a drilling Bore Hole 036; the cut was on his left-hand palm area beneath his thumb (approx. a 15mm right angle cut).
ImmediateAction: The IP returned to the site entrance point to his vehicle and informed the RSK Supervising Engineer of the occurrence. The Supervising Engineer cleaned the cut and applied an Elastoplast to stem the bleed. He then left site and advised his line Manager of the incident.

He was transferred to the medical service to perform first aid.

ImmediateAction: Self-isolation to be carried out at his residence as per MOH guidelines. Disinfection was carried at his desk.

Project: Algonquin Chevron Solar - Hayhurst New Mexico (HHNM)
ShortDescription: Employee was attempting transport tubes to the work area when he struck a tube with the fork.
FullDescription: Wood Forklift Operator was attempting to transport tubes to another area when he made contact with a tube causing a minor dent. As the FL Operator adjusted his forks attempting to lift a block of tubes, the right fork was slightly misaligned and struck the tube and as the operator moved forward. Only one tube made contact with the fork. The FL Operator was working without a spotter at the time of the incident. No damages were caused to the forks. The tube was inspected by Wood HSSE, Logistics and Mechanical Management personnel. The tube is functional and will be utilized. Both the potential and the actual risks were selected as A-1 as there was no personnel at risk in the incident.
ImmediateAction: HSSE was notified immediately by the event witnesses. HSSE stopped (SWA) the job task to conduct an investigation of what occurred.  Logistics and Mechanical Management Team members assisted with the inspection and integrity of the tubing. Measurements were taken to verify that the tube was functional an can continue to be utilized. Site wide standdown was directed by HSSE to each service line for reviewing the importance of using a spotter for heavy equipment movement and tasks. An investigation has been initiated. A Post Incident Drug & Alcohol Non DOT Panel has been administered.

ShortDescription: Operator rolled ankle while stepping out of forklift.
FullDescription: On Wednesday 10/12/22 around 09:00 a forklift operator was parking their forklift (JLG-1055, 51926) near the Wetbottom Entry. While exiting the forklift the employee stepped on uneven and loose concrete debris, causing his left ankle to roll inward. Operator reported to Safety complaining of discomfort in their left ankle.  An actual severity of B1 was selected, as one employee required first aid.  A potential severity of B2 was determined, due to the potential of an ankle roll to have required treatment above and beyond first aid.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and incident response protocol initiated.  Operator seen by Wood safety and reported discomfort to left ankle. Operator was instructed to stay in break room and keep icing ankle, and safety to recheck on employee.

ShortDescription: IP stepped on uneven ground surface resulting in discomfort in the IP's right ankle.
FullDescription: A subcontractor equipment operator exited the dozer cab while the equipment was being fueled. While walking towards the foreman's pickup truck the operator (IP) stepped onto uneven ground surface resulting in discomfort to his right ankle. The area in which the IP was walking was being graded for a project employee parking lot. The IP immediately reported the incident to his foreman. Ice was applied to the IP’s ankle. The IP was taken to the project’s Occupational Clinic and diagnosed with a soft tissue injury. The incident’s actual severity rating is a B1 as the IP received First Aid treatment. The potential severity rating is a B2 as the incident could have resulted in a medical treatment case.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped; medical treatment provided

ShortDescription: Left leg shin grazed with robin pump protruding stud.
FullDescription: IP during his walkabout along the 66 KVA trench got his left leg shin grazed with robin pump protruding stud.
ImmediateAction: IP went to project clinic for treatment.Notified plant Shift Superintendent.Initiated investigation process.

ShortDescription: 1 Wood employee tested positive for Covid-1
FullDescription: 1 Wood office based employee tested positive for covid19. IP is currently symptomatic
ImmediateAction: The case was referred to the local government health team for coordination and recording. The IP currently on home isolation and now monitored by Wood OH team

ShortDescription: A Wood employee was injured while pigging a high pressure gas line.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, October 11, 2022 at approximately 14:00 MST, the IP was tasked with pigging a high-pressure gas line on the Row 5 Spline at a XTO Energy location near Carlsbad, New Mexico .  After the IP isolated the pig receiver, he needed to release the stored pressure.  As the IP opened the valve on the bottom of the receiver barrel, the releasing pressure caused the valve assembly to rotate toward the IP where it is suspected that the valve struck the IP’s left knee resulting in injuries to the knee and tibia.  The actual severity is a B-3 because the injuries resulted in a lost time injury with significant health effects.  The potential severity has been given a B-3 pending the findings of the investigation.
ImmediateAction: 911 was called.  Emergency services arrived and transported the IP to the University Medical Center of El Paso, Texas.  The client representative contacted the Wood account manager.

ShortDescription: Employee stung by wasp - allergic reaction
FullDescription: Employee was using the port-a -john when he was stung on his left buttocks by a wasp of some type.   Employee began to feel "tingling" in his throat and reported to the safety office.  Employee had informed SBI that he was allergic to bee stings prior to the event.
ImmediateAction: Employee self administered an allergy pill and an EpiPen dose. The allergic reaction diminished and employee returned to work after 1 hour.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Wood employee was installing insulation into a 42" stack, when 2 ram jacks that were being used to lift the stack shifted.
FullDescription: At approximately 12:30 pm, a Wood employee was installing insulation into a 42"x15' stack, when the stack shifted causing the employee's right arm to get caught between the stack and the flange, resulting in a contusion to their right arm.  Employee was evaluated by offsite medical for first aid treatment and released without restrictions.  Incident was reported and company protocol was followed.  Potential - Employee received first aid unlikely injury would be more severe.
ImmediateAction: Employee was taken to offsite medical for evaluation and released without restriction.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee was detected as positive for COVID was while in the hotel waiting to embark.
FullDescription: One Wood employee was detected as positive for COVID was while in the hotel waiting to embark.
ImmediateAction: Demobilization and medical recommendation.

ShortDescription: Lifeline Protocol not followed during container installation
FullDescription: Prommac subcontractor Container Conversions were commencing container installation for Prommac in the main GHP Prommac laydown area. The Wood construction manager observed that one of the container conversions employees was not hooked on the installed lifeline during the installation of the container.The construction manager stopped the activity & conducted assurance checks where it was found that Prommac had not performed the required due diligence & assurance checks for the work to continue. Could not verify the approval of safety file approval of Container Conversions by Prommac.Subsequently, various system failures occurred which are meant to control high-risk activity work.
ImmediateAction: Work was stopped by the wood construction manager & preliminary investigation was conducted on-site.Non-Conformance report to be issued to Prommac in line with contractual legal obligations.Prommac to develop & implement a corrective & prevention plan and present it to Wood for review & approval. Leadership Engagement to be done by Wood with regard to Prommac over their subcontractors & site level management control over high-risk activities.RCA was deemed unnecessary as the causes of the event were evident from the site investigation

ShortDescription: Security guard tripped by a cable layed outside while exiting from the guardhouse door.
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: Please enter a short description of the incident. Do not include any personal details, e.g. name of the individual(s) involved.

ShortDescription: Security guard tripped by a cable layed outside while exiting from the guardhouse door.
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: On the 11th Oct @ 1000hrs, Loh n Loh contractor was laying earthing cable (4mm dia.) on the floor, in-front of 31 Shipyard Rd guardhouse door. The worker left the work area to get a masking tape to secure it to the floor. At this moment, the security guard opened the guardhouse door to attend to a delivery vehicle. He did not notice there was a cable laying on the floor and tripped over it. As the result of the fall, he complained of pain at his rib cage.  He was referred to the hospital for further review.Actual injury classification is pending EM panel doctor's review on 12th Oct.
ImmediateAction: Work activity was stopped, Stand-down conducted at 1300hrs. Commence investigation to find the root cause.

ShortDescription: While pulling out of a parking bay the vehicle came into contact with an adjacent parked vehicle.
FullDescription: The HUV (TEGI owned but utilized by Hexagon) was reverse parked.  When the driver (PM) attempted to drive out of the parking bay (outside of normal working hours hours), the right rear door of the HUV came into contact with the front left corner of a third-party sedan which was parked in the adjacent parking bay to the right.  Damage is estimated at $200 for the HUV and $750 for the third-party sedan (*Note: The condition of the vehicle prior to the incident occurring is unknown).
ImmediateAction: The vehicle was stopped and the damage to both vehicles was assessed (including photos).  The vehicle was then parked in its original position after which the damage was reported to the TEGI EHS Supervisor as well as the owner of the sedan.The PM has scheduled a safety meeting with all the Hexagon drivers on Thursday, 13 October 2022 @ 14h00 to communicate the lessons learned.

ShortDescription: CAT 777 haul truck turned front right bumper into rock wall while backing up resulting in bending bumper
FullDescription: On October 10, 2022 a CAT 777 was driving into the d-pit dump area to unload.  The truck entered the pit on the left roadway, turned right up a small ramp, stopped and backed to the left into the dumping area.  While negotiating the backward left turn the operator got too close to the wall with the right (blind side) of the truck.  The right bumper contacted the wall knocking a large rock out and bending the bumper up. The operator did not realize they had struck the wall until the next driver asked about the rock in the roadway.  They stopped the truck to do an inspection and found the damaged bumper.
ImmediateAction: A stop work in the D-pit was called and the haul truck was parked to conduct an investigation.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee moving truck forward, the truck came into contact with a bollard.
FullDescription: At approximately 1:15 pm, a Wood employee was driving vehicle # 66-10327 forward to exit the work area, when the running board came in contact with a bollard that was sticking out approximately 17" above grade.  The employee heard a crunch and immediately stopped their truck. They proceeded to back up vehicle, got out, and noticed red paint on the running board. Employee immediately notified Wood safety, operations, P66 contact, and supervision. Potential - Damage was minor, unlikely damage more than $10K and no injury.
ImmediateAction: Employee reported incident and company policy was followed.

ShortDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
FullDescription: Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offshore
ImmediateAction: IP is isolating offshore while awaiting a flight.

Project: US East - Oil & Gas - South Texas - Repsol
ShortDescription: EE was traveling to work when a deer struck the front of his vehicle.
FullDescription: On October 10, 2022 at 6:15 am, a Wood EE was traveling to location near Yorktown, TX when a deer ran onto the road and struck the front of the Wood vehicle. Impact caused damage to the bumper of the Wood vehicle. Actual (A1): Repairs not expected to exceed 10k; Potential (A1): Deer strikes typically cause minimal damage to our vehicles.
ImmediateAction: Wood EE reported the incident to his manager.

ShortDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19.
ImmediateAction: Employee taken to platform quarantine area to await demobilization from same.

ShortDescription: Wood employee hit his head against a metal disc of fired heater.
FullDescription: On 10th October 2022, some minutes before 10 o’clock, the IP (Injured Person) was conducting an inspection at the workshop of a supplier, the WELDING 2B, who is building a Steam Reformer for Wood.The IP was walking in the workshop area when a workshop employee placed behind him called him. The IP then turned his head without stopping (keeping walking) to listen to the workshop employee when he bumped his head against the metal structure. The impact caused a small cut at his right side of the head.
ImmediateAction: The IP reported the incident to the host, and he received first aid treatment at the workshop.He was feeling well and, for this reason, he was undecided whether to go to the hospital for further checks or not. Due to the minor bleeding of the wound, he finally decided to go to the hospital. The doctor at the ER decided to apply 4 stitches to guarantee a speedy recovery and also for aesthetic reasons.As per standard practice in Italy, the doctor also prescribed 4 days off The IP would have returned to work the same day because he was feeling well however, conscious that a second medical opinion to overrule the medical prescription received at the hospital would have been necessary (almost impossible to get it in Italian health care framework), he accepted to stay away from work. On the basis of the above information Corporate Occupational Health reviewed all the above information and reclassified the event as Medical Treatment Case, in line with most probable classification according to OSHA standards.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee hit a deer on his morning commute causing minor damage.
FullDescription: On Monday, October 10, 2022, at approximately 0605, The Wood employee was on his commute to work. Driving Eastbound on interstate 90. A deer ran out from the left side median into the driver side of the grill guard and driver side front and back door. Causing minor damage to the headlight and both doors. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Contacted HSE. Slow down, scan roadside closer.

FullDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19.

FullDescription: Informed by Wood staff that was tested positive with sore throat, blocked nose, and headache.

ShortDescription: Minor muscle strain experienced during general duties.
FullDescription: IP is currently engaged in building scaffolding for upcoming outage at site. IP was attempting to lift scaffold component above head from one level to another, felt a twinge in lower left hand side of back. Work was stopped and soreness was reported.
ImmediateAction: Work was stopped, visited client first aider, and was able to complete the remainder of his shift with no further impact or inflammation and no effect on his duties.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee caused minor damage to their tail gate while reversing.
FullDescription: On Sunday, October 9, 2022, at approximately 14:45, an operator was tasked with restarting a down well.  Upon arrival he saw mud & puddles around the location. He took the route that was in between separator & Well Head that had less water & thought it would be a lesser chance of getting stuck. The truck started to sink so he put it in reverse as going forward was not working & began to back up. He gave it more gas as it was stuck and as soon as he did the wheels hooked on the dirt and he reversed into a protruding Pipe causing minor damage to the truck. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: He contacted his supervisor and HSE.

FullDescription: A Wood employee reported to Wood supervisor on the morning of 10/10/2022 that they began to experience COVID-19 s/s on 10/09/2022. On 10/09/2022 the employee continued to have worsen that night and took a home COVID-19 test which was positive for COVID-19. The employee was last on site on 10/07/2022. Contact Tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.
ImmediateAction: Employee has self-quarantined and has notified management. Wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notifications have been made.
