ShortDescription: Worker cut energized electrical cable
FullDescription: Workers were tasked with identifying and removing obsolete cable from XLR between columns G5 and G6 ground floor. Workers identified  electrical cable to be  cut and removed a 3-foot section. Worker 1 was in the process of identifying the electrical cable intended for additional removal when worker 2 started cutting into a electrical cable that was not identified for removal and this resulted in cutting into a live 600 volt electrical cable. Damage to electrical cable was identified. No injuries sustained.
ImmediateAction: Energized cable isolated, Area was secured.Supervision notified.Cable demolition crew stood down pending investigation.Statements were obtained and investigation commencedPost incident testing protocol was initiated.

ShortDescription: The operator of the RIVA contractor company carried out cleaning tasks and dust in suspension got into one of his eyes.
FullDescription: At 9:20 a.m. at the HDT2 work front, the operator of the RIVA contractor company carried out cleaning tasks (cleaning of stripped formwork) with remains of concrete next to the platform of R-10201 A, in front of 5E Street, when a sudden strong wind blew, it raised dust and although he had safety glasses, dust in suspension got into one of his eyes. the worker feels a discomfort in his right eye and informs the safety technician of RIVA contractor company, and immediately reports to his Foreman of RIVA and the Frontline Supervisor WOOD, he was taken to the refinery medical service accompanied by the Safety Technician. and labor union staff.In the medical service they perform an eye wash removing the powder component and report that a foreign body which is evident in the area, for which they indicate that he be referred to an ART medical center.He was referred to ART Galeno.The person had safety glasses, it is being analyzed if he should have used another type of PPE, specifically if they should have used goggles.Today the worker was released and working on site in the PQ2024 Project.
ImmediateAction: Stop the activities and immediately reports to his Foreman of RIVA and the Frontline Supervisor WOOD, he was taken to the refinery medical service accompanied by the Safety Technician. and labor union staff.

ShortDescription: Logistics employee jack knife rear bumper while making a sharp turn with a trailer
FullDescription: On 08/25/2022, at approximately 14:00, Logistics was instructed to load crane mats from the laydown area to Block 1D. After loading the mats onto the trailer, the driver drove forward while making a sharp left turn causing the trailer to jack knife truck. Damage was observed on left rear bumper/fender and Big Tex-Trailer. The actual and potential severity rating is rated as an A1 since damage is estimated to be minor loss, less than 10k
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the incident/damage were collected. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collection.

ShortDescription: Rear pickup truck window broken after shutting tailgate.
FullDescription: On Thursday, 8/25/2022, at approximately 1645, team members were finishing loading tools and equipment into the bed of a wood pickup truck. When a team member closed the tailgate, the tempered glass of the rear window broke into small pieces. There was no evidence of anything striking the window. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor, the replacement of glass is (less than 10k), and there were no other team members in the vicinity. Investigation in progress.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent and the safety department. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, photos of the incident were gathered, the vehicle was tagged “Do Not Use” by logistics, and the window has been covered to eliminate hazard to personnel. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: IP strained back while attempting to lift spool piece
FullDescription: At approximately 0930 on the 25th of August, two pipefitters were tasked to remove some spools from their work area and place them near the road. The spools were 3" (inches) wide and 6-7' (feet) long and weighed  approximately 60lbs. While attempting to lift a spool, IP felt some discomfort in their lower back and also a tingly-like feeling in their leg and shoulder. IP and the other pipefitter sat the spool piece back down and contacted both their foreman and Site Safety Coordinator. The IP was taken to on-site medic for treatment and taken off-site for further evaluation.  Potential based on the fact the employee had minimal first aid/health effect and released to return to work without restrictions.
ImmediateAction: Stopped what they were doing and contacted their foreman and Site Safety Coordinator.  The IP was taken to on-site medic for treatment and taken off-site for further evaluation. IP was released to return to work without restrictions.

As he was driving around the back of the building to enter the car wash, he had to make a sharp right turn into the car wash tunnel. The fender of the truck received minor damage and the edge of the car wash entrance received a minor scrape.  The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck and the edge of the entrance is less than $10,000.  The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage would have been over $10,000.

ShortDescription: IP twisted ankle stepping over bags of scaffolding clips
FullDescription: A Lead Production Operator was carrying out line walking duties on Heat Medium system located in P2 Mezz level.In order to identify a tag number on the system the IP stepped over loose bags of scaffolding fittings stored on the Deck level. As his left foot made contact with the deck plate he rolled his left ankle. The IP immediately felt some discomfort in his ankle ligaments and immediately made his way to the Medic for a consultation. The IP was administered over the counter strength ibuprofen and was deemed fit to resume normal working duties. The IP was wearing a pair of company Red Wing Safety boots which were in excellent condition and offered high levels of support to the individuals feet / ankles. The deck the IP stepped onto was in good condition and was coated in anti-slip aggregate.
ImmediateAction: IP attended the medic and returned to work. Scaffolding foreman was advised of the scaffolding clip bags and they were removed accordingly.

ShortDescription: Preventable, rental vehicle, minor damage, no injury.
FullDescription: While backing truck up at an angle, the right passenger tire struck a concrete garden planter in driver's blindspot. The truck rocked forward away from planter briefly with a groaning sound from wheel well. Upon striking the planter, the driver pulled forward to correct the collision and proceeded to back out straight into local parking lot. After pulling forward onto the road, the driver noticed the vehicle was pulling forcifully to the left, and the driver and both passengers noticed a grinding sound coming from the wheel well while driving. The vehicle was stopped at a safe location and inspected. The front right passenger wheel was not in alignment with the front left wheel, and water was visible and dripping from the undercarriage of the vehicle in the same vicinity. The vehicle was deemed unsafe to drive and Enterprise was called for roadside assistance.
ImmediateAction: internal reporting initiated.

Project: China - synthomer OMNOVA VPL UPGRADE PROJECT
ShortDescription: The excavator broke a water supply line  and causing water leakage while excavating
ContractorName: Jiangsu Qi 'an Construction Group Co. LTD
FullDescription: On August 23rd, 2022. At 7.50 A.M. The construction contractor QI'AN received a work permit to conduct excavation work with excavators on the south side of the Preparation WS structure. 8:05 A.M.  When excavating to the southwest corner of the structure, the excavator broke a water supply line branch pipe that was buried about a half meter underground, causing water leakage.The construction manager immediately reported the matter to the Owner maintenance manager and asked for help in closing the valve and cutting off the water. 8.15 A.M.  When the water valve was closed the construction contractor began to organize pumping water and repair the water pipe.  9:55 A.M. Pumping water completed and plugging water, Wang Jun began to coordinate the repair. At this point, the water supply was cut off for about 2 hours. 14:50 A.M. The constructor construction manager continues to organize an excavation search for the water supply main line. The owner clarification pipeline buried depth is about 1.2 m.After digging 1m deep then prepare for manual digging after mechanical cleaning of the soil. But the excavator still carried on digging the soil and touched the water supply main line causing leakage.The construction manager contacted the Owner maintenance Manager to shut off the valve water and then organize to repair the pipe.  15:30 A.M. Pumping water was complete and plugging, the water supply was cut off for about half an hour.
ImmediateAction: 1. Stopped the excavation work immediately2. Investigated the incident 3. Conducted time out for the safety

ShortDescription: IP (AM) reported to PFA feeling unwell with upset stomach.

FullDescription: One Wood employee was tested positive for COVID when was at home.

ShortDescription: Brief Electrical low voltage Incipient Arc smoldering caused by a malfunctioning T-connector
FullDescription: On Tuesday, August 23, 2022, around 5:30pm, Wood employees in the vicinity of block 4-6 saw what appeared to be smoke. Employees grabbed a Fire Extinguisher and immediately moved to investigate. In route employees notified their supervision and HSSE team of the witnessed smoke. At the scene of the incident employees saw that the plastic wire loom tubing was smoldering and melting. The plastic wire loom tube covers the T-section of the harness and string cable. The brief Electrical low voltage incipient Arc and smoldering was caused by a malfunctioning T-connector. The crew was able to contain the active Electrical Arc to ground from smoldering and spreading by utilizing a 5lb. extinguisher, with no injuries. The actual severity rating is A1 since no employees were in close proximity to the electrical incipient event when it occurred. The potential severity rating is an A2 since the damage could not have resulted in more than 10-100k in damages and the electrical incipient event was quickly contained.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The scene was frozen and the incipient smoldering event was contained and monitored, de-energized and lock-out into further investigation, photos of the incident were collected.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: A Wood logistics technician injured his foot while moving a pallet of material with a pallet jack.  First aid only.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, August 23, 2022, at approximately 16:15, the IP was tasked with moving pallets of material in the back of a delivery van trailer so they could be unloaded with a telehandler.  As the IP was moving one of the pallets of material, the pallet jack rolled toward the wall of the trailer pinching the IP’s right foot between the pallet and the wall resulting in a contusion to the back of his inner right foot which only required first aid measures.  The Actual Severity is B1 because the injury only required first aid measures.  The Potential Severity is a B2, because the injury could have required medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: The IP reported the injury to his supervisor.  The supervisor called the Senior HSSES Advisor and reported the incident.  The Senior HSSES Advisor initiated a call to Axiom and a nurse contacted the IP and gave him first aid measures to follow.

ShortDescription: Water truck driver was backing up when his back left tire caught the edge of a slope causing the truck to slide down over on its side

While backing up (under 5MPH), his left rear tire caught the edge of the slope pulling the truck over on it's side. Driver was wearing his seatbelt and reported no injuries, thus refusing any medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: Kelchner Safety was immediately notified along with the General Contractor. Safety arrived to take witness statements, document the damages and to assess any injuries.

ShortDescription: Subcontractor installing tie rods on micropile overextended the tie rod which pinched IP's finger against the internal wall of the micropile
FullDescription: Work activity was the installation of tie rods into micropiles. The action involves inserting a tie rod through a pre-drilled hole in the micropile and applying a securing nut. IP who was wearing impact gloves at the time was in the process of inserting the tie rod with his left hand and applying the securing nut inside the micropile with his right hand. It was at this point the IP overextended the tie rod, which pinched IP’s right thumb against the inner wall of the micropile.The IP reported to the spread supervisor upon which the advanced first aider assessed the IP. The IP was then transferred to Moro clinic for further evaluation, where minor first aid was applied. IP was also cleared to return to normal duties.
ImmediateAction: Operation was stopped. Advanced first aider attended to IP.Consultation with Moro Doctor, advice given to bring the IP to Moro clinic for further evaluation.

ShortDescription: IP suffered Cold Burn when charging compressor with Freon 407C gas.
FullDescription: This incident took place when IP was charging Freon Gas into provision compressor. Upon completion of charging the Freon 407C gas into the provision compressor, IP had closed the system valve at this time. IP proceed to dismantle the charging hose and immediately after, Freon 407C gas started discharging out from the cylinder hose and splashed onto IP’s hands.
ImmediateAction: Upon further inspection, it was found by the IP that the cylinder valve was partially closed. Immediately, the IP closed the valve completely and seek medical attention from the medic.
OtherCauseofInjuryIncident: Contact with / exposure to refrigerant gas

ShortDescription: Subcontractor did not properly secure trailer prior to jacking up the trailer. Trailer shifted and fell over, no injury, no damage/
FullDescription: EP was preparing to place the tires on the east side of the trailer. The tires on the west side of the trailer were already in place. Two piers (supports) were present on the south end of the trailer. The trailer was connected to the hydraulic six-way hitch, which was connected to the "Toter" truck. EP stated that the pier on the southwest corner of the trailer was on unlevel/uncompacted material. EP stated that when he began to jack up the trailer the pier on the southwest corner shifted and fell over which allowed the trailer to shift west (down gradient).The EP was not in the line fire. The Willscot technician stated " should have done a better assessment of the situation prior to jacking up the trailer". EP took full responsibility for the incident.
ImmediateAction: Reporting initiated.

ShortDescription: Flatbed truck loaded with scaffolding struck 30' light pole with back right side trailer approx. at rear tandem , light pole struck ground
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: Truck checked in at CPS Security, was somehow released without escort, truck driver drove around plant property somehow found Wood  jobsite drove around laydown, no spotter or escort, then drove around service road of Ammonia Farm, where driver was taking right hand turnaround to sharp contacted light pole knocking it to ground and destroying it. Wood GF Carlos Salazar contacted Chris Cox and Brian Holly over radio immediately, truck was still moving around site we finally stopped him on service road close to job trailers. CPS/AECOM was contacted, we started taking pictures for investigation. Only property damage occurred, no one was hurt. Porfirio Zuniga contacted trucking company and informed them about there driver having an accident. Jason Fralia, David Garcia were contacted immediately as well. The Actual/Potential of the incident is a B1/B5.
ImmediateAction: Truck was parked, driver was brought in for witness statement, Truck cannot be offloaded until investigation is finished. CPS Contacted Bexar County Sheriff, has already come and left making a report oh this situation.

Addition force was applied to the trolley jack to get it moving again resulting in a momentary loss of control and striking the corner of a low level plant light cover. Damage to the cover was minimal and no damage was inflicted on the light tubes inside.
ImmediateAction: The T&I Electrical superintendent was called to test the light to ensure it was safe and to determine whether a replacement cover could be sourced. No covers were available therefore the individual light was isolated from the circuit until a new cover can be sourced.

ShortDescription: IP felt a twinge in their back following removal of blind hubs
FullDescription: IP was working on PDR level 1 carrying out housekeeping duties, 3 x10' blind hubs had to be removed from the area and due to the restricted space the team had to position themselves on their hands and knees. The hubs had to be dragged out by the IP and a colleague with the weight of the hubs estimated to be between 80-100kgs. A general manual handling risk assessment had been completed at the start of the task. As the 3rd hub was removed the IP felt a twinge in their back, the IP believed their back would be ok following rest overnight however as their back was still sore they visited the medic on the 17/08 at 08:00 who provided Ibuprofen and paracetamol .

ShortDescription: IP suffered finger injury while utilising stillson wrench hand tool
FullDescription: A production technician was conducting duties in preparation for a leak test to be performed. As per P&ID, Valve-2225 had to be moved from the open to closed position. The work party located and identified the valve accordingly, but noticed the valve had no wheel handle, only a rusty stem was visible where the valve wheel handle once was. Due to the valve having no wheel handle, the IP made the decision to utilise a stillson wrench tool to close the valve. During this process, the stillson wrench tool slipped, causing the IP's right hand ring finger to contact between the stillson wrench tool and the valve body. At this point the IP noticed blood seeping through his glove. The IP immediately made his way to the installation medic, where he received first aid attention. The IP de-mobbed the following day via his normal crew change helicopter and was then seen onshore for further follow up medical assessment.
ImmediateAction: IP stopped the job, made the worksite safe and proceeded to see the medic. IP de-mobilised the following day via his normal crew change helicopter. IP had a follow up medical assessment via ISOS. Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: IP Hurt his knee, Sharp pain in left side of ITB area
FullDescription: IP felt a sharp pain felt in the left side of his knee and thigh area during the maneuvering of the Hull Manway Cover into position (manway cover weighing approximately 30kg with a 2 person lift using short slings for ease).IP stopped work and reported incident to platform PIC.
ImmediateAction: Stopped work immediately once manway cover was in a safe position, reported incident to Platform PIC, received first aid treatment.

ShortDescription: Two (2) Massy Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: Two (2) Massy Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19.
ImmediateAction: Employees were taken to designated quarantine area to await demobilization from site.

ShortDescription: A 240 SGT employee tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: A 240 SGT employee who was working from home tested positive for COVID-19.
ImmediateAction: Employee self-isolated.

ShortDescription: Employee cut finger as they were plugging in laptop to socket in the office.
FullDescription: The employee had to plug their laptop in at desk SS161 and had to lift the flap on the floor where the plug sockets are.the plug cover which is on a hinge, fallen shut onto her finger resulting in a cut.
ImmediateAction: a plaster was given for the cut...there was no issue or damage with the flap that covers the plugs

ShortDescription: Positive Covid-19 test
FullDescription: On Tuesday 16 August employee had symptoms of weakness in the afternoon and fever in the evening. The antigen test was positive result this morning 17 August. Employee stayed at home.
ImmediateAction: Isolation of the individualcontact tracingtesting close contact
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Diesel leak from PEC Diesel Tank Truck
FullDescription: Diesel truck operator & worker were filling diesel to a 70-ton crane. The worker accessed the crane’s fuel tank to commence filling while the diesel truck operator turned the isolation valve to the open position. After filling for about 5 minutes, diesel started to leak at the connection of the flow meter. The diesel truck operator shut off the isolation valve. Final reading of flowmeter was concluded that 5 liters of diesel spilled to the concrete ground.
ImmediateAction: Diesel top up operation was stopped. Absorbent pads were deployed to contain and clean up spill. Incident was cascaded to Wood HSSE Department.

ShortDescription: Drill rig was drilling #6 hole of the day when at 7' deep contacted something, drill bit had pvc, conduit and wire wrapped around it
FullDescription: Drill rig was drilling #6 hole of the day when at 7' deep contacted something, drill bit had pvc, conduit and wire wrapped around with chunks of red concrete. 	Munoz drilling ( subcontractor ) was drilling 30" pier when at 7' contacted something, upon removal from hole pieces of pvc and wire with red concrete were wrapped around the drill bit. Wood immediately stopped work and contacted AECOM / CPS. Upon arrival it was potentially an abandoned duct-bank from a while back. CPS /AECOM are investigating further. Investigation confirmed duct-bank struck was active and live. CPS took blame because the drawing showing this line was not given to us. 811, GPRS and hydro dig did not locate it because it was not even known , so how could we locate it.
ImmediateAction: Drilling stopped for the day until further investigation is concluded

ShortDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
FullDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
ImmediateAction: IP is isolating and recovering at home

ShortDescription: Whilst placing tool bag on his shoulder employee has felt a twinge in his lower back.
FullDescription: Whilst placing tool bag on his shoulder employee has felt a twinge in his lower back.
ImmediateAction: Reported to SCEE supervisors and SCEE HSE. Taken to site medic for treatment.

ShortDescription: Whilst placing tool bag on his shoulder employee has felt a twinge in his lower back.
FullDescription: Whilst placing tool bag on his shoulder employee has felt a twinge in his lower back.
ImmediateAction: Reported to SCEE supervisors and SCEE HSE. Taken to site medic for treatment.

ShortDescription: IP went to the medic offshore not feeling well, blood sugar levels were found to be low.
FullDescription: IP reported to offshore medic he was not feeling well. The medic checked his blood sugar and determined it was hypoglycemia. Gave IP a drip solution and requested IP report to hospital on the mainland. IP is currently under observation at La Paz hospital, Malabo Equatorial Guinea.
ImmediateAction: IP was requested to come to town on the crew change helicopter for further observation at the hospital on the mainland. Medic was not overly concerned, as treatment is readily available. IP has been submitted to the hospital for treatment and observation.  IP to remain on campus where they will be monitored and provided with a special diet.  IP found fit to resume normal duties 29 Aug 2022.*Note: It was determined that the IP did not fast correctly prior to a medical checkup and was administered medication to reduce blood sugar levels, IP does not have a history of hyperglycemia.  Hence the reason their blood sugar levels were low when experiencing initial symptoms.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0075 FA; abrasion left thigh
FullDescription: While IP was grinding a weld the wire brush wheel struck left leg causing minor abrasion.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped, supervisor contacted. IP brought to on-site PA, scene frozen by contactor HSE. IP returned to work. Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: IP toppled office chair backwards, sustaining cut to back of head
FullDescription: IP was working from home yesterday due to a discomfort he has whilst sitting. To alleviate this discomfort he leant backwards, his chair toppled and he hit his head on a table behind him causing a laceration to his head.
ImmediateAction: IP had wound glued at A&E and returned to work.IP's home working DSE assessment checked and indicates no flags.Home workstation set-up, including computer, etc., provided by IP not Wood. Chair is indicated to be a 5-point office chair with casters. The action causing injury deemed not to be directly related to the performance of the work. (OSHA 1004.5(b)(7))

ShortDescription: Lifting and Rigging Incident
FullDescription: During lifting and rigging operations, it was observed the lifting package (documentation) was incomplete. There was no potential for an injury to occur.
ImmediateAction: The rigging and lifting operations were immediately shut down and a safety stand-down was held.

FullDescription: IP had scanned security pass, had gone to walk through the barriers, however, barrier closed on their face.
ImmediateAction: IP reported to security. security tested the barrier and seems to be an intermittent fault. security blocked the access turnstile off until it has been inspected by qualified person.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Two (2) Massy Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: Two (2) Massy Wood employees tested positive for COVID-19.

ShortDescription: Flashover on the bottom phase of Circuit 2 at tower 13.
FullDescription: At 11:20 today the OHL teams had recovered the CASS from span 13 to 14 (railway) and following a short water break, climbed the tower to reposition the ladder from the bottom phase of Circuit 1 to the top phase of Circuit 1 in preparation for CASS deployment. It was during the removal of the ladder from the bottom phase of Circuit 1 that the ladder swung towards the live side before encroaching electrical arcing distance which then resulted in the flashover event, the flash over caused the circuit to trip out.  No personnel were injured as a result of this incident.
ImmediateAction: All personnel exited the Tower and the site was made safe and operations suspended.Incident reported to the Client and escalated through the Power Solutions UK reporting procedure.All involved personnel underwent Drug and Alcohol testing protocols.

ShortDescription: A wood rigger was working on the top of 1F1, in area north, changing out bearings on a shaft when he felt something enter his right eye.
FullDescription: A wood rigger and fitter were changing out bearing on a shaft on the top of 1F1 Furnace located in the North area - Crude. While the rigger was rotating the shaft using stillsons to align the bolt holes, and being in a very awkward position, felt something enter his right eye. The area he was working in was fully blanketed for drops protection and he was working inside a humpy. At the time the wind was blowing and it appears that a gust of wind has blown a spec of unknown material into the the riggers right eye.
ImmediateAction: The rigger notified his supervisor and was transported to the medical Centre for review and treatment. The nurse located the spec of material and was successful in removing it from the eye and applied eye drops to protect the eye. Rigger was release to return to work with a f9ollowup review beginning of next shift.

ShortDescription: IP was ascending pipe bridge stairs and stunbled into upright process pipe resulting in injury to right shoulder
FullDescription: Area operator waqs condcuting routine equipment checjks at the nitrogen injection facility (NIF). when he went to ascend a small (2 steps) over the he caugt his foot on the top step causing him to fall forward and collide with process line. This cuased an impact to his right shoulder,
ImmediateAction: The IP felt discomfort and returned to the control room to be seen by a first aider. an Ice pack was appliedNHS 24 was called and the IP was advised to rest. The IP was escorted home.

ShortDescription: IP was experiencing symptoms and then diagnosed with Malaria.
FullDescription: IP (South African expat) is an offshore employee who started having headaches, chills, and on & off fever. IP was diagnosed with Malaria.
ImmediateAction: IP has been issued medication and condition will be monitored.  If condition improves the IP will return offshore on 15 August 2022.  IP is in isolation and resting.IP continues to have headaches and on and off fever and was given more medications today, 15 Aug. IP will have blood tests tomorrow and will probably be Wednesday, 17 Aug. before IP is fit to return to work.17 Aug, IP has shown post malaria symptoms and for precautionary measure, he was taken back to onshore and handed over to La Paz hospital. IP was transferred uneventful to la Paz and medical handover done to ER doctor at la Paz. Doctor's plan currently is to Admit for observation tonight and further testing being conducted.19 Aug, IP was cleared to return home unescorted in business class.

ShortDescription: Crane load made contact with PA sign
FullDescription: While conducting a lift with the crane, the dog man that was instructing the crane lost communication on the radio he was using. The load was being lowered at the time and the dogman was trying to stop the load, the spotter that was above then instructed the crane to stop but the load contacted a PA sign.
ImmediateAction: Lowered the load to deck, notified OIM. Radio was inspected and found issue with antenna.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
FullDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
ImmediateAction: Employee recovering at home

FullDescription: Two (2) managed contractor employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offsite.

Project: US East - Oil & Gas - All Other Clients
ShortDescription: IP experienced a sharp pain to right shoulder and arm that subsided within a few seconds. The pain returned over next days of IP's hitch.
FullDescription: On 08/12/22 IP was holding back the side panel of the HP pump so that maintenance could be performed by the mechanic. IP was exerting force by pulling and pushing when IP felt a sharp pain in his right shoulder. IP stated that the pain only lasted a few seconds and subsided. IP stated that all felt normal. IP stated that he was operating the crane all day on 08/14/22 when he felt stiffness in his right shoulder. IP slept the night and awoke with aching in the right shoulder. IP reported to the OIM and was initially evaluated by the onsite Medic who evaluated IP for injury. IP stated he had limited movement due to stiffness in the affected area. (B1) Actual: IP stated that the Medic administered OTC was administered for the pain and swelling. IP was advised that he was able to continue to operate/perform normal function as the crane operator. (B2) Potential of injury may have resulted in Medical Treatment and restricted work if severity of injury was worse. IP stopped physical exertion when he felt the sharp pain.
ImmediateAction: After pain and stiffness was reported the onsite medic issued OTC for the pain. IP continued to be monitored. Pain and stiffness persisted Anadarko/Oxy Medical Control gave the order to send IP ashore for further medical evaluation. IP was evaluated by physician at clinic The diagnosis by attending physician was a "Sprain of the right acromioclavicular joint with a disposition to take OTC as needed. IP was released, "Fit for duty" without restrictions. Starting 08/18/22.

ShortDescription: IP tweaked back when installing electrical cables
FullDescription: IP was tasked with cable pulling under a stairway to the ALQ roof. Whilst accessing the work space, he was reaching over a pallet of material and felt a slight twinge in his back but no pain. He continued with his task until lunch and rested over lunch. When he got up after lunch, he felt pain in his back and presented on the medic. He then returned to work shortly afterwards. Upon returning to work, the IP was able to carry on with his work which was not a significant deviation from his normal duties as an electrician.
ImmediateAction: IP visited medic, given paracetamol and returned to duties.

ShortDescription: A managed contractor employee tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: A managed contractor employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offsite.
ImmediateAction: Managed contractor self-isolated.

Project: US East - Oil & Gas - All Other Clients
ShortDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID.
FullDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID after developing mild symptoms while aboard EI 314A. EE will home isolate and monitor the condition. Contract tracing is complete.
ImmediateAction: EE was sent in for isolation and will monitor the condition.

ShortDescription: Wrongly cut the 3/4 inch pipe cooling water system pipe
FullDescription: Group of assigned workers were tasked to do pipe modification work. During the process, the supervisor wrongly instructed the worker to cut a 3/4 inch cooling water system pipe (S9203) After noticing water coming from the pipe, the worker realized that it was live system pipe. Immediately, he stopped cutting and informed his supervisor. Subsequently, they proceed to inform the Arkema's in-charge person .All related works stopped and the cooling water system was isolated. No injury reported and no further damage.
ImmediateAction: Stakeholders were notified. Safety stand down was conducted and detail investigation ensued.

ShortDescription: IP complained of chest pains.
FullDescription: At approximately 09:45 on Friday 12th August, a civils worker complained of having chest pains during the morning break . The conditions at the time were warm and sunny.
ImmediateAction: IP was able to walk to management office where he informed Project Manager of issue. Client Fire Dept (first aid) attended and administered IP with oxygen. Ambulance subsequently attended and took IP for further tests. One of the contractor management team accompanied IP to hospital.

ShortDescription: IP tested positive for Covid-19, IP was fully vaccinated.
FullDescription: As per Total Access Policy site personnel shall be PCR tested on weekly basis. On the third week of the rotation, IP was PCR tested and the test result came positive for COVID-19. IP instructed to self-isolate at home.
ImmediateAction: WoodKSS senior management and Total contract holder notified. IP instructed to self-isolate at home.

ShortDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 during PCR testing at site location.

FullDescription: One (1) Massy Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19.
ImmediateAction: Employee taken to designated quarantine area to await demobilization.

ShortDescription: Whilst conducting removal of corroded U-bolt, pneumatic Sawzall came into contact with fusible loop tubing, damaging same.
FullDescription: Whilst conducting removal of corroded U-bolt on 2” gas line in preparation for installation of new U-bolt, the pneumatic Sawzall being used by the rigger inadvertently came into contact with the adjacent fusible loop tubing causing a small penetration in same. At the time of the incident, the workarea was barricaded and there were no personnel located in the line of fire. There is no evidence to suggest injury to personnel.
ImmediateAction: Client Operations were immediately notified of the incident via Control Room systems and the job was immediately stopped. All personnel were removed from the site, all other jobs were subsequently stood down and an Operations team visited the location. The tubing was subsequently replaced by Client Operations. Joint safety stand down was held with all personnel to discuss the incident, immediate actions taken and potential way forward.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
FullDescription: One Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19 while at home
ImmediateAction: Employee is recovering at home

ShortDescription: IP felt heat stress related symptoms and informed FS of his condition. IP went to recover in truck with first aid. IP returned to work later
FullDescription: IP was feeling heat stress symptoms at around 10:30am (of Fri. Aug. 12) and informed the Field Supervisor (FS) of change in condition. IP felt tired, some muscle soreness, slightly light headed, and momentary confusion. Following prior heat related incidents across the archaeology department, the FS implemented heat mitigation strategies prior to the incident which included daily tailgate safety reminders regarding the heat, reminding staff at every half hour interval to drink water, checking up on workers conducting demanding tasks and suggesting they can switch tasks. However, by 10:30 IP was feeling the symptoms listed above and requested a "quick 5minute" air conditioned break in the work truck. The FS agreed and IP's condition did not improve within this time. IP was given ice cold water (from a cooler on site), and Gatorade powder by the FS for IP to consume for his recovery. IP remained in the air conditioned environment until lunch break which started at 11:00am. At the end of lunch break (11.30am) IP said he was fit for duty to return to work but required only screening rather digging tasks during archaeological excavation. For additional precaution, FS set up a tent for IP to conduct work tasks under. IP was instructed to call workcare. On the morning following the incident (sat. aug. 13), the FS was told that IP tested positive for Covid-19. Heat related symptoms may have been triggered as a result of the early onset symptoms of this infection.
ImmediateAction: IP put in an air conditioned truck to lay back, was given cold water and electrolyte powder

ShortDescription: Underground water line strike, minor
FullDescription: Subcontractor driller struck buried water line, approximately 3 inches in diameter, about 1 foot below ground surface. Possible irrigation line of neighbor’s facility.
ImmediateAction: Neighboring facility contacted; Reported to HSSE

ShortDescription: Working inside traffic zone tanker trailer clipped traffic cone, sent cone flying near IP, not striking IP
FullDescription: Employee was working inside a traffic control zone taking chloride samples when a super B tanker trailer clipped a traffic cone sending it flying near the employee but not striking him. Site was lit up by a LED light stand as well as the Wood and Traffic control Work trucks
ImmediateAction: Internal reporting

ShortDescription: Preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury
FullDescription: Moving truck in reverse during paving operation, checking for oncoming traffic on driver's side. Did not see contractor's truck parked behind, off the passengers side. Bumped into other vehicles Grill Guard.
ImmediateAction: Internal reporting initiated.

ShortDescription: Preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury
FullDescription: IP was distracted talking to a coworker, and as IP was turning to the left IP scrapped the truck against a stainless steel well head. IP knew the well head was there, misjudged how close.
ImmediateAction: internal reporting initiated

ShortDescription: Slip and fall causing back injury
FullDescription: Employee was tasked with welding a o-let (coupling) on a 12" pipe at the production separators. The area is congested with pipe as all pipe sits on a 8" steel beam that is directly sitting on the ground. Employee attempted to cross a 6" pipe that is approximately 18" off the ground. He stepped on the pipe to get across and slipped. He landed on his back on the pipe that he was attempting to cross. He was helped to his feet and into the superintendent's truck. The incident is classified as a B1/B1 as it is being treated as a first aid.
ImmediateAction: Injured employee was helped into the HSSE Advisor's truck for transport to Occ Med clinic.  OccuCare was notified and a medical representative contacted the IP and advised ibuprofen,  and an ice pack for pain, and would re-evaluate on Monday.  After consultation, the IE still requested to see an Occ Med clinic.

ShortDescription: Rock rolled down slope and struck contractor
FullDescription: The SBI labor crew was cleaning out the west slope south down drain when a six (6) inch rock was knocked out and rolled down the slope thirty (30) feet.  The rock struck an ESI employee in the hip causing no injury.  The ESI employee was on the ground repairing the liner at the time of the incident.  The ESI personnel did not notify the SBI labor crew they were going to be working at a lower level.
ImmediateAction: Work was stopped and the employee hit by the rock was evaluated.  Everyone involved reviewed the incident and discussed what steps need to be changed to prevent this type of incident from reoccurring.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee’s tire blew out on his commute home causing minor damage to the vehicle.
FullDescription: On Thursday, August 11, 2022, at approximately 1600, The Wood employee was on his commute home from work on interstate 25 north. Outside of Kaycee WY and the front driver tire blew out. The EE pulled over to the side of the road to inspect what happened and noticed damage to the wheel well and wire housing units. The truck needed to be towed as it was not operational. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Contacted HSE

ShortDescription: A stack of metal forms fell off the forks of an all-terrain forklift while unloading the forms off a trailer.
FullDescription: A stack of metal forms fell off the forks of an all-terrain forklift while unloading the forms off a trailer. The metal forms were bolted together to prevent movement while in transit to the jobsite. The forklift operator positioned the forks under the stack, lifted, and began to move the forklift. As the forklift moved, the load slid off the forks. No site employees were within the potential strike zone. The actual severity rating is an A1 as no damage occurred. The potential severity rating is an A1 as no employees were located within the exclusion zone.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped; investigation started

ShortDescription: Front tipping mini dumper truck inadvertently turned onto its side when transporting spoil down a slope into an excavation.
FullDescription: A front tipping mini dumper truck (supplied and operated by our civil contractor, Tolent) was transporting spoil from a spoil heap into an excavation as part of the backfilling process for the oil interceptor (concrete chamber). As the dumper truck was maneuvering down the excavation access slope it inadvertently rolled onto its side (see attached photo). The truck was fitted with a roll over protection bar and the operators seat belt was securely fastened and therefore the operator remained in the seated position. No personal injury was sustained during the incident, however a small leak of what looks to be hydraulic oil has resulted from the vehicle.
ImmediateAction: The activity has been suspended and the area secured.2. The dumper truck has been quarantined.3. The dumper truck driver has been suspended from his operator duties pending investigation.4. The dumper truck driver has provided a sample for analysis re: the purpose of substance abuse. Initial screening showed negative for alcohol and ilicit drugs.5. All other dumper truck operations have been suspended and subject to review.6. Engagement session held with site team to share initial learning and reiterate relevant expectations.7. Various samples, measurements, pictures have been taken from the incident area prior to repositioning the truck back onto four wheels.8. The equipment manufacturer / supplier has been consulted in preparation for repositioning the vehicle back onto four wheels.

ShortDescription: Operative complained of feeling dizzy whilst carrying out ground role in hot weather.
FullDescription: At approximately 10:00hrs on 11/08/2022 a sub-contractor operative complained of feeling dizzy whilst conducting ground activities at Tower PWA 24.  These activities were being conducted in hot and sunny weather conditions.  On reporting his dizziness to his chargehand the immediate action taken was to take the operative out of the sun and ensure he immediately hydrated himself.  Thereafter the operative was stood down from all working activities and monitored throughout the day by his chargehand and the Project Manager.  At approximately 15:30hrs work ceased due to the temperatures and the OHL teams returned to their accommodation. At this point the operative did not complain of any additional symptoms or request any medical assistance.
ImmediateAction: Operative stood downOperative monitored throughout day for hydration and any additional symptoms.HEART Card submitted.

ShortDescription: Damage to Anti-Climbing Device
FullDescription: On the 11/08/2022 at approximately 07:50 hrs., at tower DLB 57  a operative working for a Sub Contractor was carrying out reinstatement works at the base of the Tower, under a Limitation of Access document.  The operative was using a Mini Digger to carry out this task under the control of a Banksman.  After believing he had completed the task the operative reversed the mini digger away from the tower base, during this maneuver the mini digger crossed an area of uneven ground which resulted in the Knuckle of the Digger's Boom to raise approximately 6-7 inches and contact the ACD damaging one strand of the Barbed wire on the ACD. This was then reported to the WOOD Forman based at the site immediately
ImmediateAction: Work was suspended for approximately 10 minutes to access the damageThe Wood on site Forman contacted the Project construction manager who then reported to SSEN at 8.20 AMIt was agreed that the SAP would issue a L.O.A. to rectify the ACD repairA TBT was issued and delivered to the Sub Contractor Personnel regarding care and attention whilst working near to ACD's .

ShortDescription: East Crane boom impacted stairway during commissioning
FullDescription: As the east crane’s boom was being lowered into the boom rest, it became slightly off centre and connected with the top of the boom rest moving the boom westerly rather than easterly into the boom rest. This westerly movement caused the  booms left walkway frame to make minor contact with the MOD G stair tower handrail. Minor damage occurred to the hand rail and the cranes chord where it connected with the boom rest. MOD G stair tower is close to the cranes boom when in the rest. This is due to the construction crane being on the drill floor (MOD G) and the skid needing to be as far east as possible to allow maximum boom reach during decommissioning and construction of the east cranes.The crane is still in its commissioning phase.
ImmediateAction: The crane was positioned into the boom rest and shut down.All work ceased and incident reported.Boom and stair tower were inspected.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee tested positive for COVID-19
FullDescription: A Wood employee reported to Wood supervision on  08/11/2022 that they began to experience COV19 s/s on   08/11/2022.  On   08/11/2022 the employee continued to have worsening s/s and took a home COV19 test which was positive for COV19. The employee was last on site on  08/10/2022. Contact Tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.
ImmediateAction: Employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  Wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

ShortDescription: Two (2) managed contractor employee tested positive for COVID-19.
FullDescription: Two (2) managed contractor employee tested positive for COVID-19 whilst offsite.
ImmediateAction: Managed contractor employee self-isolated.

ShortDescription: Wood Mechanical Technician experienced breathing difficulty after inhaling H2S during a breaking of containment task
FullDescription: During work on the sea sump pump replacement, a Wood Mechanical Technician was removing the bolts from the flange when their gas monitor activated and they could smell hydrocarbons.The area was immediately vacated.The Mechanical Technician continued to work for the remainder of their shift.During the Mechanical Technician's rest period they experienced difficulty with breathing, so at the start of the following shift (Friday the 12th @ 18:30) they reported to the platform Medic.Medical checks were carried out and no treatment was administered.The Mechanical Technician was MEDEVAC'd late on Saturday the 13th and taken to Gilbert Bain Hospital in Shetland for further examination.They were released from Hospital early Sunday morning, assisted by the Shetland Responders MCM to a local Hotel. They then flew back to Aberdeen on Sunday morning and used the train to return home.
ImmediateAction: Individual reported to the Medic approximately 20hrs after their gas monitor had alarmed while they were completing a BoC task.Medic gave treatmentIndividual continued to report breathing issues, decision made to MEDEVAC individual to Gilbert Bain Hospital for further assessment.Released from Hospital and told to visit their own GP in 7-days time.Exposure monitoring / sample was taken for benzene, results returned negative for benzeneOnce the gas monitor was analysed, it was discovered the alarm had been activated by H2S

ShortDescription: IP was installing a star picket with a steel post driver, IP missed the star picket and hit above right knee with steel post driver.
FullDescription: IP was setting up barricades around work area in 2264/2265 using steel star picket and flags. IP used a steel post driver to drive steel star picket into the ground. The star picket was standing 120mm into the ground when IP missed the the star picket and the steel post driver landed above his right knee.
ImmediateAction: Witness called medic and reported to Supervisor.
CauseOfInjuryIncident: Contact with tool/equipment/machinery,Struck by moving object

ShortDescription: Active Permit to Work not signed by the Permit Receiver
FullDescription: The Ampol Training and Competency Specialist was conducting a PTW SSI (INS - 0039825) on a WOOD work crew at module 11C8 in the Area East DHTU.The WOOD work team were conducting a CSE on the vessel through the top man hole to perform a welding task on the inner wall as part of the DHTU1 T&I.Whilst reviewing the Permit, the T&C Specialist identified that the PTW had not been signed by the Permit Receiver.On further questioning, it was clear that the CSE Spotter was unaware of who the Permit Receiver for the task actually was.The T&C Specialist stopped the job and requested that the entrants remove themselves from the space until the PTW could be rectified and Permit Receiver identified.Ampol HSE lead was notified along with the WOOD Supervisor for the task.A meeting was conducted with the Confined Space Spotter,  the Wood Supervisor and the Ampol HSE lead with a way forward agreed. - Permit was returned to the Permit Office and the issue discussed with Operations. - Permit signed by the Wood Supervisor at the Permit Hut in agreement with Operations and HSE. - Work on 11C8 re-commenced.
ImmediateAction: Workfront was stopped personnel removed from the confined space, permit receiver (supervisor) was located and the permit was returned to the Permit issuer where the permit receiver signed the permit and work recommenced.

FullDescription: Project tested positive on 7 and 8 Aug 2022. He is currently doing quarantine at site and has no symptoms

A fire watch was in place for 30 minutes afterwards to ensure it did not reignite.No asset damage - trash only burnt

ShortDescription: Chemical Release
FullDescription: On Wednesday 10th August 2022, approximately 3pm, whilst conducting an inspection at the Galeota Warehouse back yard, it was observed, turbine waste oil from its primary containment was leaking into its secondary containment.  There was no potential for the oil to be released from secondary containment into any water-courses or the environment.
ImmediateAction: 1. The client was notified, and arrangements are being made for schedule waste disposal of the oil.2. Turbine Waste Oil was removed from its compromised primary containment into another barrel.3. Spill containment material was placed around the secondary containment.

ShortDescription: conducting amphibian sweeps, felt symptoms of heat exhaustion

ImmediateAction: moved into shade

ShortDescription: IP sustained an injury to their right shoulder while hand excavating in heavy soil.
FullDescription: While excavating in heavy clay soils IP sustained a minor strain to the their right shoulder. IP was using a square-end spade with a three-foot handle at the time of injury. IP was digging in heavy clay soil during an archaeological excavation. IP described it "popping out and immediately back in." IP believed it to be a subluxation. IP described their shoulder joint or muscle as being weak to begin with so this may be an aggravation of a chronic issue. IP had been upset at the shovel prior to the incident and did not feel that it was the appropriate tool for the job or that it was ergnomically appropriate for themselves. IP voiced these concerns to FS shortly before the incident and FS said that would inquire about new equipment. After the incident IP finished up the task and then informed FS about the injury, about 15 minutes after it happened. FS directed IP to call WorkCare. IP indicated that the WorkCare nurse recommended ice three times a day, OTC pain relief, and to take it easy to avoid aggravating the injury. No immediate First Aid was administered because IP was able to accomplish these suggestions themselves at home within a short time frame.
ImmediateAction: Finished activity then informed supervisor. Supervisor advised IP to call WorkCare for guidance.

ShortDescription: IP lifted a concrete cylinder to place it in the curing tank and managed to strain their elbow while doing so.
FullDescription: IP was receiving concrete cylinders. When placing them in the tank the IP somehow put too much stress on elbow causing a strain to occur.
ImmediateAction: Iced the elbow, called workcare, informed supervisors.

ShortDescription: A tailgating incident occurred at the door 51 entrance whereby a delivery driver followed in a Wood employee and clients.
FullDescription: A Wood employee used their security pass to access door 51, they have then held the door open to allow 3 clients to gain access. the delivery driver has tailgated the 3 clients to gain access to the building. The tailgating incident was observed by wood employees who tried to intervene however, by this time the delivery driver had already made their way to reception and the clients had disappeared. The Wood employees who witnessed the incident reported it immediately to HSE.
ImmediateAction: The Wood employees who witnessed the incident reported it immediately to HSE and submitted a HEART observation. Security was asked to view CCTV to identify the client's and the security pass user.

ShortDescription: Electrical PVC conduit embedded in a concrete floor was broken/cut in two (2) locations by Hand held tools.
FullDescription: While using jackhammers to excavate around pipes for a repair, the tool broke a portion of the concrete into the subgrade and made contact with an electrical PVC conduit. PVC conduit was cut/broken in two (2) locations. Fuel operations and base electricians were notified and both arrived on site to assess any impact to operations. Incident is classified as a 1) Near Miss  2) Property Damage.
ImmediateAction: Fuel operations and base electricians were notified and both arrived on site to assess any impact to operations.

ShortDescription: A window of a excavator was shattered.
FullDescription: A window of a excavator was damaged.  On August 9, 2022, at approximately 11:30 am, an operator was assisting with ditch repair and as he attempted to remove material from the ditch, the front window of the machine shattered.  The operator tried to contact the Site General Foreman, but received no answer, so he continued to work.  At the end of the day as the operator was leaving the project, he told the GF about the incident. When asked why he did not inform direct supervisor earlier, the operator said the incident slipped his mind.  The operator did mention that a spotter was present during the work activity, but the spotter did not see the incident occur. The incident is still under investigation. The actual and potential severity rating selected was an A1 as there were no injuries, and the vehicle damage was less than 10k.
ImmediateAction: 1.Witness Statements were completed.  2.Operator was drug tested.3. Investigation was initiated.

ShortDescription: During air hammer drilling a fitting of the discharge hose failed and the 4" air line that was attached flew out
FullDescription: During air hammer drilling to install a king pile at the trestle bridge construction location to the west of the PWTS building, workers attempted to clear blockage of the borehole cuttings discharge line using compressed air.  During the activity, a fitting of the discharge hose connected to a 4" air line failed and the 4" air line that was attached flew out and away from the discharge hose.
ImmediateAction: All activity was stopped and the work location was placed into a safe state.

ShortDescription: Gunfire in the vicinity of employees
FullDescription: Whilst undertaking regular bat surveys for project 852297 at, and around, main site. Two employees were walking our transect B which runs along bum brook outside of main site to the south. We heard very loud gun shots from very close and most likely from the western end of our transect in one of the mitigation fields or woodland. We have had no previous shooting in this area, so this was unexpected. At least 20 shots over a 45 min period were heard close to point B (ST 19833 44588).Raised from HEART 202252896
ImmediateAction: Ceased transect and returned to cars. The PM alerted the PfM and the client. Another employee was undertaking work on main site and his car was parked at point A (ST 20019 44311). Contacted himand arranged to pick him up from pick up point just outside of main site to avoid him walking back to car close to area where shooting was heard. Action today (9/8) – meeting had with client this morning and contact details for farmer and landowners obtained, landowners be contacted before any more surveys take place to ensure no risk of shooting whilst survey taking place. Risk assessment to be adjusted by myself today to include these details and a section on shooting, with details of procedure etc.

ShortDescription: Preventable, rental vehicle, minor damage, no injury.
FullDescription: Wood technician was asked to park in a different area of the worksite the day prior by the Ledcor foreman to allow for a flatbed semi to enter the site and was shown the location to park.  On August 8, 2022 at 5:35 am, the Wood employee was backing in to park in the new location, and did not notice that the pile of wooden rig mats stored in the area was stacked unevenly.  While backing in, the front passenger door of the truck contacted the rig mat which was protruding from the pile, damaging the side of the vehicle. The worker immediately stopped the vehicle.  Conditions at the time were dark (dawn). The worker indicated that a spotter was not available at time of backing in to the location.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to Kevin Auclair (Ledcor Foreman), Mike Veeneman (Ledcor Safety), and Nalinda Dissanyake (Wood supervisor).  Worker was transported to Blue River CannAmm testing facility for a post-incident D&A test and completed test at 11:30 am. This test was delayed in order to reinstate account with CannAmm.   Preliminary D&A test result provided by Wood HR at 3:30 pm indicated that the initial results came back as negative.

ShortDescription: IP working on site for 11 hours, cooled off in truck as much as possible.IP felt very hot and developed a migraine, possible heatexhaustion.
FullDescription: IP was on site for 11 hours. IP started getting a migraine around 15:30-16:00. IP also started to get really hot around 17:30. IP tried to get into truck to cool off as much as possible during that time. IP drove back to the lab at 18:30 and cooled off in the truck for 30 minutes in the ac. Once IP got back to the lab IP drank a large water bottle about 1.5L. Migraine did not go away however. Once IP got home started to feel nauseous, IP fell asleep shortly after getting home, woke up around 2 am still with a migraine and threw up water twice.
ImmediateAction: IP drank a large water bottle once back to the lab after cooling off in the ac on the drive back.

ShortDescription: Driver turned from a stop sign onto road shared with HH trucks 160 t GVW. It was dusty, driver didn’t see the HH, needed to slam on brakes.
FullDescription: Wood driver was driving from the workplace to the Wood lab on site. Wood driver stopped at a T intersection, the S-bound direction had a stop sign, the E-W direction is free flowing.  Wood driver looked both ways and thought he was clear to make a left hand turn onto the road but a heavy haul truck had been obscured by dust and sunlight glare and it turned out it was very close.  Both the Wood driver and the heavy haul truck had to slam on the brakes to avoid a collision.(see map attached)
ImmediateAction: Reporting.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0074 Blais MTC; laceration right pinkie pinched btw two I-beams
FullDescription: Crew was rigging an I-beam into place using a crane and secured one end with bolts. As the crew determined the beam was placed backwards, they unbolted the beam to turn it around. Upon removal of the bolts, the beam swung upwards causing the IP’s finger to become pinched between two I-beams resulting in a laceration to right pinky finger. IP was wearing gloves at time of incident.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and supervisor contacted. IP was taken to onsite PA who assessed, cleaned and bandaged. IP was sent to Timmins for further assessment. IP received sutures. Canadian Model followed. IP returned to work. Incident Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: IP was experiencing high blood pressure and respiratory problems.
FullDescription: 21 July 2022:*IP departs for offshore after quarantine.5 August 2022:*2030 hrs IP visit offshore clinic - high blood pressure and respiratory problems – Offshore medical facilities stabilized his conditions and recommended for a medical evacuation onshore at La Paz Hospital.6 August 2022:*0200 hrs IP was transferred from offshore facilities (OKUME).*0233 hrs PM contacted ISOS and opened a medivac case.*0245 hrs PM visit local clinic (La Paz) to organize IP arrival.*0259 hrs Hexagon PM sent an internal communication.*0500 hrs IP arrived onshore.*0530 hrs  IP admitted in Local Clinic (La Paz) (Hexagon PM, Client’s HSE Mgr and medic were present to facilitate the process).*PM managed to get ISOS to contact La Paz’s medical team and Client’s Medic 7 August 2022 (IP in ICU):*1020 hrs PM and client medic visit the clinic to get an update on IP.   Client medic proceeded with a PCR test on the IP.*IP's family was notified and face to face conversation with PM and La Paz doctor took place.*1246 hrs PCR result negative (-).8 August 2022:*0349 hrs La Paz informed PM that the IP did not respond to treatment and passed away.Comments:* The IP has a medical history of high blood pressure,  the IP was sent to the clinic two weeks prior where medication was issued which was found to be effective and the IP was permitted to commence quarantine.
ImmediateAction: 6 August 2022:IP was transferred from offshore facilities (OKUME) 0200 hrs to onshore arriving 0500 hrs EG Time. Local Clinic La Paz was notified and was waiting for IP arrival. Ambulance transported IP from the port to the clinic. ISOS already notified and concurs with the current procedure.Approximately 10h00: ISOS is maintaining contact with the PM for updates (ISOS has requested to have a telephonic discussion with the IP, being arranged by PM).  IP is currently stable and will remain at La Paz for further diagnostics / treatment.8 August 2022:*Management informed of the passing of the IP.*PM informed the family to report to the clinic.*Hexagon HR Government Relations Representative to visit the clinic and attempt to contact the family in order to provide support.

ShortDescription: A wood company truck was damaged on the front left side and the left rear window was shattered
FullDescription: On August 5, 2022 at 3:35 pm an employee driving a wood company pickup truck was traveling down HWY 301 headed back to his camper.  There was a black Honda accord car driving in the right lane about 200 feet in front of him. The driver moved into the left lane and was approaching the vehicle at the posted speed limit of 55 mph.  While driving past the vehicle, the driver proceeded to turn left into the employee's vehicle, striking the right side of the truck, causing the truck to slide sideways and into a traffic sign. The employee was able to gain control of the vehicle and pull to the side of the road. He then exited the vehicle and went to check on the other driver before contacting the police department. His truck had sustained damage to the driver side rear door and window, along with the right rear quarter panel and right rear door.  When the police arrived at the scene, he observed the front left side of the Honda accord was damaged, and the bumper was on the ground due to making contact with the company truck earlier. The driver of the Honda accord admitted to the police officer that the accident was her fault. The police officer reviewed the car insurance of both drivers and told both drivers the police report would be available in 30 days. The actual severity rating selected was a A1 as no one was hurt, but vehicle damage expected to be less than 10k. The potential rating selected was an B2, as there was a potential for injury and more significant vehicle damage.
ImmediateAction: The Police Department was called.  A police report was completed.  Employee of company truck contacted his supervisor. Investigated initiated.

ShortDescription: SIR-Unauthorised transfer of material
FullDescription: Unauthorised transfer of a heavy duty cable drum inside a sea container from Angore to Lae.  The cable drum was not listed on the consignment note for removal from Angore.A person who claimed to be a Wood employee attempted to take possession of the drum from the TWL yard at Lae but did not have the correct paperwork and was not authorised by Wood for removal of the drum.
ImmediateAction: TWL security halted the transfer from the TWL Lae depot to a person claiming to be a Wood employee.  TWL employee reported the incident to EM Logistics team.

ShortDescription: Spectacle blind installed on wrong flange.
FullDescription: A wood employee was undertaking blind installation on vessel 11C4 under permit 092300 which specified the install of blind 609 and the unbolt of MW1. The supervisor allocated the work to a fitter who has had experience on the Ampol site, then left to set up other work fronts. The fitter undertook this work activity following P&ID 6024233 on his own.The supervisor returned to the area (11C4) at approx. 3.30pm to check on the fitter’s progress and was informed by the fitter that he removed the blank end cap B623 and unbolted B625, bagged both ends, as they were to be worked on as per the P&ID. They were also in vicinity of 609 and Manway1 which he had completed as per permit and P&ID 6029228. P&ID 6029228 references work pack 6024233 that lists the blinds and instructions to unbolt and install. The fitter thought he could just ask the area operator to add these blinds to the permit after the job was completed. B623 was a redundant nozzle (N4A) which was to be removed and repaired as per P&ID instructions and B625 was fitted to a drain. Both the nozzle and drain were under the same isolations for the vessel and covered by the boundary isolations Plan No 6029822.The supervisor went to find the allocated area operator but could not find him, however, at approx. 5.00pm the supervisor found another operator to come over to the vessel and explained the permit requirements to the fitter instructing him in future not to perform work that is not prescribed on the permit. The operator reluctantly added the two blinds to the permit but was not happy about the circumstances. The permit was signed off and returned to the BRM and an incident was raised by the operator INC0024000.Causal factors: •	The fitter removed the additional blank on B623 and unbolted B625 as they were listed in the P&ID as scheduled work and in the vicinity of the blinds already installed however was not listed on the Permit.Root Cause:•	Wood fitter failed to follow the permit to work instructions on permit 092300.Recommendations: •	Toolbox to be delivered to T&I personnel regarding the PTW process and to reinforce the understanding that work scope and activity is limited to what is prescribed on the Permit to Work.•	The fitter be subject to Wood Group’s Fair and Just Culture process.
ImmediateAction: Report & escalate

ShortDescription: Wood vehicle struck by forklift off loading a 20ft. Section of 3" pipe
FullDescription: On 8/2/2022 at ~ 09:30am, A Wood Maintenance employee who is nested within OC1001 Maintenance group as a MRO was tasked with using a mast type forklift to offload a 20' x 3" section of pipe from a Wood company truck. While attempting to position the forklift on the passenger side of the Wood company truck the forks of the forklift were not centered under the section of pipe. The Wood employee attempted to reposition the forklift forks using the Left-Right centering mechanism of the forklift mast without success. The Wood employee then attempted to reposition the forklift by backing away from the Wood company truck and re-centering the forklift on the load. As the forklift approached the Wood company truck their focus was on the frame holding the pipe and the forks, during which time the mast of the forklift struck the passengers side fender causing a dent in the fender. Wood Supervision, Wood Safety and ESS were notified.
ImmediateAction: The Wood EE stopped the job and then notified the Foreman, Wood HSSE, the DOW EHS and DOW ES&S

ShortDescription: A break in occurred in the Contractor laydown area some time during the evening of the 1st Aug 2022 and the morning of the 2nd Aug 2022
FullDescription: On the morning of the 2nd August 2022 the Babcock team reported to the Wood Construction Manager that a break-in had occurred at their laydown and office area. The exact time of the incident is not known and may have been anytime during the night of the 1st Aug 2022 up until the early morning hours of the 2nd Aug 2022. The Wood construction manager subsequently notified the Wood HSSE team. The details of the event are still under investigation by the South African Police Service in conjunction with the Client Security teams. The incident involved other Contractors on the project (Masedi E&I) and one Contractor working for the plant (Geecom) who also have their laydown areas in this section of the production unit where items were taken also
ImmediateAction: Incident reported to the Client security teamIncident reported to the South African Police Service for investigationIncident reported to Wood HSSE-ManagerIncident loaded onto CAIRS pending investigation outcome from the SAPSScene secured for investigation purposesInventory check to be done once the investigation of the scene is completed by the SAPS to establish the losses experienced

ShortDescription: Whilst removing a spool piece from an old pump the IP lost his balance and a check valve that fell in the process scraped his right shin
FullDescription: At 15h30 on the day of the incident, two Prommac employees including the IP were busy removing a pipe spool from the discharge line on an old pump unit as part of the deconstruction scope on the Green Hydrogen Project in Sasolburg at the Chlorine Plant. The IP was standing on the elevated pump base next to the pump unit which was about 100mm above the floor level, which was a slightly sloped surface and very narrow. While the IP ( Boilermaker Semi-Skilled) was standing on the pump base concrete plinth to assist in the removal of the 6-inch spool piece & non-return valve, the IP lost his balance and in the process, the non-return valve & 6-inch spool piece dislodged from the discharge flange of the pump and fell over. The check valve came off the spool piece and struck the IP on his right shin causing an abrasion to his shin area. The IP was transported to the Client's medical facility and treatment was given. The doctor only classified the incident the following day as a first aid case.
ImmediateAction: - Work activities were stopped - Emergency preparedness and response were initiated.- The IP was transported to the midland medical station.- Immediate stand down was held with the employees.- Stand down was conducted the following morning with the entire Prommac team with Wood and Client personnel present.- Preliminary Investigation started the same day and was continued the following morning. Formal investigation to follow

ImmediateAction: His mechanical supervisor informed HSE Lead and site superintendent. His mechanical supervisor and his project Ampol supervisor are task to investigate "no report for the crew person of any personal injury or pain during work hours between 2nd and 3rd August inclusive". Also to investigate if any further controls are to be actioned for the workplace and the task described in the crew person statement and text received the morning of the 4th August.

ShortDescription: Tech was on site for a concrete test, concrete truck operator tripped on ladder and splashed tech with concrete. No injuries.
FullDescription: Technician (IP) was on site at 90 Alexander for a concrete test when he was involved in an incident around 1:00 pm. The Granite pump operator was priming the pump near the back of the Building Products concrete truck and the IP was standing near the front of the Building Products concrete truck. As the operator was priming the pump, the operator tripped on a ladder and splashed the IP with concrete. The IP suddenly felt concrete hit them and saw concrete spraying on the Granite pump truck, the Building Products concrete truck, on the pump and concrete truck operators and the ground surrounding the area. The IP got concrete all over their clothes, arms, neck, hair, and face. IP was wearing all necessary PPE (Hard Hat, Safety Glasses, Steel Toed Boots, Long Pants, Vest). After the incident the IP cleaned himself off with water as best as he could. IP sustained no injuries. IP finished concrete testing at site. IP drove back to office and reported incident to Supervisors (Randell Johnson and Steven Saindon) and called Work Care at 3:30 pm.
ImmediateAction: Washed concrete off skin with water.

ImmediateAction: Wood EE drove to a safe location to stop and notify his account manager/supervisor.

IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: Employee was Traveling East on Route 333, 18 minutes from Seabright headed to Halifax.  Wood employee was driving home from non-work related event during foggy/ rainy poor visibility conditions.  At approximately 3:15 am traveling around 60 Kilometres/ hour employee missed a turn, hit the guard rail & drove into the ditch ahead. The approximate depth of ditch was 10ft and there was no rolling involved. There were also no injuries & no third party involved. This incident took place on Route 333 just before civic address 7082 Prospect Road. Employee did a walk about of the vehicle & determined there was no obvious visible damage such as airbags or broken glass.
ImmediateAction: Employee returned to the site a few hours later in daylight & had the vehicle towed.

ShortDescription: 48” vessel slid off forklift forks dropping about 4” to the ground while being moved causing damage to the vessel.
FullDescription: The task was to unload a customer owned vessel (48” diameter/13,432 pounds) laying horizontal off a hot shot truck with a forklift. The vessel was picked up and lowered down to about 4" off the ground. The operator then proceeded forward to the location to set the vessel. During transportation, the vessel slid off the left fork onto the ground bending a nozzle and scratching the paint. They did have skids on both sides of the vessel to prevent movement. The crew stopped and secured the vessel and then reset it properly onto skids. The operator is certified, and a spotter was in place. No personal was in the line of fire. There was a steady drizzle of rain during this operation. This incident is rated an A1 for actual and potential due to being under 10K damage and no personal anywhere near the dropped object.
ImmediateAction: Crew stopped, assessed the situation, and stabilized the vessel. The vessel was then picked up, moved to destination on skids.
