ShortDescription: The team at PWA22 installed the conductor clamps and pull-lift, but as they started to take the weight the team witnessed the clamps slip
FullDescription: After installing the issued HARU (stamped with SWL 3.6 ton) and KLIEN (Made in USA and stamped CBS 1.4 ton) Conductor Clamps onto the Horse Conductor which was to be replaced.  The team started to take the weight and noticed the Clamps slipping and not gripping onto the conductor as expected.  The team released the load and informed their Wiring Foreman, who in turn informed the Site Manager.  Work was halted and a brief investigation was carried out with regard to the slipping issue and the suitability of the clamps. It was discovered that there were three different types of Horse clamp on the project. The three different types were: HARU Grip Range 13.46, KLEIN-CBS Range 13.46 – 18.80mm, KLEIN-Chicago Stamped Horse all of which fell within the tolerance requirements for HORSE Earthwire.
ImmediateAction: Work was halted to establish the cause immediately. The diameter of the HORSE Earthwire was identified at 13.95 mm, the lower range of the clamps were 13:46mm which gave them a within tolerance of 0:49mm.  The site believed that the old conductor installed circa 1962 had stretched or corroded at points and therefore fallen outside the Clamp Tolerances.  Replacement KLIEN - Chicago (Stamped HORSE) Clamps were ordered, the initial supplied CLAMPS were quarantined for return to Power Solutions UK Stores. No personnel were injured as a result of this incident, neither was there any damage to the Infrastructure.

ShortDescription: One Wood subcontractor was reported discomfort on the left eye, probably caused by foreign body.
FullDescription: One Wood subcontractor during the activity of installing screws for fixing cable trays was supporting the task in the execution providing equipment, looking for materials, etc. After a wind current at the site, the employee felt discomfort in his left eye. The IP stopped the job and immediately alerted the event to his work partner, who instantly stopped the activity and activated the safety supervision for due support and necessary actions. The IP lesions were evaluated by a offshore doctor and no foreign body identified, but a micro lesion  was observed in the conjunctiva region and as a precautionary measure the employee received a tampon and was instructed to rest for the rest of the day. The IP was reassessed once again at the day after and no foreign body was found and the IP was released to go back to work normally. The current classification is B1 due a no further intervention was needed but the consequence could be a Medical Treatment or RWC being B2 as a potential.
ImmediateAction: Activity was stopped, the IP was assisted by client offshore doctor and was released to back to work on the day after.Time out for safety was carried by HSE team and the case was shared to all employee.

ShortDescription: Two weed eaters transported on the back of a zero turn mower was damaged.
FullDescription: On Thursday, July 28, 2022, at approximately 3:00 pm, an operator of a zero-turn mower was asked to transport two weed eaters to the front of the array for a  co-worker.   It was raining outside, so the operator hurriedly  picked the weed eaters up off the ground and began driving to the front of the array. As he proceeded on his path,  he  drove along the left side of  a wood company truck, took a  sharp left  turn around a  trailer connected to the company truck, causing the weed eaters hanging on the back of the zero-turn mower to become damaged. The actual severity is an A1 because no injury occurred and now one was in the truck when the weed eaters were damaged. The potential severity is a A1 because the damage to the weed eaters is less than 10k.
ImmediateAction: 1.Investigation initiated2.The operator reported the incident to the general foreman3.The operator was drug tested4.Witness Statement were collected.

ShortDescription: Kaefer personnel reported feeling unwell whilst erecting scaffold to condensate leak
FullDescription: At approximately 16:00 the Kaefer scaffolding team reported feeling unwell whilst erecting a scaffold to provide access to a condensate leak which was reported earlier in the week. 2 employees went to Furness General hospital to get checked over as they reported feeling light headed and nauseous.
ImmediateAction: The scaffolding job was stopped and issue was reported to the PTW coordinator and HSEABenzene and gas detection was carried out at the worksite around 20 mins after the first report, the benzene test provided no reading and the multi gas detector read CH4 volume % 0.6 and 12% LEL, this reading was able to detect directly against the leak due to the detector having an extendable probe. Both employees attended hospital to get checked over. Their bloods were taken and they were monitored for approx. 3 hours before being released and returned to work the next morning (29/07). Both employees were advised to return if they suffered any further adverse health effects.

ShortDescription: During connection of ram cylinder of boom unexpected weight caugt IP off guard, pinched middle finder along frame of excavator.
FullDescription: The IP and the crew had reviewed the IWC work page which included the lift plan for the work scope but did not contain a written and formal procedure for changing the environmental bucket to the digging bucket. The crew signed off on the paperwork and entered radiological zone 3 to gain access to the McNally work barge. Once there, the workers positioned the work barge along the shoreline and secured it with the spuds once they were lined up and tied off to the anchors. The excavator was then moved into position with the boom and stick facing east towards the shore. This is where the exisiting extension stick and clam bucket was to be placed and the parallel extension was located that was installed onto the excavator. The crew began to disconnect the environmental bucket and set it down to the side of the work area. The excavator  lined up with the parallel stick extension on the shoreline. The next step involved a second excavator on the zone 1 side that was used to hoist the parallel extension so the excavator could place the main stick inside the extension unit. The parallel stick extension was lifted approx 3-4 feet in the air with appropriate rigging and the barge excavator was able to insert the stick inside the parallel extension and was then pinned in place by the workers on the ground. The parallel stick extension has one support bracket located on the operator side and was supported by a piece of wood and the main boom stick. The ground workers, both working together, decided to manually manouver the support bracket to the correct orientation, which is a procedural step not required at this time. As the workers were performing this task, they manually manouvered the support bracket as it pivoted in the air back towards the excavator. The first worker had their hands on the support bracket, lifted it up and rotated it back towards the excavator, away from the hydraulic hoses. The other worker was able to support the weight and was handed the control arm where it was brought under control using both hands ad guided to the desired location, to be placed against a collar which was sticking out from the parallel extension. While performing this movement, the IP had placed their left hand in a position which has been identified as "in the line of fire". The IP finished their task and reported to their supervisor where they were taken via boat to the boat dock to receive first aid treatment. After receiving first aid treatment on site, the IP was taken to Northumberland Hills Hospital by their supervisor for medical evaluation. The worker received 3 stitches to the top of their middle finger and two stitches to the bottom of their middle finger.
ImmediateAction: The work was placed in a safe state and the worker was removed from the work environment.

ShortDescription: IP was handling survey tapes and reports experiencing a burning sensation on the right forearm the previous day, developed skin reaction.
FullDescription: At the end of the field day yesterday IP was collecting tools and equipment for the day (around 3pm) and was walking back to the trucks (where we head out from the work site). During his walk he felt a burning sensation on his forearm and didn't think much of it. His forearm had been pressed against a particular piece of equipment (survey tapes) that IP believed were likely in contact with Wild Parsnip when the site was gridded on Monday/Tuesday. The walk back to the trucks on the previously establish path also passed through a few parsnip plants. Exposure either to a noxious oil covered tool or direct contact with the plant itself is unclear. However, in the evening of the 27th, IP experienced a linear bubbling burn on right mid-forearm (palm side) and noticed it while showering at home. He thus at that point thoroughly cleaned the burn with soap and water. IP made the incident known to an FS the following morning (July 28th). IP called work care which instructed him to keep the burn clean with  soap and water, to avoid aggravating it, and to call again if symptoms worsen. The new FS for the 28th (Dan Ionico) then conducted a thorough hazard assessment to mitigate potential parsnip exposure by deliniating a new path to site that avoids parsnips plants and all high growing weeds generally. The FS also high-vis flagged around parsnip plants located within the work/study area to make the crew aware of hazards.
ImmediateAction: IP went under a tent for shade and water.

ShortDescription: Employee assigned to QA duties at Fuels repair project reported respiratory irritation after working near sandblast operations
FullDescription: Employee assigned to QA duties at Fuels repair project reported respiratory irritation after working near sandblast operation.  Employee was working outside of a fuel tank containment system that was being sandblasted for future coating operations.  Employee reported that they were exposed to fugitive dust emissions that resulted in irritation to the respiratory tract.  The tank was enclosed and had a ventilation system in place.  Employee did not enter the enclosure during sandblasting operations.
ImmediateAction: Employee reported observation to the on-site Safety Officer who stopped operations.  Initial status call was scheduled with the contractor and SSO.  Modifications to the containment system were made to reduce the potential for fugitive emissions from the enclosure and all staff were coached to avoid exposure and use respiratory protection or dust masks when working near the enclosure.

ShortDescription: Employee had missed flight to Nigeria and was unable to be contacted.
FullDescription: A Wood employee was due to travel internationally to a high-risk country.  The travellers journey management plan indicated a departure date of 27 July with an overnight layover in a connecting city, then continuation on to the high-risk country.  Due to the travel risks in the destination country, the Regional Security Manager had arranged security support via contractor which included airport collection in the high-risk country.  On 28 July, the contractor notified the Wood security team that the employee missed their connecting flight.  The Regional Security Manager repeatedly tried to contact the traveller for new flight details without success.  The security company, Regional Security Manager and the traveller’s Line Manager were unable to contact the traveller despite numerous attempts on their work and personal phone. Towards the end of the working day on 29 July, a message was received confirming that the traveller was ok and had to deal with a personal matter.Because the employee was unaccounted for, for approximately 10 hours with no alternative flight arrangements made, an emergency response team was set up and next of Kin were contacted. Next of Kin details were not current which caused further confusion and communication delays.
ImmediateAction: * Meeting held with the local EMT and Security  to begin ER * Calls, emails and texts to the employee to check if he was ok* Flight carrier contacted to make sure employee had not travelled* NoK was contacted to find out  where employee was and if ok.

ShortDescription: Poor professional driving behaviour
FullDescription: Approx. 7:40am within the car park area of the WG warehouse two utes were parked up in the driveway – not the parking spaces where at least three car park spaces were open to use. •	Both vehicles were facing in the forward travel direction. •	Ampol Facilities supervisor was entering the warehouse area on the pedestrian path and witnessed the poor behaviour.•	Travis Anderson identified them as WOOD E&I utes but unable to identify individuals. It is captured on site area camera.•	As one ute rounded the carpark spaces safely and in the correct direction, the second ute cut through the car spaces as if to try to cut in front of the first vehicle. That same driver braked hard.It can only be assumed that it was “sky-larking” as it was impossible not to know the first ute was rounding the driveway to leave the area. Driving on site is listed as one of WOOD's Life Saving Rules
ImmediateAction: the HSE Lead spoke with one E&I Supervisor, the second had left the site. The event was emailed to AMPOL and WOOD management. An action has been raised within the AMPOL system for both supervisors to coach their team on driving behaviour and the parking rules at Wynnum Gardens warehouse car park. they have been asked to investigate who was driving the second ute at the time.

ShortDescription: Mechanical contractor, no contractual relationship to Wood, fell into sinkhole at worksite.
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: AT THIS POINT, THIS INCIDENT IS BEING ENTERED INTO CAIRS FOR LEARNING PURPOSES.  INCIDENT IS STILL BEING INVESTIGATED TO DETERMINE IF WOOD’S HAS ANY ROLE / RESPONSIBILITY AS WORK WAS NOT IN RELATION TO THE WOOD SCOPE OF WORK.  BC Mechanical was contracted directly by Honeywell to install a fire protection line.  This installation of the fire protection line was not within Wood’s scope of work.  However, the line was installed within the boundaries of the Wood project site.  In addition, the Wood subcontractor, Brandenburg, was used to dig the trench.  Wood was not otherwise involved.  This was an additional work being conducted at an active facility. Trench was dug, pipes laid down but work was not completed by the end of the day so trench was left open.  A heavy rain event occurred over the weekend causing some washout of the backfill on the site.  On the following Monday, a BC Mechanical employee walked on the backfilled area to  inspect the trench and to assess it prior to continuing the installation of the fire protection line.  While walking, the ground gave way and the individual fell into a hole, approximately 5’ (or less) below grade while standing and ~10’ back from the leading edge of the excavation that was sloped back.  The site was the basement of a former building that our subcontractor (Brandenburg) demolished and backfilled.  Soil had been compacted and compaction tested by a 3rd party so was within compaction specifications.  There was no signs that this hole existed prior to it giving way and the individual falling in.  There is still no visual signs of washout in that specific area, although there was signs of washout in other areas of the site.  The BC Mechanical employee self rescued by using a strap attached to an excavator.  BC Mechanical employee reported only minor injuries.
ImmediateAction: Brandenburg assisted the EE out of the sinkhole using equipment for the employee to grab on to and self-rescue. EE went to the clinic for evaluation. The site was secured and no further entry allowed until an engineering inspection was completed. Brandenburg conducted a test pit in the area from a safe location to assess the subgrade and water conditions. The investigation will be used to determine work relationship along with EE employer’s and client investigation
OtherIncidentAssignedTo: BC Mechanical, contracted directly by client

ShortDescription: A Wood light duty vehicle mistakenly entered the haul road and tailgated a haul truck. No injuries occurred.
FullDescription: Two material testing technicians were in a hurry to get to an 8 am pour. As they were loading the equipment, they received a call that the concrete truck has already arrived. They headed straight to the intersection near the Wood lab and drove onto the haul road by accident. It was not until seeing the "beta-down" entrance on the other side of the concrete barriers that they realized they took the wrong turn. They then had to drive all the way to the earth dam and do a U-turn. On the way back, they were following a haul truck; their radio was not on the right channel so they were unaware the haul truck driver was trying to get ahold of them. They followed too closely behind until they reached the exit that takes them back to the right road. The incident was reported to AFDE safety by the haul truck driver.
ImmediateAction: Driving privileges revoked

ShortDescription: 3 Wood Engineers were involved in RTA collision with the train. No significant injuries.
FullDescription: On 24th July 2022 at approx. 1430hrs, 3 Wood Engineers (Wood BGC Project) were traveling back from their regular work in WQ1 DS08 to their homes via Al Majal supplied minibus. The journey includes crossing the train line nearby NR: DS04. At that time the train was moving forward close to the crossing point of the Al Majal vehicle, and while crossing the rail, the Al-Majal driver discovered that the vehicle was in a hazardous position on the rail and was unable to react in time to avoid the collision.The train crashed into the vehicle, and the consequence was damage to the right side of the vehicle. Wood Engineers immediately reported the incident to the Wood fleet coordinator and HSE department, Al Majal Driver has reported the incident to Al Majal logistics and Fleet Manager. The team immediately informed IOM and IOM and deployed the investigation team to the site.The investigation team reached the event location to gather evidence while the Wood fleet team channeled another vehicle to transport the passengers to the hospital for verifying and confirming their health condition.
ImmediateAction: Wood Engineers immediately reported the incident to the Wood fleet coordinator and HSE department, Al Majal Driver has reported the incident to Al Majal logistics and Fleet Manager. The team immediately informed IOM and IOM and deployed the investigation team to the site.The investigation team reached the event location to gather evidence while the Wood fleet team channeled another vehicle to transport the passengers to the hospital for verifying and confirming their health condition.

ShortDescription: Right arm was caught between the 600lb load and a handrail when the load shifted unexpectedly causing minor swelling.
FullDescription: A 600 lb. air compressor was lowered from the main deck to the cellar deck. The load was on a wooden pallet and vertical when lifted. Tag lines were used to guide it onto the landing area on the cellar deck. Once landed on the edge of the wooden frame, one rigger pushed with another pulling on the pallet from each a side to lay it down from vertical to horizontal. While pulling, a board of the wooden pallet broke free and the load unexpectedly pivoted with the load catching the right arm of one rigger between it and the handrail. Actual severity is B1 due to First Aid measures used. Potential severity is B2 because a more serious injury such as medical treatment could have occurred.
ImmediateAction: Load was landed all the way onto the decking. Notifications were made of the event. Eventually the IP used first aid measures to treat his right arm for minor swelling.

ShortDescription: IP exposed to unknown mist / vapour / while entering the engine room.
FullDescription: A mechanical technician was requested to go and manually turn off the forward fire pump. The forward fire pump had auto-started in the morning following a trip of the vessel, during a CER / TER upgrades work scope. When the mechanical technician was in the engine room shutting down the engine, he became aware of an unknown smell and started to cough. He shutdown the engine and exited the module. The individual was witnessed coughing by the MSTL outside the port doorways, who investigated further. When opening the door, it was identified there was a presence of an unknown yellow mist or haze. Exclusion barriers were erected and all available doorways opened to allow for ventilation. ToR issued and joint Investigation commenced between client and Wood. Potential classification categorisation will be revisited pending the outcome of the investigation.
ImmediateAction: Individual visited the medic, no treatment given and the IP returned to work. Incident reported accordingly, initial witness statements taken, investigation ToR issued and KO meeting completed 26/0722.

ShortDescription: Worker felt pain in right wrist after connecting heavy lead to temporary works outlet
FullDescription: Worker was task with running leads from a genset to a distribution board. the leads are approx. 240mm singles with single plug ends. He reported to First Aid escorted with the T&I HSE Advisor and the Ampol HSE Lead representative on the T&I. The workers received first and (wrist strapped) and he returned to work. He reported to work this morning at 6am and has reported his wrist feels fine. He has maintained the strapping on his wrist as a precaution.
ImmediateAction: Worker was escorted to the Ampol site first aid room where he received first aid treatment. the incident was reported to Tim Smith and Judith Barr by Nathan Toovey. The incident was reported to the Client.

ShortDescription: A skid steer hydraulic hose broke causing less than gallons of hydraulic fluid to leak onto the ground
FullDescription: At approximately 12:45 on 07/21/2022, The civil crew was task to off load a spoil pile at the entrance of block 2 Toshes Rd, In the process of the operator backing up and raising  the skid steer rigid frame. A hydraulic hose broke causing less than 1 gallons of hydraulic fluid to leak onto the ground. The leak was immediately noticed, and the machine was stopped. Environmental (SWPPP) was notified and clean up procedures began. The actual severity and potential ratings were selected as an A1 due to minimal reversible environmental impact.
ImmediateAction: The equipment was shut down. Environmental was notified. Clean up procedures immediately took place. All contaminated soil and diapers were picked up and disposed of into proper containments.

Project: US East - Oil & Gas - All Other Clients
ShortDescription: Housing of LED Light damaged by rigging during Crane Operations.
FullDescription: LED Light near living Quarters was damaged during crane operations. After Landing an 8'x12' cargo box, the banksman directed the crane operator to swing/lower the sling to the back side of the box so it could be disconnected from the crane hook safely. The light housing was cracked when the one legs of the 4-part sling flipped, struck, and snagged on the light housing.  Actual (A1): Minor damage of <10K occurred when one leg of the 4-part sling struck and snagged on light housing. Potential (A1): Minor damage <10K;  If Banksman would not have noticed the sling leg snagged then the Light may have been ripped from the mounting bracket causing more damage to the mounting bracket as well as the housing.
ImmediateAction: Banksman called "all stop", untangled the  the sling leg from the light. EHS Specialist was notified of the incident. The light was observed to be working, but the housing was cracked. The incident was reported up to the HESS Offshore Installation Manager (OIM) who notified BSEE as per regulatory requirements for Offshore Crane Incidents. Client (HESS) and Wood conducting Investigation.

ShortDescription: Overhead communication wire was struck by excavator bucket operated by owner's contractor, the line fell, lightly striking IP on upper back.
FullDescription: Wood Involved Person (IP) was standing in the pipe trench (< 3ft deep). He was facing the compaction efforts ~10m ahead in the trench and talking to supervisor on the phone. The excavator was working on another area of the site, ~10m away from IP but still within view. The excavation contractor (hired by NSDPW) had a spotter with the excavator during the trench digging all morning. It was identified at the start of day that the excavator would be working in proximity to the overhead communications line. The contractor did not have a spotter as the excavator operator attempted to smooth out the stockpile of excavated soil. The boom of the excavator struck and severed the communication line and it fell striking the IP lightly in the back (no injury). No risk of an energized conductor involved in this event. Dropped object risk was estimated to be low/green, based on 4m height and low weight TV cable section of 1m, 0.1kg.
ImmediateAction: IP was on the phone with supervisor at the time of incident so immediately reported to supervisor. IP was not hurt (no injury). Work stopped and contractor notified client (NS Dept. Public Works) and met on-site with a property owner representative (Facilities Manager with NS Dept. Natural Resources). Contractor and Facilities Manager assessed the scene, confirmed it was a communication line and determined it was safe to resume work. Communication line was relocated to a safe place with repairs underway. Wood will not return to site until we see an incident report/ corrective actions from the contractor.

ShortDescription: Worker going down trailer steps rolled left ankle due to the tread portion of a stair giving way underfoot.
FullDescription: The IP reported for work at 2200 hrs Tuesday 19 July, as they work the night shift, which extends through to 0800 the next day.  At approx. 0520, the IP exited the Security Trailer as they needed to open up Gates #1 and #2 in preparation for the days activity. They went down the trailer stairs, which are supplied with the trailer unit by the trailer supplier.  The stairs are of metal construction, with the steps being metal framed with a grated tread welded to the frame from underneath.  There were no braces under the tread portion of the steps.  The stairs had recently been checked by Wood and Lakeland Multitrade in response to other stair related incidents on the Project and were found to be in serviceable condition.  The IP stepped down with their left foot onto the stair that was the second up from the bottom. They stepped down such that the heel of the foot was in the centre of the stair tread; the foot was turned to the left and slightly inclined to the left (i.e the foot was not placed flat onto the stair tread).  The IP was holding onto the handrail.  When the IP stepped down onto the stair, the tread became separated from the front steel framing (tack welds failed) in the centre area where the foot was placed.  The grated tread depressed approx. 1". Due to the tread depressing unexpectedly and how the IP had stepped down onto the stair, the IP was put off balance resulting in the ankle rolling to the left.  As they were using the handrail at the time the IP did not fall. The IP was wearing 6" CSA Grade 1 construction boots.  They were laced up, however the top eyelets were not used.The IP continued to complete their task and returned to the trailer.  As they were sitting in the trailer they elevated the foot and used over the counter pain medication.  The Wood H&S Manager was notified of the event at 0620 when arriving at the Project Site for the day, and investigation was undertaken, including interviewing the IP and taking photos.  The IP indicated that there was little pain except for when putting weight on the ankle when stepping.  The damaged stair was painted with high vis orange paint.  When the Ast Superintendent arrived shortly after, a discussion of what could be done with the stairs was held.  The Commissionaires worker coming in to start their shift at 0700 was notified of the hazard and to step off to the side of the weak tread location when accessing the trailer. During this time the IP was supplied with a rapid cold pack to apply to the ankle. Shortly after tailgate was completed, the stairs were replaced with a spare set that were available.  The replacement stairs were of a different design, having braces under the grated tread providing better support.The IP, after application of the cold pack, indicated that the ankle was much better.  The ankle was inspected and there was some minor swelling noted on the left side.  The IP indicated that they would wrap it with a tensor bandage when they got home and rest it.  They had no plan on seeking medical evaluation and were instructed to inform Wood if that were to happen. As of 21 July, the IP completed their next sheduled shift (2200 20 July to 0800 21 July) and reports the ankle is much improved.  The worker has no restrictions and there has been no lost time.
ImmediateAction: Worker reported incident to Wood.  The stairs were replaced.

ShortDescription: Employee's vehicle was stolen while parked in the garage at the Thoroughbred Building.
FullDescription: Employee reported that personal vehicle was stolen from the parking garage. The truck 2016 Chevrolet Silverado 1500 LTZ was parked at the Tbred Bldg. front parking lot, about three spots east of the Visitor Parking spots along the bushes that parallel Park Row. The truck was backed into the parking space near a Danner’s Security Camera Setup approximately 100 yards east.  Employee parked the vehicle at 8:20 am 7-20-2022 and later in the day when employee was ready to leave the office at 7:00 pm 7-20-2022, employee found that the vehicle was stolen. The time the vehicle was stolen is unknown. This same vehicle was stolen from Clydesdale Parking Lot on 12/15/2021 but vehicle was found and recovered 20 miles east of the campus on the day it was stolen. A police report (Incident No. 096428222Q) was filed.
ImmediateAction: Employee was not able to report the incident to anyone on site because it was late and after business hours.  Employee informed the project management and department management on 07/21/2022. A police report (Incident No. 1678116-21T) was filed. Facilities and HSSE teams were notified and they held a meeting with involved employee to collect incident details and discuss immediate corrective/preventive actions to address more security around the campus.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: NWR.  IP (Filipino expat) was experiencing pain in their right calf muscle from early morning.
FullDescription: 19 July 2022•	The IP experienced muscle cramp in their right calf when they woke up in the morning.•	The Trident Energy Dr conducted an evaluation who referred them to La Paz Hospital:o	Diagnosis:  Muscular cramp. No sign of haematoma/thrombosis.o	Recommendations:  To continue with blood pressure and cholesterol treatment.  Reduce by half cholesterol medication.  3 days’ rest.o	Medication prescribed:  Yurelax (muscle relaxant) and Hidroxil (Vitamin B1, B6 & B12).•	Trident Energy Dr evaluated the La Paz medical report and recommended that the IP be taken to INSESO Hospital for further diagnostics (Doppler Ultrasound + Coagulation Test).•	INSESO medical report:o	Doppler Ultrasound Result:  Atheroma Plaque in the artery walls with no signs of “TVP” on this examination.o	Medical Diagnostic:  Leg pain probably as secondary effect of Atheroma Plaques without evidence of thrombosis.o	Recommended Treatment and recommendations:  To return to previous Hospital to continue with treatment with primary doctor.•	Trident Energy Dr provided a report recommending that the IP return to La Paz Hospital for a Cardiologist Examination.•	Cardiologists medical report:o	Medical Diagnostic: Blood Pressure under control. No cardiovascular problem detected at this time.o	Recommendations: Perform an Echocardiography.20 July 2022:•	Cardiologists Echocardiography report:o	Light hypertrophy.  No contractility disorders at rest.  Good biventricular systolic function.  No HTP elements.
ImmediateAction: The IP is currently in his regular accommodation at Bome and will return to work on Friday, 22 July as per medical report issued by La Paz Hospital.

ShortDescription: Preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury.

Was removed by client contact.  Damage was not immediately evident to front bumper which was pushed in approximately 2" by the fall into the ditch until the tire began rubbing on the front right, which was not noticed until 7/21. Front bumber of fleet vehicle is bent approximately 2" inward which is rubbing on front right tire during left turns.
ImmediateAction: Visually inspected vehilcle after removed from ditch.  No issues on 7/19 - 7/20.  Truck began rubbing wheel well on 7/20.  Called Donlen on 7/21 at apprx. 4:30pm.  From my converstion with them, Donlen who did not deem the issue a major malfunction at the time they advised truck could be taken to firestone for repair sometime the next week which I planned to do with scheduled oil change on 7/26 when I was back in the office.

ShortDescription: Plant Operator punctured a refrigerant line while attempting to drill a drainage penetration in an air conditioning unit

Comparable units cost approximately $1,600 new.  Subcontractor employee was wearing PPE and was not injured.
ImmediateAction: Power to the unit was disconnected and further modifications to the unit were suspended

ShortDescription: IP's skin contacted xylene while performing the task of circulating xylene trough Coalescing Filter Separator.
FullDescription: IP was tasked with circulating xylene through the BGC B Suction Coalescing Filter Separator Liquid Sump. System was not circulating. While trouble shooting system to move fluid, IP slowly opened the ball valve to vent and prime the system releasing a small amount of xylene that subsequently made contact with IP's left forearm. IP immediately experienced slight skin irritation and readiness. Actual: (B1) Slight skin irritation and redness was flushed with water for 10 minutes as a first Aid measure. Potential: (B2) A larger amount of xylene could have been released if the valve would have been fully opened resulting in the potential for greater severity of injury requiring medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: IP removed contaminated shirt and administered First Aid to self. IP flushed his skin with water that relived the redness and irritation. IP reported to supervisor as per protocol and was evaluated by the on-site Medic. No further treatment was administered and the IP returned to work.  HESS HSE is conducting 5 why/investigation and monitoring IP's injury site.

ShortDescription: Wood Employee felt pain in lower back
FullDescription: At approx 12.30pm Wood employee Rope Access Level 1-Pipefitter was in the process of climbing back up from the work site onto the platform deck  , weather was clear with good conditions for climbing.IP had been working all morning on the rope access job underneath the deck, and returned up the ropes onto the platform desk. IP had no issues with his back until he was taking off his safety harness when he felt a twinge /pain in his lower back, he went for lunch and then went down to see the Wood Field Team Lead FTL before he went back to work at approx.13.25pm .Wood FTL advised him to go see the medic which he did around 13.35pm. The platform Medic gave the IP a check-up and treatment with medication (ibuprofen /paracetamol) to relive the pain. Platform Medic then stood the IP down for the remainder of the shift.
ImmediateAction: Wood IP went for treatment on the 15th July 2022 at approx 13.35pm with the medic and was given pain killer medication (Ibuprofen /Paracetamol) issued by the medic and told to stand down for the rest of the day.IP has been advised to return back to check with the medic tomorrow the 16th July 2022 to check how the IP is feeling.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Lower back strain during transport of nuclear guage from testing location back to IP's vehicle
FullDescription: IP was at a project site (Laurelwood MUP) to check Granular A compaction. After checking compaction, The IP was going back to their vehicle, the surface they were walking on was uneven. The Granular A was not properly compacted in several spots. As the IP was walking with the nuclear gauge in one hand and hammer, pin, plate, and safety cone in other, right foot got tilted. The IP felt normal at that point but over the weekend noticed couldn't move properly. Tried applying an ice pack on Saturday. On Sunday it got worse and couldn't bend and straighten up normally. After trying some stretching and anti-inflammatory medication, observed no improvement. WorkCare was called on Monday.
ImmediateAction: Worker reported the occurrence on July 17, 2022 and WorkCare was contacted.

ShortDescription: Foreign body in eye
FullDescription: the IP was supervising a cutting of a gusset plate on the north bunkering station. ShortDescription: SIR - Crew required to shelter in refuge due to potential local unrest
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: PLEASE NOTE - Incident is non-stewardable by WoodSeven personnel who had been working at Well Pad G (comprising 1 x Wood employee, 5 x subcontractors and an ExxonMobil contracted bus driver) were returning to HGCP at the end of their shift along the spineline.   After travelling approximately 1km past WPE they noticed a group of local men with weapons barricading the road with chopped down trees.  One of the team instructed the bus driver to turn the bus around and they headed back up the spineline to WPF and locked themselves into the safe haven after securing the gates as per the emergency response procedure.  The team contacted JOC via the landline phone and reported the issue and were instructed by JOC to stay in the facility and await further instructions.After a short period of time, JOC contacted the crew and advised that Security, Police and Defense Force personnel were on their way to facilitate their return to HGCP. The Defense Force liaised with the local incumbents who then left the area.  The road was cleared of obstructions allowing Security personnel to reach the crew at WPF and they were escorted safely to HGCP, arriving at approximately 19:30.    The Wood Construction Co-ordinator made sure the crew were provided with meals upon their return and offered his support to the team including the use of the EAP.There were no injuries and no property damage.
ImmediateAction: The driver turned the bus around and the crew entered the Safe Haven at WPF and reported the issue to JOC.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Injury to left foot during hot washing activity
FullDescription: IP was working inside the Coalescer B, performing hot washing (around 2,600 psi) to remove residual waste contents of the vessel. The IP's foot was stuck in the contents of the vessel (a form of dense tar like deposit) and so the IP began to utilise the hot washer to spray around their boot to free their foot. The IP began to feel like warm water on their foot, and then realized that they had penetrated the boot and that they had injured their left foot. The IP then went to the medic for treatment. The decision was made to arrange a medevac for the IP to get a further checks. The IP was medevac'd the following day (14th July) and arrived on the beach around 11:30 and a taxi took them straight to ISOS.Current understanding (as of 15th July 13:00) is that ISOS doctor checked him over and has no concerns. the IP is to monitor the foot and if any swelling or redness appears (which it has not done so up to this point) then they should return but otherwise they don't need to return. The IP is back in work (NRC offices) and feeling fine.03/08 - Classification has been updated to RWC from FAC following receipt of ISOS report.
ImmediateAction: IP visited the medic on the platform and a medevac was arranged for the following day.

ShortDescription: Repetitive motion causing left arm/wrist pain.
FullDescription: IP started feeling a painful shooting sensation from the knuckle of  left ring finger up to  elbow around 1:45pm. IP feels this pain when putting pressure to left hand/wrist, when rotates arm and when bends arm too (but bending is less painful). IP mentioned had a little bit of 'wrist tiredness' throughout the day until the above reported time. IP immediately let site supervisor know.
ImmediateAction: IP was provided with immediate work accommodations to pain comfort level (avoiding all physically demanding tasks) and called WorkCare. WorkCare told IP to put a cold compress on wrist and forearm and to watch it for changes such as inflammation or increase in pain changes. IP was instructed  to take over the counter pain medication (ibuprofen), antihistamine if it swells, and to avoid heat in the areas of concern. IP has scheduled follow up call with WorkCare.

ShortDescription: Trapped pressure in blocked impulse line
FullDescription: Whilst attempting to gain correct readings on the HTFS Pressure control Valve it became clear that the pressures indicated were not correct. Instrument technician along with plant operator (both wood employees) attempted to "blow down" the instrument to get correct readings. Upon finding one side of DP blocked (tube and manifold) the isolation valve was closed and the tube fitting slackened to try and bleed off pressure. The slackened fitting gave off a little liquid bleed and the techs then assumed that the isolation point was holding. Tube loosened off further and then released from manifold releasing steam and Teg mix (Triethylene glycol 40%) into atmosphere at approx 150. degree celsius. There was no physical injuries reported as a result of this incident.
ImmediateAction: Technicians asked for HTFS to be taken off line and attempted to release pressure upstream. Further operations assistance arrived and they managed stop the steam release by shutting additional isolation valves. Both technicians involved in the incident were temporarily withdrawn from their duties. (temporary close supervision installed to monitor employees wellbeing)Client led investigation has commenced with Wood involvement.The incident has been reported to the enforcing authorities (HSE & EA) by Shell as the asset operator.

ShortDescription: One Wood employee was twisted/sprain his left knee while picking up  the torqueing machine.
FullDescription: During the night shift one of Wood employee was twisted/sprain his left knee while picking up  the torqueing machine (30kg aprox) which was being  carrying with cargo car. To pass through the warehouse area door he picked up manually the machine and  started feel pain.Immediately, they stop the activity and call the supervisor and client HSE. The IP was go to the offshore hospital by walking and was assessed by doctor who decided to disembark to be better assessed at the onshore hospital.The IP was disembarked in the morning later by MEDVAC and was assisted by our nurse at the hospital where are recommended immobilization and pain killer.   The B1 actual and B2 potential was chose  due the IP still  being under the investigation if previously lesion could contribute or not to the actual injury.After corporate doctor evaluation the case classification was change for B3 as LTI and potential too.
ImmediateAction: Stopped the job, follow the IP to offshore hospital where was assessed to doctor who decided to disembark the IP.Time out for safety was  conducted to offshore supervisor  about the recommended weight to carry and reinforced the stop work authority.

ShortDescription: A Wood truck and RTV were damaged when the driver was pushed off the roadway by a semi-tractor/trailer.
FullDescription: On Sunday, July 10, 2022, at approximately 8:30 am, the EE was commuting to the job site in Deming, New Mexico.  The EE was driving unit 151 and pulling a utility trailer loaded with a Honda RTV.  The EE was driving south on interstate 25 about three miles outside of Raton, New Mexico.  As the EE was driving, a semi-tractor with trailer drove up next to him and merged toward the Wood truck.  The EE turned toward the shoulder to avoid a collision with the semi-tractor.  When he did this, the Wood truck contacted two reflector posts and was pulled off the side of the road.  As the EE turned the truck back onto the roadway, the RTV which was strapped down on the trailer fell off the trailer and onto the roadway.  Truck received minor damage to the grill guard, driver's door and rear fender.  The RTV received damage to the windshield and body.  There were no injuries.  Actual severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck and RTV appears to be less than $10,000.  The Potential severity is A2 because the damage caused to the truck could be more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: A sheriff's deputy responded to the incident scene.  The EE called his supervisor and the HSSES Advisor was contacted.  The Wood EE was sent to a nearby facility to receive a post-accident drug and alcohol test.

ShortDescription: Worker tripped, fell to ground injury right ring finger and hand
FullDescription: The worker was walking away from structure 9B, down the slope to get back to their truck.  The worker tripped on a survey stake that  was laying on an angle to the ground.  The worker fell forward and reached out to break their fall, by  extending their hands out in front.   The worker subsequently landed quite hard on their right hand and hyper extended their fingers back towards their wrist.
ImmediateAction: After the worker got up from the ground, massaging the affected hand, the sub-contractor's foreman arrived on site (a couple minutes later).  Worker spoke to athe sub-contractor's construction foreman, advising them of what happened.  Worker drove  to the on-site first aid, located approximately 1/2 KM away.    The worker's right hand was assessed, ice applied and hand was bandaged. The first aid attendant advised the worker to travel to Smtihers to get an x-ray of the hand.  When worker was at first aid, the prime contractor PM was passing by in their vehicle and was flagged down.  The worker advised the PM of the incident and  that the worker would drive to the hospital in Smithers for an x-ray.  (approx. 1  hour away).   Worker travelled out of the field, stopped at the client site trailer, approximately 20 kms away.  The worker  advised the client construction officer  of what happend.  He told the worker he had already been advised about the incident.  Worker continued on and drove to the Smither's Hospital.  Worker waited approximately 4 1/2 hours at the hospital before seeing a Doctor.  The hand was x-rayed and no fracture was identified.  The Doctor suspected a hairline fracture of the right ring finger.  As a precaution, the right ring finger was splinted/taped and worker advised to keep the splint on for 3-4 weeks, no heavy lifting during that time.  The worker was advised they could go back to work.    Immediate Corrective action: The prime contractor PM went back to Structure 9B, took a picture of the stake and removed it from the ground.   This incident is currently under investigation and more information will  follow.July 11 UPDATE: Worker was contacted by the Doctor previously seen in the ER.  X-ray was reviewed by a radiologist and no fracture was identified.  The finger was immobilized as a precautionary measure and the worker was advised the splint should be kept for at least 1 - 1/2 week.  No paperwork was given to the worker by the attending Doctor at the Hospital.   Worker will reach out to the Doctor to see if a soft immobilization measure can now be used.  Recordability may change.

ShortDescription: Working Under BA and having broken into a 2" Flange  there was a sudden release of Hot water/Product residue causing minor burn
FullDescription: When working under BA conditions to refit a new Butterfly valve 027RBV0003A. Fitters working under BA had broken into a 2" 8 bolt Flange of a Fuel gas line which had been purged and cleaned with water following isolation. Under Operator standby they had loosened the bolts of the Flange and identified that there was a slight release of water and steam which was observed to dissipate fully. Under BA they re-approached and opened up the flange which showed a clear air gap. They tapped the pipework with a spanner to re-assure no product was present. No further release occurred so they began to remove all bolts, at which point there was a sudden release of hot water which contaminated both fitters but one more than the other. As a result he received a burning sensation to his right forearm which was treated onsite by a site first aider. He attended the local A&E department as a precaution where his arm was cleaned and he later returned to work.
ImmediateAction: Injured party treated for Minor Scald, Incident investigation commenced with Information being collated,

ShortDescription: Damage to security fence by unauthorised operation of telehandler
FullDescription: Incident details:Angore Crane and Rigging crew were unloading and moving equipment inside the fence line at WPB. Crew were using the telehandler for the tasking and telehandler was parked up in between tasks with the keys left in the ignition.One of the local walk-in spotters decided under his own judgment and without being asked by the supervisor, to operate the telehandler, spotter drove around the back end of WPB. Whilst driving near the security fence line, the telehandlers forks contacted the fence panel and fence post.The impact noise was heard by the supervisor and other crew members, and they walked over to see the telehandler being driven back to its previous parked location,
ImmediateAction: Post Incident:•             Nobody injured•             Nil people in the line of fire•             Nil damage to the Telehandler•             On investigation the supervisor noticed the damage to the fence and phoned his manager to report incident. Damage to fence panel will be wired closed for overnight security and the repairs will be scheduled into work tasks over the next few days.

ShortDescription: Release of no more than 1 gallon of gasoline onto the ground
FullDescription: At approximately 11:45 on July 07, 2022, mechanical helper was driving a UTV with three passengers. Individual proceeded to back up into work area for crew to use port-o-let. At the area there were (4) 5 -gallon metal gasoline cans inside a containment pan (kiddie pool). The UTV driver nor the passengers were aware of location/proximity and ran over the cans inside the kiddie pool. As a result, no more than 1 gal. of gasoline was released inside the kiddie pool, which also sustained damage, spilling content into the ground. The spill was immediately noticed, and cans were transferred by crew to an adjacent kiddie pool. Environmental (SWPPP) was notified and clean up procedures began. The actual severity is A1 since spilled quantity was no more than a gallon. Potential rating was selected as an A2 due to probability of all (4) 5-Gal. Gasoline cans being full having 20gals. spilled onto the ground and just fairly below the reportable quantity for spills for VA (anything exceeding 25gallons).
ImmediateAction: The UTV was parked and shut down. Environmental was notified. Clean up procedures immediately took place. All contaminated soil and diapers were picked up and disposed of into proper containments. Incident investigation was initiated. UA screening post-accident for UTV driver took place and pictures and statements gathered.

ShortDescription: Employee was working at the Bechtel office and took a fall while walking in the parking garage.
FullDescription: A Wood employee working for Energy Transfer at the Bechtel Office in Houston, TX stepped off a ledge in the parking garage and fell to the ground. Both Bechtel and Wood are contracted to Energy Transfer. The incident is classified as a medical treatment due to the prescription of medication. The potential classification could have been higher due to the potential for a break.
ImmediateAction: - Employee immediately contacted Wood, Energy Transfer and Bechtel personnel.- The injured person was sent to the nearest Concentra Medical Center for medical assistance as per Bechtel policy. - HSSE&S Team met with Employee at Concentra Medical Center to assist with medical review and met with both Bechtel and Energy Transfer to determine follow up actions. The employee was allowed to return to work with restrictions as of July 7, 2022. Restrictions include:Maximum hours sitting: 8Sitting: Sedentary dutyThe employee is able to complete their job in line with the above restrictions.

ShortDescription: Substandard rigging practice identified during the offloading of the eating facility for Babcock
FullDescription: On the day of the incident, a supplier for Babcock (Speedspace) was scheduled to deliver an extension for the eating facility in the Site Establishment area. The supplier arrived on site and proceeded to the Babcock HSSE Office. The Babcock HSE Officer was busy scanning documents for their head office so he only reviewed the certificates for the slings and the truck-mounted crane unit and the operator competency that was provided by Speedspace. The HSSE Officer from Babcock then requested the Rigging Supervisor for Pro-Rig to assist the Speedspace provider with the offloading of the unit as the Babcock-appointed Rigging Supervisor was in a training session and not available for the day.The Speedspace team then started to set up the lifting and placement of the unit when the rigging supervisor from Pro-Rig a Babcock Subcontractor appointed to perform the rigging scope of work on the burner replacement project noticed that the slings that the Speedspace team had already hooked up to the crane hook of the truck-mounted crane had some cuts in them. The rigging supervisor for Pro-Rig stopped the activity and then proceeded to replace the damaged sling with an undamaged one and after visually inspecting all of the other slings the Speedspace team had brought with them assisted the provider with offloading of the unit in the Babcock site establishment. The Speedspace lifting equipment was used to then offload the unit and not Pro-Rig equipment as reported in the initial report of the incident in CAIRS.A decision was made to use a Pro-Rig PTRA and only have the Speedspace team sign onto the Pro-Rig PTRA that was used the previous week for offloading containers in the same area with a mobile crane. The Pro-Rig supervisor then assisted the Speedspace team to offload and place the unit safely.After the unit had been placed the Wood HSSE Officer who had been at the work area arrived at the Babcock HSSE Officer's office and told him that the unit cannot be used due to it not having the correct steps and also showed him a photograph of the damaged sling that had been shown to him by the Pro-Rig Supervisor.Sometime after the unit was safely placed an audit was performed by the Wood Construction Manager Mr. Wickus Bester, as he had been in meetings during the lift, as a follow-up and due to the fact that Wood had not been informed of the lift prior to starting of the work. A Near Miss was raised after Mr. Bester found that several deviations from the agreed process and procedure had occurred
ImmediateAction: The Incident investigation started and will continue on the 07th July 2022 to be conducted by BabcockAll lifting and rigging activities for Babcock have been stopped until the investigation is completedPro-Rig and Babcock senior management to be informed by Wood PM that they will be required to investigate the matter with Wood in support

ShortDescription: NWR - Adverse reaction to medication
FullDescription: Approximately five weeks ago, the individual was working for the Enbridge project in Tennessee when they noted a lump on the back of the neck where the hard hat met skin. The lump grew and resulted in irritation.The individual sought out medical care and was prescribed antibiotics.The lump continued to grow/reported puss to be coming out of it.During this time, the individual moved from the project in Tennessee to the Motiva project in Port Arthur.After seeing the doctor again, the individual was prescribed new medication. The individual started to feel sick and was not deemed safe to be attending the site/staying at the hotel unattended. (This is believed to be a reaction to the medication.)
ImmediateAction: The individual stopped taking the medication when they noticed the side effects. The individual's partner was called to come take the individual to the doctor.The diagnosis was a staph infection. The individual will not return to work until they have completed the medication.

ShortDescription: Subcontractor Vehicle damaged G.S.6 barriers on access route to OHL route
FullDescription: A experienced subcontractor driver was moving a load of Earthwire conductor Drums along the OHL access route (Wood CDM area) during high winds to the EPZ location with his HGV, which was fitted with a HIAB..  To speed up the unloading process, the driver positioned his HIAB on top of the Drums, at which point the vehicles combined height was 4:3m.  On approaching the G.S. 6 barriers set up for the 11kv overhead line., the driver noticed their was significant deflection due to the high Winds, thereby reducing the actual height of the barriers  The driver however proceeded to drive through two sets of barriers, both set at 5m.  After completing the maneuver, the driver looked in his mirrors and realised he had broken the height restrictor on both sets.   He contacted the Wood foreman immediately, after parking his vehicle in a position of safety.
ImmediateAction: Informed client of incident and ensured there was no impact on the functionality of the asset.The Road was closed to traffic and repair teams contacted to replace G.S.6 Barriers.The incident was reported via the Power Solutions escalation procedure.The incident was reported to the client within the 30 minute reporting timeframe. The subcontractor driver was informed of the requirement to undergo the Drug and Alcohol protocols.

ShortDescription: Employee was rear ended as he was pulling out of a intersection
FullDescription: Employee was on his daily commute home form the job site, PLU 27. As he proceeded to leave the stop sign at the intersection 128 and highway 115, he attempted to make a left hand turn to head east on Highway 115. Employee was rear ended by a Nissan Titan also making a left hand turn onto highway 115. Wood truck was struck on the driver side bumper and tail gate. Employee felt he didn't need any medical attention, but as he waited for the Sheriffs department to arrive felt some minor stiffness. A police crash report was taken and will be available in 10 days. No citation was issued to employee.  Actual/Potential is a B1/B2.
ImmediateAction: Andrews County Sheriff's department was notified and report taken. Also notified site management. No further treatment needed

ShortDescription: IP rolled right ankle when walking engaged in a conversation with coworker
FullDescription: On Wednesday, July 6th, 2022, IP and coworker were tasked to install MC4 connectors in Block 3 PCS 27 climax. In the process of walking to the next task IP and coworker were engaged in a conversation not paying attention to his footing or walking surface rolling right ankle. Employee’s right foot leaned outward causing discomfort. Incident was reported to the supervisor. Wood HSSE was notified, and IP was taken to Wood HSSE trailer to be evaluated by onsite medic. After assessing condition, RICE protocol was implemented to care for IP right ankle mild soft tissue sprain. Actual rating is B1 since onsite medic started FA treatment for mild soft tissue sprain. The potential severity is an B2 since medical treatment could be a possibility if protocol for mild soft tissue injurie is not followed during first assessment.
ImmediateAction: The Crew stopped work. IP notified Foreman and GF about the ankle discomfort. IP was taken to wood HSSE trailer to be evaluated by onsite medic. Accident investigation was initiated by gathering statements, collecting JSA and capturing a picture of conditions of the ground.

ShortDescription: Fuel transportation in Afton Catchment Area

ImmediateAction: To rectify the situation, the bowser was unhitched and removed by a 4x4 pick up truck.

ShortDescription: IP felt a sharp pain in his lower back as he reached for a 36 inch pipe wrench.
FullDescription: IP was tasked with removing a plunger from an auto catcher and while standing on the well access stand the a 36inch pipe wrench began to slip and fall. The IP attempted to quickly grab the wrench and felt a sharp pain in his lower back. IP was evaluated at an occupational clinic and diagnosed with a low back strain and released to work with restrictions. Actual: B2- Injury resulted in restricted duties. Potential: B-3 Potential lost time had the injury required days away from work.
ImmediateAction: IP stopped work and notified the client and Wood Management for incident reporting. Axiom Medical initiated and phone consultation resulted in further evaluation needed.

ShortDescription: One (1) Team member received positive test result for COVD-19.
FullDescription: Supervisor and the HSSE Team received a note from employee indicating that received positive test for COVID-19. Employee indicated that a Covid-19 Test was taken on Monday 07/04/2022 and received positive result. The last day employee worked at the office was Thursday 06/23/2022. Employee disclosed to be fully vaccinated and antibody infused treatment. Employee will be working from home and follow quarantine protocols. Employee reported no close contact with other Wood employees.
ImmediateAction: Employee contacted supervisor to report the positive test result and stayed home. Employee continue working from home and following quarantine protocol. HSSE Team handled the case reporting in CAIRS per Wood requirement. Employee will provide updates and will follow the necessary steps on Covid-19 protocols prior to returning to the office.

ShortDescription: Worker from fencing subcontractor walking on gabion stone tripped up and fell down, resulting in right pinky finger dislocation.
FullDescription: The IP was installing permanent perimeter fencing in the East Gorge Area of the PGWMF portion of the project site. The section of fence being worked on at the time was being installed across a gabion-covered area (erosion control) in the bottom of the gorge. The IP at the time of the event was installing the top rail of the fence framing. As the IP was traversing from one section of fencing to the next while feeding the top rail through the post mounts, they were moving sideways.  During this movement, the IP was not watching their foot placement and their right foot was placed on a loose gabion stone. The shifting stone caused the IP to topple over onto their right side. They put their right arm/hand out to break the fall.  Coworkers went to his aid to see if the IP was okay. The IP initially thought that they were alright, however upon getting up, they realized that their right pinky finger was dislocated.
ImmediateAction: First aid was provided to the worker; worker was taken to hospital by their supervisor for assessment.

ShortDescription: IP cut finger whilst opening Reed Bed access gate
IncidentAssignedTo: Visitor (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: Whilst accessing the reed beds to conduct a bat survey, the IP cut their finger when opening the gate to reed beds at around 21:00 on 4 July 2022. The IP returned to site on the evening of 11 July 2022 to conduct a further survey, the IP asked for help to open the gate as it was difficult to open and mentioned the cut finger from the previous survey. The IP only noticed the cut finger when they left site because they were wearing gloves. They cleaned the finger themselves and put a plaster on it at the time.
ImmediateAction: Accident record completed to record the accident with input from the IP.Access gate was inspected, latch no longer shut and gate will be held closed with locked chain only - improvements to the gate will be carried out to resolve issues (CAIRS action to be raised).
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Preventable, rental vehicle, meduim damage, no injury.
FullDescription: Driving down I-10 West after completing a day on-site. Rain started to fall and driver slowed down to be careful of hazardous conditions caused by the weather. As the driver continued to drive smoothly and slowly down the straight road the car started to spin and slide. The driver tried to reduce speed even more by pumping the brakes to try to get traction and by holding the steering wheel steady. These corrective actions were taken to avoid anymore spinning out and possible hydroplanning of the car due to the weather. The car still went out into the grassy median where the driver side was met with a tree.
ImmediateAction: Called 911, police showed up on scene about 30 mins later, claims no info taken by police after confirming he was ok and tow truck called. Police did show up more than once due to calls made to 911 by passersby.Called Enterprise after calling 911. They arranged tow truck, Bronco Towing who took vehicle to Caliber Collision in Mesa, AZ.

ShortDescription: Diesel Fuel (less than a pint) spilled onto the ground and cleaned up appropriately
FullDescription: At approximately 1045am June 30, 2022, During the safety leadership walk the discovery of less than a pint of diesel was found on the ground next to a secondary containment. It appears that the leak happened this morning when the subcontractor was fueling equipment. Environmental (SWPPP) was notified and clean up procedures began. The actual and potential severity ratings were selected as an A1 due to minimal reversible environmental impact.
ImmediateAction: Environmental crew was notified. Clean up procedures immediately took place. All contaminated soil was picked up and disposed into proper containments.

ShortDescription: Operator of a Zero-Turn Mower bumped the controls while in close proximity to another employee causing the machine to make contact with the
FullDescription: On Thursday June 30, 2022 at approximately 10:15AM, an operator of a Zero-Turn Mower bumped the controls while in close proximity to another employee causing the front tire of the machine to make contact with the employee's safety-toed boot.  There were no visible damage or markings on the boot.  Additionally, there was no visible swelling of the employee's foot and the employee was able to bear weight and walk normally.  The mower was fully idled down and the deck was not engaged.  The two individuals were purposefully in close proximity to each other, exchanging a set of jumper cables.  The controls were not disengaged per the task plan.  The actual severity is an A1 because no injury occurred.  The potential severity is a B2 because 1 employee could have needed medical treatment had the machine moved further or faster than actual.
ImmediateAction: Equipment was parked and operator was drug tested per policy.  Employee was evaluated for injury and investigation was started.  JSA was closed and new one was created following a stand down with the crew discussing human machine interface.  Entire crew was shown what disengaged controls looked like when approaching equipment and all operators were reminded of the requirement to fully disengage controls when there is a need for someone to approach the equipment.

ShortDescription: Preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury
FullDescription: No Injuries. Minor, cosmetic damage to vehicle. The bumper was not completely seperated from vehicle, truck is still operational and the bumper is still attached - just seperated from the rest of the front end maybe 2 inches. Ground conditions on-site are not ideal. The valence on this particular truck sits approximately 8 inches off the ground, the site holds water and there are existing, raised rows for crop cultivation and ruts caused by large trucks/drill rigs which hold water. Mud caked the tires causing the truck to become stuck within either the raised rows or within a rut created by a truck utilized by the subcontractor to install groundwater wells. While being pulled out, the valence caught either the raised crop row or rut and stressed the bumper clips to a breaking point.
ImmediateAction: Late reporting by Wood employee

IP informed the nearest supervisor and retrieved an antiseptic wipe from the site First Aid Kit. The wound did draw blood but the bleeding stopped within a few minutes.
ImmediateAction: IP informed the supervisor and used an antispectic wipe from the site First Aid Kit.

ShortDescription: IE experienced heat cramps and was transported to medical facilities.
FullDescription: On above date worker was tasked to drive the telehandler from one location to the next location.  The IE left the old location at around 1300 hours and was expected to take 1 hour to get to the new location.  The IE stated that the front window and side window were open during the trip.  The IE also stated that the vents kept pushing out hot air even after the IE attempted to turn fan off.  The IE stated that they took off their gloves and placed them in the front vents and placed their FR shirt over the back vents.  The IE stated that about halfway to the new location they stopped and exited the telehandler because they were getting hot.  After 10-15 the IE then proceeded to the new location.  Once on the new location the IE stated that they went to the pickup and took a small sip of water and immediately vomited.  The crew lead told the IE to sit in the vehicle and cool off and try to drink some water.  The IE while sitting in the vehicle attempted to drink some more water again vomited.  IE’s body started to shake along with heavy breathing also at this time.  The crew lead began 1st aid measures trying to cool the IE with wet rags in IE’s hot zone areas.  The crew lead stated after a few minutes of 1st aid measure the IE condition started to worsen.The crew lead stated that the IE’s entire body began to cramp uncontrollably.  The crew lead phoned wood supervision and safety and stated that the IE was incoherent, and body was cramped up (“like someone having a seizure”) including cramped and distorted face.  Crew lead was immediately told to hang up and phone 911 and get an ambulance to their location.IE was transported to the nearest hospital and treated for heat cramps and was released to full duty.Actual B2 as was treated by medical staff and given IV solution.  Potential B2 as could have been restricted work case as well.
ImmediateAction: Investigation was started following the care of the IE

ShortDescription: Al Majal driver was travelling from WQ1 to Basrah heading towards the engineers' house.  when the Accident Occurred.
FullDescription: Al Majal driver was traveling from WQ1 to Basrah heading towards the engineers' house. The driver was conducting the vehicle at a speed limit of 80 km/hr. As he was approaching a speed bump, the driver slowed the vehicle to 40km/hr which was the time when the vehicle was struck from the back by another third-party (Starex / Mini Bus Hyundai). The third-party vehicle collided with Al Majal vehicles from the left-back side. The driver took the vehicle under control immediately and parked at the side of the road. The Accident was reported to traffic police and after their investigation, it was established that incident was caused by the third-party Starex / Mini Bus Hyundai.
ImmediateAction: Fleet coordinator AMLS & Wood JMC had been informed about the Accident. A replacement vehicle and driver were sent to transport the engineers from the accident area to his home. No injuries were reported at that time.

FullDescription: At Approximately 8:15am a Wood EE was tasked to dump a roll off box on to the landfill of B5100. ShortDescription: Electric vehicle impacted by a closing roller door
FullDescription: A driver of an electric vehicle has impacted a closing roller door to access the ETP Tunnels.  The driver is unharmed and had been wearing a seatbelt.  The roller door had been open when the driver went to drive the electric vehicle through the opening however the door started to close automatically unbeknown to the driver.  The top front of the electric vehicle contacted the bottom of the door resulting in damage to the vehicles flashing light and the roller door being bent.  The roller door is inoperable.
ImmediateAction: SR has been submitted for tag-out and repair.  A SR has been submitted for the electric vehicle to tagged out pending mechanical inspection.  D&A Test completed (negative result)

ShortDescription: A Wood surveyor sprained his ankle while walking on a steep slope next to a creek bank requiring first aid treatment.
FullDescription: On Thursday, June 23, 2022 at about 9:45 am, the Wood IP was tasked with doing a topographic survey of a steep creek bank that was in the P13 zone at the Itafos Dry Valley project site.  While performing this task, his right ankle rolled, resulting in a sprain. The actual severity is a B1 because the injury required first aid treatment.  The Potential Severity is a B2 because the injury could require medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: The Project Manager was notified.  The IP went immediately to the onsite EMT where he received first aid treatment for a sprained ankle.  IP called WorkCare.

ShortDescription: Forklift Operator drove forklift forward & made light contact with warehouse upright pole.
FullDescription: Operators describes: Forklift was parked under awning in front of Tools warehouse. Operator Proceeded reported he drove forward, looked left, began to veer left and noticed the pole in front of forklift. He hit brake and the forklift slid and made light contact with the warehouse support structure. Small mark on the pole. No damage to forklift. No injury.
ImmediateAction: Forklift operator did not report the event until after midday. He was then escorted to the main Gatehouse for a D&A test conducted by a third party organised by Ampol.

ShortDescription: Employee's vehicle was break in while parked in the garage at the Stallion Building.
FullDescription: Employee's vehicle was parked at the Stallion garage and found that someone break in. Employee reported that the vehicle was locked, so they must have used a slim jim or something to get in. The contents of the center console were spread across the backseat, a glove box was gone through, and the contents that were stolen include a knife (approximately 6" blade) and a multitool.  No personal injuries or other damages to the vehicle reported.
ImmediateAction: Employee reported the incident to Facilities and HSSE Teams and provided details of the vehicle break-in. Incident was reviewed by the teams and re-evaluated to add more security patrols to cover the parking garages.

ShortDescription: Employee's truck was break in while parked in the garage at the Stallion Building.
FullDescription: Employee's truck was parked at the stairwell on the 2nd floor on the NE corner of the garage and found that someone break in. Employee reported that nothing was stolen.  Employee had nothing of value in the vehicle (just umbrella, sunglasses, etc.), so they didn’t bother with that.  All they did was flip up the back seat of the truck and put a bunch of cigarette ashes in the cup holder in the center console.  They also moved a bunch of stuff around, looking for anything of value. No personal injuries or other damages to the vehicle ported.
ImmediateAction: Employee reported the incident to Facilities and HSSE Teams and provided details of the truck break-in. Incident reviewed by the teams and re-evaluated to add more security patrols to cover the parking garages.

ShortDescription: Wood multi-craft crew was removing a sight glass when it came in contact with a 3/4 inch conduit causing it to break at the joint.
FullDescription: Wood multi-craft crew was removing a 2 inch sight glass from D-133 at Unit 28.1, when the sight glass made contact with a 3/4 inch conduit causing It to break at the joint. Incident was reported to operations immediately. There were no injuries reported. Investigation pending. Potential - Damage was minor loss <$10K and no injuries.
ImmediateAction: Incident reported to operation and client safety. Wood protocol followed. Investigation pending.
