ShortDescription: P backed up causing hard hat to wedge at the top culvert opening-hard hat moved and forehead exposed and struck concrete edge
FullDescription: When transfering from one side of the culvert to the other, the IP was standing in the flare end, and needed to move out of the way. In order to do this, the IP backed up, causing their head/hard hat to wedge against the top of the opening of the culvert. When the IP proceeded forward, the hardhat shifted back on their head, causing the top of the IP's head to be exposed. As the IP moved forward, the top of their head, approximately 1 inch above their forehead, was cut by a hanging piece of conrete reinfocement.
ImmediateAction: Visit to site nurse, first aid applied.

ShortDescription: Non preventable, rental vehicle, minor damage, no injury.
FullDescription: While travelling from the Vista Heights Wood office location en route to Lac La Bich exited from HWY 1 onto the merging lane toward Hwy 2 Northbound. Yielded to oncoming traffice from the South when struck from behind by another driver.
ImmediateAction: Pulled over at a safe location to assess damage and potential injury, reach out to the first points of contact for health and safety incidents and exchange information with other driver

ShortDescription: Skid Steer left rubber track made contacted causing vehicle damaged on front plastic bumper
FullDescription: On Wednesday June 22nd, 2022, at approximately 1715 skid steer operator was traveling to the front of block 1C to park his equipment. When operator was traveling to the front of the block, he seen his supervisor in the truck. Operator thought supervisor wanted to talk to him, so he pulls around to the driver side of the vehicle. When the operator was traveling to the front left side of the vehicle the rubber track contact left plastic bumper. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor, the replacement of the bumper is (less than 10k), and there were no other team members in the vicinity.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the vehicle damaged were gathered. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: Citizen property damage claim towards street sweeper operator while cleaning county road
FullDescription: On Wednesday, June 22nd, 2022, around 15:30, Wood SWPPP GF receives a phone call from Street Sweeper Operator notifying that a citizen driving their personal vehicle claimed to have sustained damage while sweeper operator was making a left turn on county road, by Substation entrance, to let traffic behind pass. Vehicle behind sweeper claimed their front side contacted sweeper’s left back tire frame. HSSE was notified and both (sweeper and citizen had already made their way to main office location). Police was called and State Police Trooper responded to the jobsite to gather information. Sweeper has low moving equipment triangle on the back, amber flashing light at top of cab and two flashing red lights on bumper which are operational. Turn signal was in use and operational. Area where claimed accident occurred is a single lane, no passing zone. An SP50 Pad was filled out by Trooper since damages claimed by citizen are considered non reportable damage for DMV.  The Actual and Potential severity are an A1 since Sweeper had a previous dent when it was brought to site by rental company and claimed damages by citizen have been estimated to be non-reportable and Trooper issued a ticket to citizen for following too close on an identified slow-moving equipment. No violations found or tickets were issued to Street Sweeper Operator.
ImmediateAction: Wood HSSE and Operation Team assess the incident and start the investigation process. A UA screening was conducted on Sweep Operator following protocol of post-accident. Sweeper daily inspection was gathered and presented to Trooper with rental company proof of insurance. Investigation is in process.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee’s tire blew out on his commute home causing minor damage to the vehicle
FullDescription: On Wednesday, June 22, 2022, at approximately 1650, The Wood employee was on his commute home from work on interstate 90 east. 20 miles outside of Gillette WY and the front passenger tire blew out. The EE pulled over to the side of the road to inspect what happened and noticed damage to the wheel well and wire housing units. A spare tire was put on and the truck was able to make it to Gillette with no other complications. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Pulled over to the side of the road and called HSE

ShortDescription: Hyd oil spill 0.015l of biodegradable hyd oil from crimper unit  (PP 241)
FullDescription: Spill of approximately 0.015l of biodegradable hydraulic oil from a  crimper unit on drilling equipment (PP 241) attached to Spider Excavator (PP 247). The hydraulic oil was leaking out of the crimper and onto the ground when it was noticed by the driller
ImmediateAction: The equipment was immediately shut down by the driller when he noticed the spill. Driller notified the spider operator and site supervisor.The riggers placed absorbent pads under the leak to contain further spill onto the ground surface and peat moss absorbent sawdust was spread over the contaminated ground surface to absorb the hydraulic oil. Spill absorbent pads and duct tape were used to cap off the source of the leak and mechanic was requested.The mechanic on site isolated the source of the leak and the spider excavator was moved uphill to a safer location. From there the mechanic will trouble shoot the mechanical issue and have it resolved.The soaked peat moss sawdust on the ground was scraped with shovels and bagged and the contaminated soil was also removed and bagged. Further clean up of equipment body with absorbent pads was done appropriately and waste placed into contaminated waste bags.The bagged contaminated sawdust, soil, and absorbent pads were transported back to Moro X and stored in the DG bunded container.

ShortDescription: Fugitive Dust Outside Property Line
FullDescription: On Wednesday, Jun 22nd, 2022, at 10:30am, project received the visit of a county inspector regarding a complaint brought by a citizen of the community due to fugitive dust. The citizen had contacted a Senator which contacted the county inspector. When county inspector arrived at the location, to address the complaint, it was observed that the fugitive dust had been dissipated passed project property line, which is a deviation from project dust control plan. The county inspector issued a verbal stop work until conditions comply with approved dust control plan. The Actual severity is an A1 since the verbal stop has a minimal reversible environmental impact with no impact on business operations or reputation. The Potential severity is an A2 due to possibility of becoming a minor pollution with no lasting impact on business reputation.
ImmediateAction: Wood stopped United Grading dirt moving operations for the day. Immediate action of Wood having a second water truck to assist United but United replacing their current water truck (not street legal to drive - depends on rain events to fill up with water from basins) with (2) 4,000 gals. water truck that are street legal and can drive to other blocks ponds to fill them with water. A permanent solution that will begin on the week of June 27th, 2022, is seeding/strawing by United to keep the dust down.

ShortDescription: Heated conversation at parking lot ending on physical altercation
FullDescription: On Wednesday, June 22nd, 2022, at 6:45am two individuals from Logistics team started a heated conversation at the parking lot before clocking time. The verbal altercation escalated to a physical one, when one of the individuals placed their hand opened on others person face to push party away. Once this event occurred, one individual informed supervisor about the incident. After subsequent conversation with P&O, one of the individuals claimed sustaining a busted lip. The actual severity of the incident is A1 since neither individual received any treatment. The potential severity is B2 as the physical altercation could have resulted in treatment beyond first aid.
ImmediateAction: Project CM contacted P&O project's rep. Statements from both individuals involved in the altercation were gathered among statements of witness. P&O interviewed all affected parties and witnesses. Fair and Just culture intervention was applied, and individuals were terminated due to failure to comply with company policy/procedure. SDAF forms were filled out and copy kept on everyone’s employee files.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Passenger van drove over lead line for blast.
FullDescription: While preparing for a blast in the South Pit/Chert Borrow the operators were in the process of relocating their equipment to be out of the blast zone.  The employees had moved the screen and excavator and started to move the dozer when they were told the dozer would be fine where it was located.   They were instructed to drive the van out of the area and to park near the standpipe on the southeast side of the pit.  As they were exiting the area driving along the east side of the blast pattern the van drove over the lead line placed by Arizona Drilling and Blasting (AZD&B), who were in charge of the blast.  They ran over the lead line about one hundred fifty feet (150) south of the blast pattern.  The AZD&B blaster immediately notified everyone on the radio and inspected the lead line for damage.  The line was not damaged, and the shot continued as planned.AZD&B  failed to clear the area prior to running the lead line across the south exit as per procedure. They did not communicate with the personnel involved in the blast where or when they were running the line out.  If by some chance the shot had been initiated, the three personnel in the van could have been injured from fly rock or blast concussion.
ImmediateAction: The AZD&B blaster immediately notified everyone on the radio and stopped the process until they inspected the lead line for damage. SBI Safety informed to stand down until an Inspection of the area was completed and it was confirmed with the blaster that is was safe to proceed. The line was not damaged, and the shot continued as planned.

ShortDescription: Wood operator struck Wood vehicle with Track hoe counterweight causing minor damage to the back right corner of Wood vehicle.
FullDescription: On Wednesday June 22nd, 2022, a Wood maintenance crew was removing a culvert that was over the fuel gas and waterlines. The culvert was very close to the lines, so the employees backed a truck with a generator next to the track hoe to utilize equipment to cut the culvert away from the lines to avoid damaging the lines when they removed the culvert. After the cuts were made, the track hoe operator removed a large piece of concrete from the bell hole, upon swinging the bucket, the counterweights struck the parked vehicle behind the track hoe. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Contacted supervisor and HSSE.

ShortDescription: Wood rental vehicle damaged in restaurant parking lot
FullDescription: On June 21, 2022 at approximately 1430, a Wood employee parked their rental vehicle (vehicle #1) in a restaurant parking lot to go inside. Upon exiting the restaurant, an Amazon delivery truck contacted the parked vehicle (vehicle #2) adjacent to the Wood rental vehicle. The Amazon delivery truck's contact with vehicle #2 dislodged multiple ladders that were secured on the vehicle #2. The ladders contacted vehicle #1 resulting in minor damage. The Actual and Potential was A1 as there was minor damage to the rental vehicle not to exceed 10k.
ImmediateAction: Wood employee called the local authorities to initiate a police report. The damage was cosmetic and the wood employee was able to continue on their journey.

ShortDescription: Hyd oil spill 0.05L of biodegradable hyd oil from Hydro Veac unit on Laurini (PP 250)
FullDescription: Spill of approximately 0.05 L biodegradable hydraulic oil from Hydro Vac Unit mounted on the Laurini Mule Trax 2,400 (PP 250) leaked onto the secondary containment and slowly dripped onto the ground. The oil leak on the ground was noticed by an excavator operator who was walking behind the equipment and the Laurini operator was advised to shut down. The cause of the spill was due to a loose hydraulic connection to one of the hydraulic pumps coming loose because of equipment vibration.
ImmediateAction: The equipment was immediately shut down by the operatorA drip tray was placed under the leakage to contain further spill onto the ground surface and peat moss absorbent sawdust was spread over the contaminated ground surface to absorb the hydraulic oil. The mechanic on site came over and tightened the connection.The soaked peat moss sawdust on the ground was scraped with shovels and bagged and the contaminated soil was also removed and bagged. Further clean up of equipment’s secondary containment with peat moss absorbent sawdust and absorbent pads was done effectively and waste placed into contaminated waste bags.The bagged contaminated sawdust, soil, and absorbent pads were transported back to Moro X and stored in the DG bunded container.

ShortDescription: Individual was contacted by flying debris just below right scapula while weed eating adjacent to mowing operations
FullDescription: On Tuesday, June 21st, 2022, individual was cutting grass using a weed eater underneath solar panel. On the array row adjacent to their location (approximately 15 feet), a zero-turn mower, with a 72" deck, was in motion cutting the grass. When zero turn mower operator did a 360 turn to get away from the CAB System and drive out of the row to do the next row on his right, the mower, rode over a rock that was mostly embedded on the ground (deck is set approx. 4" from the ground), causing a small piece of rock to break off. The piece of rock exited the discharge deflector and contacted worker adjacent to the operator, below their right scapula.  Actual rating is an A1 since onsite medic evaluated worker, but no treatment was administered. The potential severity is a B2 since medical treatment could be a possibility if flying debris contacts open skin in a different location.
ImmediateAction: Supervisor took individual to onsite EMT for evaluation. Work stopped, JSA closed, and witness statements were captured. Project agreed on leaving three clear rows of solar panels between mowers and bystanders as of abundance of precaution until more information is obtained. Investigation has been initiated. Project is evaluating the energy associated with the projectile.

ShortDescription: Employee experienced discomfort, tingling sensation in face, dizziness and disoriented.

Employee was able to tell co-workers she was experiencing discomfort, tingling sensation in face, dizziness and disoriented. Co-workers immediately notified Wood HSE lead and initiated on site emergency response team. The site EMT arrived and evaluated the employee. The decision was made to summon local ambulance for transport to local emergency room for further care and evaluation. Actual and B2 due to care and transport to local emergency room.
ImmediateAction: Notified site emergency response team. Notified site management and client.

ShortDescription: Pile Driving Machine tilted over while turning to place the steel plate on the ground resulting in damage to the machine.
FullDescription: At approximately 10.20 AM, Pile Driving Machine No. 05 was moving from the west side to the east side of the Wastewater Treatment area (approx. 22 meters away) to continue the piling work. The Pile Driving Machine laid 2 steel plates on the ground before travelling on them. While trying to deploy the 3rd steel plate, the  lifting and turning motion of the Pile Driving Machine caused the ground that it was standing on to move and its consequent tilting over. There was no one in the line of fire within the barricaded area. The machine operator was sitting in the cabin with the seat belt fastened and his helmet worn when this happened. After the machine has completely tilted over and laid flat on the ground, the operator turned off the engine and got out from the cabin safely before he informed his supervisor about the incident.
ImmediateAction: -	Secured the incident site with additional barricade and signage.  -	Informed all stakeholders (Wood CM, Wood PM, Wood HSSES Manager, Lenzing CM, Lenzing SHE Manager). -	Stopped all of SCP activities. -	Conducted Safety Standdown to all SCP team members, led by Wood Construction Manager and Wood HSSE Manager. -	Commenced incident investigation on the same day at 1 pm.

ShortDescription: A Wood EE received medical treatment for minor first and second degree burns to his hands and face. EE released to full duty.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, June 21, 2022, the EE was tasked with removing water out of the gas gathering lines using a foam pig.  The EE had completed running the foam pig through a 12-inch line and needed to put the line back into production.  At about 13:15, as he was reinstalling the top flange on the steel riser, the gas coming out of the line engulfed the Wood truck, unit 476,, which was idling down wind, and ignited, causing total damage to the truck.  The EE did not suffer any burns from the initial ignition, but in the process of trying to move the truck out of the area, the EE suffered first, and second degree burns to the right side of his face and to the wrist on his right hand.  When the EE realized the truck was not savable, he grabbed his phone and exited the truck.  He walked up the road to a safe distance and notified his supervisor and the local fire department.  Actual severity is B-2 because the IP received medical treatment.  Potential severity is B-3 because the injury could have resulted in a Lost Time Injury/Significant Health Effect.
ImmediateAction: The EE called his supervisor to report the incident.  The HSSES Advisor was notified.  The local fire department was notified.  Axiom was contacted and the nurse advised the EE to be taken to a medical facility for evaluation.  He was transported by the HSSES Advisor to the local ER where he was treated with over-the-counter ibuprofen, burn cream and given a prescription for pain medication.

ShortDescription: Hessian sack fell to sea during FRC loading operations
FullDescription: During a package transfer from CPC to the Fast Rescue Craft - one of the hessian sacks being transferred fell approx. 15m to sea. The package weighed 11kg and was retrieved from the sea by the FRC. The hessian sack was being lowered by a rope & hook, connected to a tie wrap around the sack. The tie wrap failed and ultimately the hessian sack descended to the sea. No damage was sustained to any personnel, the vessel, the bag or its contents.The FRC procedure dictates it does not approach the object being lowered until it is at sea level, as such there is no risk to people during this process.
ImmediateAction: FRC proceeded in and retrieved the sack from the seaServices Team Lead immediately tasked with improving PTW controlsInstruction from OIM that no lowering of any materials permitted unless in SWL rated bagsOnshore immediately instructed to source rated equipment for this task

ShortDescription: Spill of approximately 0.05 L hydraulic oil from a Drilling Equipment (PP 236) attached to Spider Excavator (PP 244)
FullDescription: Spill of approximately 0.05 L hydraulic oil from a Drilling Equipment (PP 236) attached to Spider Excavator (PP 244)Approximately 0.05L had dripped onto the ground surface when it was noticed by one of the roustabouts.The cause of the spill was due to wear and tear of the fitting.Weather condition was fine/sunny with no rain. The spill was confined to the micro pile trench and hence, no impact to the existing stormwater drainages or ecological impact at the time of incident.
ImmediateAction: The equipment was immediately shut down by the operator when a roustabout noticed the spill and site supervisor was notified.A drip tray was placed under the leakage to contain further spill onto the ground surface and peat moss absorbent sawdust was spread over the contaminated ground surface to absorb the hydraulic oil. The mechanic on site immediately attended to the drilling unit.The soaked peat moss sawdust on the ground was scraped with shovels and bagged and the contaminated soil was also removed and bagged. Further clean up of equipment body with absorbent pads was done appropriately and waste placed into contaminated waste bags.The bagged contaminated sawdust, soil, and absorbent pads were transported back to Moro X and stored in the DG bunded container.

ShortDescription: A wood truck was struck by an oncoming vehicle after pulling into an intersection causing Minor damage.
FullDescription: On Friday, June 17, 2022, at approximately 1:10pm, a Wood lease operator was making a U-Turn near AR 1791-6-35 at an intersection. While performing the maneuver and turning back onto the preceding road the EE was unaware of an oncoming water truck.  The oncoming truck contacted the front corner on the driver side of the vehicle damaging the front driver panel, headlight, bumper, and grill. At the time of impact, the water truck was traveling less than 20mph. No party sustained any injuries, and no first aid was administered. AXIOM was contacted as a precaution; the EE did not require any first aid or medical evaluation. Local law enforcement investigated the incident and did not issue any citations. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck would have been greater than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: The EE reported the incident to the HSSES Advisor and supervisor.

ShortDescription: IP rolled right ankle while walking on work area
FullDescription: On Friday, June 17th, 2022, IP had already placed an Arc Flash label on a Combiner Box at PCS 23, Block 3 at Snowberry, as part of assigned tasks. In the process of walking to the next Combiner Box, IP stepped on soft ground (mud was present due to rain from previous day). The change in ground conditions caused IP to slip, right foot supinated and fell on its left side. IP felt discomfort and reported the incident to supervisor. Wood HSSE was notified, and IP was taken to Wood HSSE trailer to be evaluated by onsite medic. After assessing condition, RICE protocol was implemented to care for right ankle soft tissue sprain. Actual rating is B1 since onsite medic started FA treatment for soft tissue injury. The potential severity is an B2 since medical treatment could be a possibility if protocol for soft tissue injuries is not followed during initial assessment and first 72 hrs.
ImmediateAction: Crew stopped work and IP notified Foreman and GF about slip and fall from same level event. Accident investigation was initiated by gathering statements, collecting JSA and capturing a picture of conditions of the ground.

ShortDescription: Water leak from HVAC system through ceiling tiles onto monitors and docking stations due to obstruction in the condensate drain line.
FullDescription: 8:34AM Facilities received an email from Mike Leary with a report on “Water dripping form ceiling tiles at cubicles U1018E, U1019”. At around 8:45am, O&M Facilities team had been at the reported leak location to address this reported emergency situation. A quick investigation showed that the reported leak was caused by an HVAC roof top unit located directly above cubicle U1019NE. Within an hour or so, the HVAC issue was addressed and resolved. The water around the area was mopped up and furniture was allowed to dry. The damaged ceiling tiles were replaced. No employees, laptops, or desktops were present in these cubicles or nearby.
ImmediateAction: HVAC issue resolved. Inspected other HVAC units in the building. Incident investigation underway.

ShortDescription: Silt laden run-off bypassed two timber-log cross drains and sumps then entered the Swinkey Burn
FullDescription: Torrential rain within the Afton catchment mobilised significant volume of sediment from the access tracks.  The associated rainwater / silt laden run-off bypassed two timber-log cross drains and sumps then entered the Swinkey Burn.  Mitigation (silt curtain) installed downstream, prior to works, prevented the silt laden water entering the main body of the Afton Reservoir. Thus, preventing a significant environmental incident
ImmediateAction: All works ceased immediately and the mitigation team mobilised a small excavator within a few minutes of the initial observation to resolve the issue. Excavated cross drains were installed to divert the silt laden water into the sumps.  This stopped the silt laden water entering the Swinkey Burn immediately and the watercourse was running clear within 10 mins.  The full incident from initial observation to the watercourse running clear was approx. 45 – 60 mins

ShortDescription: Injury to arm while opening a fire door
FullDescription: Individual was working with colleague to move a wooden box at M1C area.To achieve this they required a pallet truck and went over to fire pump module C to obtain one.The individual had to open the sliding door to retrieve the pallet truck, therefore grabbed hold of the door handle with his right arm fully extended and began to slide open the door. While doing this they felt a sharp pain within the arm area where the upper arm meets the forearm.Work colleague came around the corner as he was opening he door and helped pull their coveralls down at one side to inspect their arm as he was unable to raise it towards his chest and on doing so identified that the right bicep was hanging at an awkward angle. Coverall was placed back over the arm and they both went to the medic to allow the arm to be checked over.Working with Occ Health for the final report to determine classification which may change on receipt of final confirmation of Fitness to Return to Work Certificate.
ImmediateAction: Individual visited the medic to have their arm checked over.The medic was limited to what he could check so advised that individual be placed on crew change chopper on Friday to visit ARI.Individual was seen at ARI who provided diagnosis with advice to attend his local ARI at home (England) for scan.They then visited ISOS to get checked over and assessed before being allowed to travel home.ARI visited at home on Saturday morning where scan was undertaken and diagnosis was tear to both forearm and bicep muscles and stretched tendons/ligaments.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Homeless and agitated man on premises. Returned several times. Sherriff and Police were notified.
FullDescription: A man entered the office spaces around 9:30 or 10:00AM and was acting strange. He finally straightened up and asked if we had a Job application. I came walking up front at this time and noticed he was acting strange and that another accountant was also behind the desk at this time. She was out of view and rolled her eyes at me indicating concern. I then called the PM that was in the office up front to join us. He finally finished the application and I followed him off the property. Approximately 40 min later he was spotted coming back so the mechanic myself and 2 other employees made our presence known in the parking lot and he was advised by the equipment manager to not come on the property and keep walking.  He did. Again about an hour and a half later he returned and went into the shop and threatened the mechanic with a hammer. The police had already been notified and were in route. The mechanic told him "the smartest thing you can do at this time is leave Police are in route. He left and the police and Sheriff confronted him in front of the building on Highway 395. He was told to stay off the property and head out of town. The Sheriff also told him that if he returns to the property he will be arrested. The Sheriff came back to us after confronting the man and told us that he has the potential to become violent so be cautious not to provoke him. We will ensure at least a 2 man concept tomorrow when opening the gate and office. We have maintained a full lockdown on the building since the first incident. Grading justification Actual - 1 threatened 1 intimidated, Potential - 1 attacked
ImmediateAction: Locked down the Building. Notified the Authorities. Had a meeting with office personnel on security and 2 man concept for the next few day especially when opening and closing the office and yard.

ShortDescription: One smoke blow came out of the load bank during generator testing
FullDescription: At approximately 09:45 member of the Wood commissioning team reported that cloud of smoke came out of the permanent load bank located at the MDA Back-up power. Smoke came out during the generator test with the load - 1.98MW after noticing smoke coming out of the load bank fans, generator was promptly manually opened removing the generator from the load. Wood Safety Manager was contacted with information of abnormal situation and possible need of Fire Brigade support. US Navy Fire Brigade was contacted. Fire Brigade came to the place of event after verification that there in no load on the equipment load bank was check with the thermovision camera to assure that equipment will not ignite. After positive verification that equipment will not ignite. Place of event was secured and all supply circuits to the load bank secured with LOTO locks
ImmediateAction: 1. Removing the generator from the load2. Contacting US Navy Fire Brigate for possible support3. On the spot check with thermovision camera as assurane that equipment will not ignite4. Isolating load bank from all sides and applying LOTO5. Securing and monitoring of the equipment

Exceedances range from 7 - 30 kilometres over the speed limit. Many of these exceedances occurred in regional areas of Sth East/East QLD. The Driver was the only occupant of the vehicle. There is no reported data of loss of vehicle control.

ShortDescription: Wood EEs were exposed to fibers/particles from materials being used by another contractor work group working below the Wood EEs.
FullDescription: On Friday 06/17/2022 @ 9:45AM, Wood I&E EE's were pulling wire in the pipe rack at the B72/LHC-7 turnaround. Wood I&E EE1 saw particles in the air around their work area. Wood I&E EE1 started to experience shortness of breath and began coughing a short time after noticing particles in the air in the work area. Wood I&E EE1 got down from the structure and saw that there was another company removing/installing some insulation from pipes. Wood I&E EE1 went to Wood Foreman about the situation. The Wood Foreman then told the other Wood I&E EE's (EE 2,3,4,5) to get down from the structure. The Wood Foreman then went to Dow Operations to inform them of the exposed EE's. Dow Ops called Dow ES&S to come out to B7200 to evaluate the Wood I&E EE's. Potential - EEs were evaluated and released back to work with no restrictions.
ImmediateAction: Dow ES&S was called to come check on Wood I&E EE's. A Wood I&E EE was transported to Occupational Medical Clinic due to the EE having breathing problems and coughing. The other Wood I&E EE's were transported by company vehicle to Occupational Medical Clinic. All Wood I&E EE's were evaluated and released back to work with no restrictions. Wood HSSES is currently investigating the incident. Dow EHS and IH investigated the work area and determined that material was NON-ACM and that although there were reports of ACM present in the work area of the other contractor, the proper mitigations and controls were in place and that ACM's had not been disturbed and that no release of ACM or exposure to ACM occurred.

ShortDescription: Wood EE cut his right palm while working and left the jobsite without informing Wood or client supervision to seek treatment at Urgent Care.
FullDescription: A Wood IE employee who is nested within a client IE work group was tasked with pulling and stripping instrumentation cable/wire while working with a client work partner. While performing this task, the Wood IE EE reports that they sustained a laceration to their right palm while using a Wood and Client approved hook/bill knife. The Wood IE EE states that they were stripping cable/wire by pulling the hook knife towards their hand. The Wood IE EE informed their client co-worker that they needed to leave the work area and would return. The Wood IE EE then left the work area and client site plant without notifying Wood or Client supervision or HSSES/EHS and went to a local Urgent Care Clinic in Lake Jackson, TX for treatment where they received six sutures for the wound to their left hand. The client co-worker informed their client supervisor that the Wood IE EE had left the job site and not returned. The client supervisor stated that the Wood IE EE had contacted them via personal cell phone and stated that they had a "personal family emergency and would not return to work for the rest of the day, and possibly not return for the rest of the week". A short time late, the Wood IE EE returned to the client work group offices to retrieve their personal tools and belongings and informed the client supervisor that they had received sutures for an injury sustained while working earlier that day. The client supervisor notified their manager of the incident.  Wood supervision and HSSES was notified of the incident at approximately 16:00pm. Potential - Laceration could have been more severe but unlikely for any significant injury.
ImmediateAction: Wood Supervision, HSSES and Management Team notified of the incident, Client supervision & EHS notified of the incident. Wood IE EE was accompanied by Wood HSSES to offsite Occ Med provider for evaluation of the injury and resulting treatment. Wood Incident Investigation was begun.

ShortDescription: Employee backed inside fenced temporary field office area near I-85 Exit 149 in Commerce, GA
FullDescription: Backing inside a fenced field office area approximately 8ft with foot only on brake pedal.  Backing while turning steering wheel to the right.  Checking front left corner due to close proximity of field office/wood stairs, watching the right side mirror for other stored material, and watching the backup camera.  EE knew the 55-gallon drum was there, but failed to realize how close the rear bumber was before stopping to turn to the left.  The drum remained upright and the piece of plywood remained on top of the drum.
ImmediateAction: Stopped vehicle and looked at bumber and tailgate. Contacted supervisor and HSSE.

ShortDescription: IP rolled right ankle resulting in restricted duties.
FullDescription: The IP walked up the steps on the Rad Zone 2 side of the Boot Wash trailer to remove a sign from the outside of the door. Upon completion of the task, the IP turned around and walked down the steps. As the IP was about to step onto ground level with her right foot from the bottom step, she was distracted by something and looked around. In doing so, she miss-stepped onto the gravel covered ground surface at the bottom of the stairs, causing her to roll her right ankle. Rolling her ankle caused the IP to fall backwards onto the ground.  At the time of the incident the IP was holding a laminated paper sign in her hand, and was not using the handrail for stability. The IP was wearing pull-on style safety boots (no laces).
ImmediateAction: Work care contacted, visit to clinic.

ShortDescription: Forklift driver was offloading some equipment from a truck when that piece of equipment struck some granite that was also on the truck causi
FullDescription: A Wood employee was operating a forklift south of the store house removing some equipment from the trailer of a hot shot truck. As the operator was attempting to remove the second piece of equipment, the lifting eyes on the side of the equipment struck a granite slab on the hot shot trailer, causing the granite to break and snap on the end of both slabs. The hot shot driver was acting as the spotter because the forklift driver could not see on the side of the load. The spotter failed to stop the forklift driver prior to striking the granite. Wood Safety was contacted immediately and the forklift driver was taken to offsite for post accident protocol.  Potential - damage was minor less than $10K, no evidence to suggest injuries could have occurred.
ImmediateAction: Work was stopped, and foreman contacted Wood safety. Employee was taken to offsite medical for Post Accident Protocol.

ShortDescription: Solar panel damaged after being contacted by zero turn rollover protection system (ROPS)
FullDescription: On Monday June 13th, 2022 at approximately 3:45PM, a subcontractor's zero turn mower became stuck in mud. The ROPS was stowed in the down position and elevated to approximately 45 degrees for extraction. After extracting the zero turn mower, the operator began operating under the solar modules and contacted a panel with the ROPS. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor; the replacement of panel and zero turn ROPS repair is less than 10k.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the Project Manager and Incident Investigation protocols were initiated.

ShortDescription: IP was stung by a bee on left forearm
FullDescription: On Monday, June 13, 2022, around 10:45am, Commissioning employee was Zip Tying string cable when suddenly a bee stung him on left forearm. IP was brought to onsite medic where he was evaluated, and treatment was provided. IP was released to return to work. The actual severity rating is a B1 since IP was stung and received first aid treatment. The potential severity rating is a B1 since IP has not experienced any allergic reaction to the sting.
ImmediateAction: IP was evaluated by onsite medic; First aid treatment was provided sting relief and was released to return to work. JSA was closed. Investigation is on process.

ShortDescription: IP Stung by bee on abdomen
FullDescription: On Monday, June 13, 2022, at approximately 10:45am, Commissioning employee was walking through the arrays of Block 4 Pcs 6 row 6 when a bee stung him on the abdomen. IP was brought to onsite medic where he was evaluated, and treatment was provided. IP has not had any reaction to the sting. The actual severity rating is a B1 since IP was stung and received first aid treatment. The potential severity rating is a B1 since IP has not experienced any allergic reaction to the sting.
ImmediateAction: IP was evaluated by onsite medic; First aid treatment and sting relief was provided, JSA was closed. Investigation is in process. IP is being monitored for any late reactions.

ShortDescription: Found IP in the SP0E kitchen running cold water over burnt hand.
FullDescription: Found IP this morning in SP0E kitchen running her hand under the cold water tap. Asked her what happened, she explained that she had scalded herself but she was ok.
ImmediateAction: I told her to keep her hand under the cold tap and it should really be looked at and put her in contact with one of our First Aiders.  IP believed injury was not severe and carried on with day-to-day activities.  Subsequently injury persisted and therefore IP went to Security for further assistance instead of contacting one of the first aiders.  IP left site later on in the day and went to the pharmacy for a cold press and further assistance.

ShortDescription: Transport contractor dropped laser printer when unloading it.
FullDescription: Laser printer was being transported to site in order  to make laser etched labels on site for equipment installations.  The printer was transported to site using a transport company arranged by the supplier.When unloading the printer the unit was wheeled onto the tail lift of the truck, but due to the nature of the ground conditions it needed to be lifted to transport it into the sea container being set up as the work location.  The transport company employees used a lifting strap under the metal frame of the printer, but as the weight was taken up, the balance of the load shifted and the printer toppled over to the ground.  No injuries were sustained.
ImmediateAction: Unit and area was made safe, incident was reported.

ShortDescription: Employee cut hand while cutting a zip tie requires first aid and medical attention
FullDescription: IP was installing bat detector boxes in the monitoring study area of Oakwood Natural Area. IP tried cutting a zip tie that was used to mount the detector box in place on a small tree in order to make an adjustment to the detector box.  Due to the size of the tree, the IP used their left hand to stabalize the tree below the monitor.  Using the pocket knife in the IP's right hand to attempt to cut the zip tie in a downward motion the knife slipped off the zip tie, and cut through/punctured the left hand/thumb used to stablize the small tree.  June 20th UPDATE:  Document analisys and interviews with the IP and their direct Supervisor have indicated that gloves were not implemented the day of the incident and were not indicated as required PPE by the AHA or the project HASP.  During the interview it was outlined that on June 13 the IP was working alongside their direct supervisor on site, however in different reqions, and they both had general purpose cloth gloves on them.  However, they rarely used the gloves for the direct task of mounting/monitoring the bat monitors.
ImmediateAction: After call the IP's supervisor, the IP compresed and elevated the wounded hand, and recognizing assiatance was required, proceeded to seek prompt first aid from the staff at nearby arena/rec centre which was within quick walking distance. After receiving first aid from the complex staff, the IP called 911 EMS given the apparent depth of cut and continued bleeding.  The EMS crew arrived promptly, examined and redressed the wound, and proceeded to transport the IP to receive medical treatment at a hospital. Following a period of time in the hospital waiting room, a doctor proceeded to diagnose, clean and close/repair the wound with stitches. The wound was sterilized and redressed with bandages. IP was also given a tetanus shot as a precaution. The IP was released from hospital emergency and was picked up by vehicle and transported by the IPs supervisor (following contact by phone), contacted WorkCare and was driven back to the IPs parked vehicle at the Oakwood Community centre. The IP then drove himself home and contacted his supervisor to confirm that he had arrived home safely.

ShortDescription: Wood Company Truck 01.20.0035 was reported missing by Firestone Automotive in Clute, TX on 6/13/2022.
FullDescription: Wood Company Truck 01.20.0035 was reported missing from Firestone Automotive in Clute, TX on 6/13/2022. A representative with Firestone Automotive contacted Wood Mechanic Shop Manager Steve Morgan to report that the vehicle was missing from the Firestone Automotive property. The vehicle had been dropped off at Firestone Automotive on 6/6/2022 by Wood Employee Cheyenne Etie for repairs and service to the air conditioning system. Potential - No impact to business operations.
ImmediateAction: Wood Company records were back checked to confirm that the vehicle had not been picked up by a Wood employee or another Wood work group. A police report was filed with Clute, TX PD on 6/13/2022 by Steve Morgan. Wood HSSES was notified of the missing/stolen vehicle on 6/23/2022. A criminal investigation is ongoing by local law enforcement organizations.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Nonpreventable, rental vehicle, minor damage, no injury.
FullDescription: At about 9:40 pm while driving on the Yellowhead highway ( roughly 40km from Hinton) wildlife leapt out of the forest and hit the driver's side of the truck. It first hit the driver's door then its body slammed at the tail of the truck just before the rear tire.
ImmediateAction: Internal reporting initiated.

ShortDescription: Bee sting on left side of neck.
FullDescription: At the Roswell, NM Army National Guard Base on the east side parking lot of the Field Maintenance Shop a hollow stem auger rig was drilling. During well drilling; the driller swatted at a bee flying around head, thinking it was a fly. The bee stung subcontractor on the left side of neck.
ImmediateAction: The driller stated that hasn’t been allergic in the past to bee stings, but it itched. The stringer wasn't present in neck. The left side of neck was cleaned with alcohol wipes, sting ointment was applied to the effected area. Monitored for signs of swelling, and off site personnel (Wood task manager, client contact, and drilling supervisor) were notified.

ShortDescription: Small bore fitting identified as being finger tight on site walk down
FullDescription: MC (tri-party) walk undertaken on boundary of limit of system handover (LOSH) drawings (see Figure 7). Walk and associated punch items recorded within MC  dossier .The MC dossier was handed over/accepted by commissioning. No further new joints were assembled or any of the existing joints disturbed as part of commissioning activities (commissioning only encompassed a function check of PT 813066). Service test pack developed and added to SH dossier to capture all Once the PT function check was completed the system handover dossier was offered to operations for acceptance No leak testing was performed on the system as part of commissioning activities. Service test and associated IDP approved by site authority As part of line walk and commencement of service test a seep was identified on joint 54719 (joint found to be “hand tight”) Joint with seep reassembled and service test commenced.
ImmediateAction: Initially recorded by client as unsafe condition revised to NM following investigation carried out with QA

ShortDescription: Hyd oil spilll 0.15L of biodegradable hyd oil from a Bob Cat Skid Steer (PP 205)
FullDescription: Spill of approximately 0.15 L of PANOLIN biodegradable hydraulic oil from a Bob Cat Skid Steer (PP 205)when moving tools and equipment from the winch pad to the laydown area.
ImmediateAction: Spill of approximately 0.15L of PANOLIN biodegradable hydraulic oil from a Bob Cat Skid Steer (PP 205) when moving tools and equipment from the winch pad to the laydown area.Approximately 0.15 L dripped onto the access road ground surface from the end of Yellow Zone 3 to Yellow Zone 2.Weather condition was fine/sunny with no rain. A drip tray was placed under the belly compartment of the skid steer to contain further spill onto the ground surface and peat moss absorbent sawdust was spread over the contaminated ground surface to absorb the hydraulic oil.The soaked peat moss sawdust on the ground was scraped with shovels and bagged and the contaminated soil from the equipment track was also removed and bagged. Further clean up of equipment body with absorbent pads and waste placed into contaminated waste bags.The bagged contaminated sawdust, soil, and absorbent pads were transported back to Moro X and stored in the DG bunded container. While the bucket containing hydraulic oil was temporarily stored in a bund in the site container. The hydraulic oil will be transferred into a closed container to be transported to Camp 6 compound for storage into restricted waste IBC tote.

The medication IP is currently taking is 500mg of Naproxen and it is for a total of 7 days. IP informed HSE this week and HSE conductED the incident report today, June 16, 2022. IP felt that injury didn't require him to miss work.  IP has been asked to call Workcare to provide further guidance.

ShortDescription: Wood winch fell off Contractor delivery vehicle
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: At 1208hrs, transport company Dickinson’s attended our depot to drop off an empty 40ft trailer for loading and collect a pre-loaded trailer for delivery to our Bishopswood contract – on arrival the driver was advised where to drop the empty trailer and given instruction on the loaded trailer.While the yard attendant was sorting out the paperwork for the loaded paper, the driver parked the unloaded trailer near the loaded trailer, unhitched the unloaded trailer and then hooked up to the loaded trailer. After hooking up to the loaded trailer the driver realised that he had parked the unloaded trailer to close to the loaded trailer leaving no room for himself to be able to strap the loaded trailer down. The driver then moved the loaded trailer with the unsecure load to be able to strap the equipment down and, on doing so, lost one of our 5t TEMA winches off the back of the trailer causing damage to the winch.
ImmediateAction: Yard crew righted the winch using the yard telehandler before it could leak more oil.Small oil spill cleanedInvestigation commenced with photos taken and initial statement prepared and signed

He did not make a notation of it on the timesheet as required.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0061 MTC Aecon; laceration left thumb from clamp
FullDescription: IP was removing peri-form clamps, when clamp slipped and struck IP’s left thumb causing a laceration. IP was wearing gloves at time of incident.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and supervisor contacted. IP was taken to onsite PA who assessed, cleaned and bandage. IP was sent to Timmins for further assessment. IP received sutures. Canadian Model followed. IP returned to work. Incident Investigation initiated.

FullDescription: IP states back strain occurred 5 days prior to reporting
ImmediateAction: GP review organised.Coaching and Mentoring undertaken re: immediate reporting

ShortDescription: During an excavation activity, the excavator bucket broke a pvc pipe, following the pipe rupture there was a liquid leak.
FullDescription: On June 9th , a team of civil workers was engaged in excavation and earth-moving activities in the area of the tank farm. Around 3 p.m., the excavator bucket sheared a PLE pipe; a clear, odorless liquid came out. The workers immediately stopped their activities and informed Wood's team of the event. Wood's team, after conducting a site inspection, contacted the customer to find out the service of the damaged pipe.
ImmediateAction: As per procedure, all activities in the area were stopped and the client was informed of the event.Random tests were conducted to analyze the contents of the spilled liquid, as the nature of the broken pipe has not yet been traced.

ShortDescription: EG National was experiencing symptoms and subsequently tested positive for COVID-19
ImmediateAction: IP was placed under quarantine and will be tested again prior to returning to normal duties.

ShortDescription: Whilst manually moving swivel style light pole IP’s thumb has been caught in the pinch point.
FullDescription: At approximately 12.30pm on the 9th June 2022 a SCEE storeman was offloading a swivel type light pole from the truck bed onto a pallet on the ground in Area 2172-Leaching lay down area. Whilst manually moving swivel style light pole from truck bed to a pallet on ground, IP placed his hand in the pinch point area of the swivel and pinched the skin on right thumb. Supervisor contacted HSE Team immediately and IP was taken to Medical Centre for examination and treatment and returned to work.
ImmediateAction: Supervisor contacted HSE Team immediately and IP was taken to Medical Centre for examination and treatment.

ShortDescription: IP felt dizziness and had a shortness of breathe.
FullDescription: IP felt dizziness and had a shortness of breathe. first aid as called and the IP was escorted to the first aid room. no known medical history with the IP. First aider called 111 for medical advice. The operator referred the IP to his local GP for a further assessment. got hold of their GP who requested them to attend A&E. IP took a taxi from Shinfield at14:49 to Frimley PArk A&E.
ImmediateAction: A member of the IP team called security for a First Aider.

ShortDescription: Skid steer windshield broke while closing the door
FullDescription: On Thursday June 9th, 2022, at approximately 10:15 the operator of a skid steer went to close the door of the skid steer. While closing the door the window rubber seal broke causing window to fall. The actual severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor (less than 10K). The potential severity rating is B1 because there was a potential for minor first aid event.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the incident were gathered. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: While going through the hatch, WGS Inspector caught the side of the hatch causing minor laceration to his eyelid.
FullDescription: While going through the hatch, WGS Inspector caught the side of the hatch causing minor laceration to his eyelid as his glasses were pushed down. An investigation has been launched to find out the real causes of the accident.
ImmediateAction: The injured person was evacuated by the FERTIAL ambulance to the Annaba ophthalmological clinic where a surgical glue was used to his eyelid to close a laceration of approximately 2-3mm. IP then returned to his work station.

ShortDescription: Employee stung on back of neck by bee.
FullDescription: On Wednesday, June 8, 2022, at approximately 12:15am, Employee (IP) was sitting near Block 3 PCS 15 when a bee flew into their hair, they swatted the bee away, and the bee stung the IP on the neck. IP was evaluated and treatment was provided. IP did not have any reaction to the sting. The actual severity rating is a B1 since IP was stung and received first aid treatment. The potential severity rating is a B1 since IP has not experienced any allergic reaction to the sting.
ImmediateAction: IP was evaluated by onsite medic; First aid treatment and sting relief was provided, JSA was closed. Investigation is in process. IP is being monitored for any late reactions

ShortDescription: A plexiglass windshield on a golf cart contacted a Wood employee’s forehead causing a superficial. laceration.
FullDescription: On Wednesday, June 8, 2022, at approximately 13:45, the Wood IP was tasked with driving a golf cart to a connex to load some cases of water.  The golf cart has a two-piece, fold-down windshield.  The top half of the windshield was folded down.  As the IP was driving the golf cart to the connex, the wind was gusting sand and dirt directly in the IP’s face.  As, the IP reached down and grabbed the upper half of the windshield to fold it up to give full protection, the windshield separated at the seam between the upper and lower windshields.  The wind blew the upper windshield back at the IP, striking him in the forehead causing a superficial laceration.  The Actual Severity is B1 because the IP was taken for medical evaluation and no treatment was given.  The Potential Severity is a B2 because the injury could have required medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: The IP reported the incident to the account manager the day after the incident.  Axiom was called, and the nurse referred the IP to a local medical facility for evaluation.

ShortDescription: Cat 336 Excavator (0485) made contact with McCloskey R155 Screen Plant (2287)
FullDescription: Operator was on the side of the McCloskey Screen Plant (#2287) looking at material to load with a CAT 336 Excavator (30485).  The excavator shifted forward and to the right which caused the bucket to scrape along the side of the screen plant denting the access cover, breaking a hydraulic fitting,  and moving the handrail.  The paint above and to the side of the access cover was also scraped.
ImmediateAction: Operator shut down the machine and called his supervisor.  This occurred at approximately 1430. Safety was called to the scene and the investigation was started.

ShortDescription: Forklift struck fixed bollard
FullDescription: Forklift operator driving out of the WOOD scaffold yard drove into a fixed bollard, no damage to plant or equipment and no hurt. The forklift had stopped at the exit to give way to other vehicles. When he drove forward approximately 300mm the forklift struck the yellow bollard which was in a blind spot for the operator. It is worth noting that the bollard is a legacy from when there was a spoon drain adjacent to the exit to the scaffold yard. The bollard does not protect anything and is now an obstacle for vehicles exiting the yard.
ImmediateAction: Forklift operator reported to supervisor, and was accompanied to the Sale Medical Centre for drug and alcohol testing. The results were negative (no signs of Alcohol or other drugs in the operators system).

ShortDescription: Volvo 45G Articulating Haul Truck - Bed tipped onto side
FullDescription: Employee drove the left rear tires of a Volvo G45 articulating haul truck (#2700)  up on a pile of rocks/dirt while backing up, which caused the bed to turn over to the right side.  There was no injury to the driver or damage to the truck.  The truck was being spotted by a dozer operator.
ImmediateAction: The driver immediately called their supervisor and safety.   A safety stand down was held for all employees to show them the truck and to discuss the reasons why it occurred.  Employees also offered suggestions as to how it could have been prevented.

ShortDescription: Wood truck strikes Deer
FullDescription: Employee was returning from his home in Colorado to Tioga, ND in the Watford area on Hwy 85 employee states it was drizzling and it was dark he was driving the speed limit 65 mph when a deer jumped in front of the Wood truck and he struck the deer on the passenger side front with the grill guard damaging the headlight and bending the hood, the deer went over the grill guard and into the passenger side door mirror damaging it as well. No damage to the engine compartment he said he pulled over and checked that no fluids were leaking and everything is okay. The incident is classified as a B1/B2 on the actual/potential severity matrix.
ImmediateAction: Employee pulled over and assess the damaged vehicle.

ShortDescription: Wood employee driving company truck hit a deer while driving to work.
FullDescription: Wood employee operating a company pick-up was driving south on Highway 35.  When located a few 100m north of the Lindsay Airport the driver noted a deer jump over the road from left to right in front of the vehicle.  The driver was watching the deer continue on to the west when another deer, unobserved by the driver, jumped in front of the vehicle.  The second deer was struck.  The collision caused damage to the trucks front end.
ImmediateAction: Pulled off to the side of road, Police were dispatched to record the incident.

ShortDescription: The Wood scaffold leader was fall  sufferings a cut on left shin while assembling the scaffold to remove a valve in the pump room.
FullDescription: On Jun 06th, at approx. 15:00, a scaffold leader (IP) was assembling scaffold to lift and replace valves on the last floor of a pump room.  To replace the valves, the floor grating had to be removed.   During the task, the IP attempted to get more materials and slipped on the beam structure striking their left leg (Shin) on the steel column resulting in a laceration and falling approx. 2.2 meters.  The IP was wearing fall protection which arrested their fall and was able to climb back up to the original location where the Client ERT assisted and referred to offshore medical for initial assessment, followed by assessment and treatment from an onshore physician.  The laceration required 7 sutures to close the wound.  Actual: B2 was selected as the incident required medical treatment. Potential: B3 was selected as the incident could have had worse consequences depending on the fall and strike to the body.
ImmediateAction: Stop work and Safety meeting was held by supervisor reinforcing the LSR Work at Height. The Ip was moved to onshore to be assed deeply by specialist.

ShortDescription: Ankle rolled while doing on-site tunnel top inspection, due to sudden change of unnoticeable walkway surface level drop
FullDescription: IP was performing duties as inspector on-site. While IP was trying to capture photos of material defects to make a report on it and stepped backward without noticing the stepping surface level drop by 2" and rolled over ankle by stepping on the edge.
ImmediateAction: WorkCare contacted

The crane was temporarily placed out of service.
ImmediateAction: The crane was temporarily put out of service until the damaged cable was returned back to service.

ShortDescription: Excavator windshield broken while opening
FullDescription: On Saturday June 4th, 2022, at approximately 0815 the operator of an excavator went to open the windshield of the excavator. While lifting the windshield into the open position, the tempered glass of the windshield broke into small pieces. The actual severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor (less than 10K). The potential severity rating is B1 because there was a potential for minor first aid event.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the incident were gathered. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: NWR - Individual suffered tingling sensation in the arm
FullDescription: Individual was using bench press equipment in the gym during off-shift recreational time. During this process the pin for securing the back rest of the bench slipped out of place causing it to fall and the individual to strike the back of their head against the said back rest in a whip like effect. Later that night the individual experienced a mild tingling sensation down left side of his face and down the left arm, which continued into the early hours, concerned the individual reported to the Medic. The individual was examined, neurologically and physically and advised to return to Medic if any conditions got worse.  ISOS Topside doctor consulted and no further action was required. the individual was an experienced gym user and had completed the appropriate gym induction.
ImmediateAction: Individual consulted the medic. Bench press equipment was checked and no fault found. Individual remined to check all equipment prior to use.

ShortDescription: AP crane used to lift load of 4.4T despite temporary safe workload restriction of 3T due to grit contamination on the rope.
FullDescription: On the morning of Friday 3rd June the involved person (IP) our level 3 crane operator was lifting a manifested 4.6te container from a vessel onto the fixed platform using the AP crane. Under normal circumstances the SWL is 6te, in April 2022 this was de-rated to 50% of its SWL to 3te due to grit on the ropes. This de-rating had been communicated to all and signed off. This particular incident was picked up by the OIM when walking across the platform when they noted that the lift of a 10x8 container is usually 2.4te on its own with no cargo, so to have a 600kg load inside for a 10x8 would be very unusual. The OIM then asked the crane operator what the load he was seeing and the reply was just over 3te, which was not true.
ImmediateAction: The container was put down safely and the incident was discussed by the OIM, the maintenance supervisor, crane op and banksman.  The IP scale of responsibilities were restricted and place under the supervision of another level 3 crane operator on a temporary basis.

ShortDescription: IP felt a tingling sensation on left elbow while reaching into the combiner box
FullDescription: On Friday, June 03, 2022, a quality control inspector was task to check combiner boxes in block 4 PCS 35. The inspector started by inspecting the ground pass through and the CGB under the box before the combiner box was open. He then opened the combiner box and checked the string cable and put his left arm into the box to check the ground. while his arm was in the box IP placed his left elbow on the D/C terminal causing what IP described as a “tingle” in his left elbow. He pulled his arm out of the combiner box and the sensation immediately subsided. He called his supervisor and the electrical department to test for any current. The actual and potential severity rating is A1 as the IP did not sustain an injury and there are no signs of injury and the equipment was verified to be in a zero energy state.
ImmediateAction: IP was evaluated by onsite medic and an Occucare Int. medical professional; vitals were checked, Electrical and QC department verified that there were no panel or string cable connections made, no fuse in the combiner box, and zero current to and from the combiner box. JSA was closed and a new one issued. Witness statements were gathered, UA screening collected, Investigation is in process.

ShortDescription: Piling rig drill component fell on IP foot
FullDescription: During the afternoon of 3rd June 2022 at approximately 14:00pm, the civil contractor was tasked with piling operations in the DWX area of the refinery. The weather conditions were sunny with the ground condition being good and no lighting issues being identified. The experienced operator believed he had attached the drill component to the kelly bar, however, on this occasion the drill component was not effectively engaged and subsequently fell onto the IP's foot. The IP was wearing foot protection that reduced the impact.  The supervisor informed the civil contractor HSSE Manager and also the Wood team. Piling machine and area made safe and initial investigation works began.
ImmediateAction: Supervisor stopped work and immediately informed Contractor HSSE Manager. IP travelled to hospital on own accord. Contractor HSSE Manager informed Wood. IP returned to work on next working day.

ShortDescription: While Wood employee was preparing the job, and turn on the weld machine to test the equipment , an short circuit happen in the machine. .
FullDescription: While Wood employee was preparing the job, and turn on the weld machine to test the equipment , an short circuit happen in the machine.As informed by our operation team, the machine was properly grounded, and the employee was followed the sequence bellow to prepare the job when the short circuit happened.1)           Assuring the voltage and connecting the power cable at the extension.2)           Plug the extension at the socket 3)           Switch on the socket4)           Switch on the machine ----- Short Circuit happened immediately.Today during the daily meeting was mentioned by offshore team the deluge test performed by client few days ago and probably the machine was wet inside which was not possible to see before to use.    No one was injuried(A1)only material loss,   but the short circuit damage the machine and the scaffolder where it was. Considering the effect at the scaffolder the consequence  in user could be serious and causing an accident with LTI(B3).
ImmediateAction: The Wood employee turned off the socket and remove the cable,  informing the supervisor about the NM.The Supervisor stop the activity and delivered a Time Out for safety, the machine  was put out of service to be inspected onshore.All  employee was informed and was requested to put out of service  all machine that could be in touch with seawater from deluge system.

ShortDescription: The Piling Rig's Lift Wire Frayed during Pile recovery operations.
FullDescription: Update: G. TowellFollowing pursuit of TIP Contractor (Seymour's) - Sub-Contractors & Suppliers, following by a number of Incident Investigation Meetings, the Contractor agreed the Incident Classification Status and Wood's HSE Request to undertaken a Thorough Examination & Inspection following an Equipment Critical Component Change Out & Alteration of Maintenance, by a Trained & Certified Person.The Equipment was inspected and Re-Certification was obtained, Wood HSE Instigated the Investigation and consulted Seymour's QHSE Manager, Technical Authorities, Equipment Suppliers and Subject Matter Experts to undertake and independent review of the Incident Report & Supporting Information, this concluded the following Findings:- The damage to the Lift Wire was caused from bad operational practices from the Piling Crew  - Side Pulling the Lift Line, which had began to snag on a Mast Running Guide, resulting in a defect to the Lift Wire being Sustained (Fraying & Broken Strands), as a contributory factor it was also identified that the Piling Rig Operator made an error, by retracting the Life Wire and defect into the Rigs Spooling Drum, resulting in a Bird Cage, Cross Wraps & Loops being formed.-During the Investigation, previous Industry Incident Information was Obtained from the Supplier-Feedback was provided to the Equipment Supplier & Sub-Contractor Management, Regarding the Design and Substandard Practices. -Corrective Actions Included Safety Stand Down & Lessons Learnt Session with the Whole Involved Team (Reset to Work)-Meetings with Contractor & Sub-Contractor Supervision & Management, to identify Roles / Responsibilities & Expectations. -Constant Tension was Kept & Monitored During the Auger Retraction Process, Auger Sections were Lifted Under the -Control the Excavator within the Picking Up / Vertical Lifting Point, Preventing Side Pulling, RAMS Were Revised to Include the above Mitigating Controls.-Additional Resources were deployed to Monitor the Re-start and Operations were Completed Without further Incident - Potential for Improvement to the Equipment Design (Guide Runners, Wire Protection Sheaves)Initial Incident Information: Foundation Piling - Seymour's Sub-Contractor, were in the process of Concreting Pile 9 within the Northern Cluster (Olefins 6 - Area DA) the Rig's Lift Line had been lowered to detach and remove a section of auger from the retracted Pile. The Lift Line was lowered and engaged with the section of flight auger. During the hoisting of the auger section the lift line was observed to snag and jump, following this, slack line was observed in the Rig's spool winch, which subsequently sustained "bird caging". An All Stop was called by the Seymour's Superintendant and a decision was made to pull out the lift wire in an attempt to remove the "bird cage" and slack line within the rigs spool drum, however during the pulling out of the Lift Wire it was identified that the Lifting Wire had sustained damaged and subsequently suffered fraying, an estimation of 3 - 5 broken strands and crush / cut damage. Seymour's & Foundation Piling made the decision to continue operations to finish the pile, for fear of the auger sections still within the ground becoming stuck or concreted in. The undertook this operation by a multitude of Utilization the Piling Rig to rotate the augers from the ground and the Excavator to detach lift the sections of auger free from the operational area.Following a period of time, the Pile was completed and Wood received a telephone call from Seymour's Project Manager informing them of the incident. Wood HSE Immediately requested a meeting, where a general overview of the Incident was relayed. Wood requested a full investigation and subsequent inspection of the rig and repair to follow. A period of 5 working days lapsed, before Wood was supplied with an Initial Incident Report, which has been attached to this CAIRS Report and upon receipt of the Incident Report Seymour's failed to provide sufficient information to determine the Initial and Root Cause and claimed the classification of the Incident was incorrect and the event was subsequently a breakdown and repair / replacement was classed as maintenance. Wood refused the suggested classification of the Incident. In addition to the above Wood HSE requested the rig to be Rig to be Inspected by a Competent Person to determine the Root Cause and assess for additional defects and damage. Wood HSE also requested the Piling Rig to be repaired with a re-certification inclusive of (Wire Rope Assurance / DC, Load Testing, Thorough Examination and Repair / Inspection Report). Seymour's removed the rig from Site and a Foundation Piling Operative removed and replaced the Lift Wire. Seymour's refused to undertake a Thorough Examination of the Piling Rig and subsequent repairs, to which Wood HSE refused to accept and informed Seymour's of LOLER Regulation 9 & Schedule 1 Requirements. Seymour's again refused to accept this guidance / instruction, so Wood HSE Consulted Wood's Technical Authority for Lifting, whom re-emphasized the same requirements under LOLER. In addition Wood's HSE requested the competency of the Foundation Piling, whom had performed the repair and re-spool of the Lifting Wire, Seymour's are yet to supply this information. Following a prolonged period of request and liaison's Seymour's have agreed to perform a Thorough Examination of the Equipment, however they requested this to be undertake, via the Piling Rig's Hire Company. Wood's HSE requested their competency to perform the thorough Examination, to which certification was supplied (Welding & Plant Mechanic) Wood refused the certification as no reference to Competency, Training or Experience was relating to PUWER & LOLER. Wood's HSE also re-consulted Wood's Technical Lifting Authority, whom verified Wood's HSE Concerns of the proposed Thorough Examiners Competencies. Wood's Technical Authority requested copies of the Examiners (LEEA's Certification). Wood HSE has relayed this request to Seymour's but the information is yet to be provided. Woods' HSE has also advised of Third Party accredited organization, whom can perform the Examination and re-certification requirements. Wood's HSE has refused the Equipment and Operations to be recommenced, until the necessary Examination and Certification is supplied.
ImmediateAction: The Sub-Contractor Supervisor, called an All Stop to the Operation, to inspect the Piling Rig's defect, however the Contractors then continue the Operation,Wood HSE requested a Full Investigation and subsequent Report - Contractor challenging classification and requested action by WoodWood HSE requested full Inspection of the Piling Rig to determine Root Cause, Immediate Cause and Contributory FactorsWood HSE requested Piling Rig re-certification by a Competent Person, prior to re-starting of operation (Wire Rope Assurance, Load Test, Thorough Examination)

ShortDescription: EE was leaving gate 2B after scanning badge didn’t notice gate arm down and proceeded forward bending gate arm forward and breaking it.
FullDescription: EE described incident as follows, "I was driving and there was another company truck in front of me, They had badged out and the arm was up, turned my head to the left to scan badge and looked forward and the gate was down without me seeing it, I didn’t realize it and drove forward and took the gate with me, after I noticed it I waited 5-10 minutes and no one came out so I drove off. I was in truck alone and had no witness to see anything. all this took place at 4:45 pm."  Potential - Minor damage less than $10K, and no greater due to the fact there was no injury or other damage potential.
ImmediateAction: EE is removed from site until further notice, Wood Supervision and HSSES notified of incident by Shintech HSE Manager on 6/3/22 (EE failed to report incident immediately and in a timely fashion). Wood Incident Investigation commenced, Wood Supervision began process of repairing damaged security arm in cooperation and coordination with Shintech HSE Manager.

ShortDescription: A Wood worker entered the RP 1/2 Trailer and closed the door behind themselves and ended up pinching a finger in the process.
FullDescription: The IP was entering a Radiation Protection site trailer which allows a transfer from Zone 1 to Zone 2 as part of the northern access process to radiologically controlled areas. As the IP walked up the trailer stairs, they reached for the door knob using their right hand, opened the door and proceeded to enter the trailer. As they entered the trailer, they reached back behind them, without looking, with the right hand and grabbed hold of the door knob and proceeded to pull the door closed. The worker had a hold of the door knob using their thumb and forefinger. Using this type of grip caused their middle finger to stick out. During the closing of the door, the middle finger got caught between the door and the strike plate located on the door frame, pinching the tip of the finger causing a small laceration. After realizing an injury had occurred, the IP notified their immediate supervisor and received first aid treatment on site by one of the designated first aiders.
ImmediateAction: The wound was cleaned and dressed. Notifications to Wood and client made.

ShortDescription: The rear fender and taillight lens were damage on a Wood truck by a swinging metal gate.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, May 31, 2022 at approximately 10:20am, a Wood lease operator stopped and opened a metal gate near the 4476-28-41 well location.  While the EE was driving Wood unit 273 through the open gate, the wind pushed the gate back into the truck, causing minor damage to the rear corner of the truck. The taillight lens was cracked and the paint on the fender in front of the taillight was scuffed on the driver’s side.  The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: The EE reported the incident to the HSSES Advisor.

ShortDescription: Knee injury whilst climbing under the desk
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: At approx. 0930 on Monday 30 May, the Injured Party (IP) had completed setting up his own desk and assisted a colleague, who was not in the office at the time, by setting up his desk equipment. During that process, it was noted that a computer cable was not plugged into the outlet under the desk, and the IP kneeled down to plug the cable in. As he was getting out from under the desk, the IP felt a twinge and pain in his right knee and immediately noticed that he was not able to straighten his leg fully.
ImmediateAction: The IP continued to work through the day, and as he had another health-related appointment already scheduled for Friday of that week, he booked a consult with his GP for the same afternoon. The GP has referred him for an MRI which has been completed and shows some form of injury – but the specialist advice is pending at this point.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident
