ShortDescription: A Wood employee was operating a mini-excavator equipped w/a hydraulic jackhammer to break concrete, a piece of concrete struck windshield.
FullDescription: On May 31th 2022 at ~9:45 a.m. a Wood excavator operator working at Dow B-205 was tasked with chipping out concrete to locate a water leak using a mini-excavator equipped with a hydraulic jackhammer attachment. About halfway through the chipping the Wood excavator operator noticed a small piece of concrete fly back striking the windshield of the excavator cab causing it to crack and "spider web".  The Wood excavator operator then stopped the equipment and reported it to operations.  Potential - based on damage <$10K, unlikely damage could be >$10K.
ImmediateAction: Wood excavator operator saw small concrete piece hit windshield of cab so he stopped and reported it to Dow operation and Wood supervision to start evaluating the situation. All work immediately stopped and incident reported.

ShortDescription: Preventable, rental vehicle, minor damage, no injury.
FullDescription: While launching the boat at Ironwood Lake the truck and trailer got stuck in the water. When the employee driving the truck opened the door to the vehicle to get out and rig tow straps water entered along the floor of the vehicle. When the employee got back into the truck after rigging the tow straps water entered along the floor a second time. The truck was sucessfully towed out from the lake after 5-10min. Initial assessment of the vehicle identified no damages had occurred. The employee tried to air out the wet carpets and interior of the vehicle but no issues with any internal systems of the vehicle were noticed in the following 4 days of use on the project. No employees were injured during the incident.
ImmediateAction: Employee filed a near miss and HEART observation for the towing. It was not obvious that the water had caused any issues so this was not reported or follwoed up on as an incident until the rental company notified the employee of potential issues with the truck.

ShortDescription: Gas leak in transmitter (01FT182-03A) vent
FullDescription: Gas export compressor K-153A is scheduled for testrun to ensure availability and functionality. Prior tostart-up, pre-checks was conducted. This includesvalve line-up status, RCU of motors, turbine enclosurecheck and etc. During start-up sequence a hissingsound was observed prompting the operators toinvestigate. Upon investigation, gas had been leakingfrom a transmitter vent.
ImmediateAction: Start up of K153A was aborted. The transmitter vent valve wasimmediately closed and tightened eliminating the gas leak, before resuming the start up

ShortDescription: Small cut to forehead and nose

ImmediateAction: Individual went to the locker room to wash the cut area.They then went back to the site and stopped the job before reporting the incident to their supervisor and team.On completion of this they visited the medic to have the injury checked out before returning to normal working duties.

ShortDescription: When removing keeper pins on skidsteer brush attachment IP felt discomfort in shoulder.
FullDescription: IP was removing keeper pins for the stands that keep the power brush attachment off the ground when not in use. At this time IP just wants it reported and will go through the weekend with basic ice, rest and over the counter medication.Actual B1 as IP will rest through the weekend and see if that helps.  Potential B2 as the case may have possibility of being a restricted or medical treatment case.

ShortDescription: A Ford F-250 truck was driven onto soft outer edge of road and got stuck
FullDescription: Employee drove the pickup close to the the area where he was repairing/dismantling silt fence.  He parked on the soft edge of the road and realized he was stuck when 4x4 did not allow him to move.  He then shut the truck off and went to work without notifying anyone.Second Employee was going to move the truck closer to where they needed to load material.  He noticed a back tire was in soft dirt and decided to try to move the truck in 4-wheel drive.  When attempted to move the truck forward the back end slid down the edge towards the creek bottom. He stopped the truck and went to get a radio to call for help.The supervisor was contacted and came to the area where he was informed of the problem. He went to fill out a JSA and get the tools needed to pull the truck out.  The Supervisor called Safety to check with the second employee, who told him about the incident and led him to the area.  While Safety was surveying the scene operations personnel came by and they contacted the Superintendent to assist with getting the truck out.
ImmediateAction: Cable slings were attached to the front tow hooks for the pickup with shackles and then to the rigging points on a forklift. A cable was connected between the rear of the pickup and a skid steer to allow it to act as an anchor to prevent further sliding.  The Superintendent got into the pickup to steer it towards the road while it was being pulled by the forklift.  This was done successfully without any damage or environmental spills occurring.

ShortDescription: Dozer comes in contact with 6" Gas riser
FullDescription: Wood contractor was leveling and prepping site for gravel at WBI Tioga using a dozer. The dozer operator came into contact with a 6" natural gas riser. The riser was protected by a 24"x24"x24"concrete block that was placed in front as well as a cage with warning signs. HSSE was notified called at about 11:45am and went to the site. HSSE ordered personnel to evacuate all personnel and take muster. The client has shut down the site until Tuesday, 5/21 to assess damage. The dozer operator refused to submit to his company's drug and alcohol policy and was terminated. The actual/potential severity of the incident is classified as a B1/B2.
ImmediateAction: All Wood employees were evacated and accountabilty was done, the site was shut down for the rest of the day by Client. (WBI)

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0054 NM Aecon - Utilizing R/T crane to lift rebar cages into place without a proper tag line and barricading.
FullDescription: At Approximately 13:30 on May 24, 2022 in the secondary crusher area, workers were putting in place a rebar pedestal. While craning the pedestal in place it was noticed that several safety infractions were happening at this time. Workers were in close proximity to the over-head load, insufficient barricading was in place, improper tag line in use and an unstable plywood platform was used to walk on between two rebar baskets.
ImmediateAction: Work was intervened on. All safety infractions were addressed. Incident investigation was initiated.

ShortDescription: IP stuck head on air valve and fell to same level ground
FullDescription: At approximately 9:45 AM, on May 24th, a hole watch was passing water to fellow colleagues that were working inside of Boiler Unit 7.  After passing the water bottles to their colleagues, the hole watch stood up and hit their head (with hard hat on) on an air valve that was just outside the opening of the hole.  This resulted in the hole watch breaking the air valve and falling backwards onto the same level ground striking their head on the ground and losing their hard hat.  The actual severity was an A1 as no first aid was provided, only medical evaluation by the first responder and medical facility.  The potential severity identified as a B2 as the injury that the IP sustained to their head, could have resulted in medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: Fellow colleagued radioed for help.  IP was evaluated by first responder, then EMS arrived conducted further evaluation.  IP was then transported to medical facility for further evaluation.  No treatment was provided, was a medical evaluation only.  IP was released to return to work without restrictions. Follow up with physician was recommended on 05/31/2022.

ShortDescription: Improper use of continuous slings for unloading rolls of liner from box trailer
FullDescription: The Bayer construction manager had instructed SBI employees to "choke" two slings together to get a longer strap length to pull liner rolls from the back half of the box trailer.  This resulted in a knot being created, which would make a weak spot when the strap was put into use.
ImmediateAction: There were shackles available and these were utilized to connect the straps correctly

ShortDescription: Wood employee was exposed to an experimental polyol chemical (XSD 499.02) while removing an instrument fitting from a valve.
FullDescription: A 2 person Wood I&E crew was tasked with removing an instrument in the B4600 block at FE-2208. During the process of removing the instrument an experimental polyol gel (XSD 499.02) dripped onto Wood EE1 pant leg.  Dow TXO B4600 Operations was immediately notified and Wood EE1 placed himself in a Safety Shower within 5 -7 feet from this equipment. ES&S were notified. Wood Supervision and Safety were notified. A walk thru was conducted with Wood and Dow Safety.  Dow Safety took photos and will email to Wood.  Wood EE1 was taken to Pro Active for evaluation by ES&S.  Wood EE1 was accompanied to Pro Active by Wood HSSE Coordinator.  Potential - employee stopped work and followed procedures, no health effects.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped, Wood EE1 immediately doffed work clothing and entered the closest safety shower while Wood EE2 notified Operations. Wood EE1 was evaluated by Dow TXO ES&S and taken to Pro Active for evaluation by Occ Med provide. Wood EE1 was evaluated and released to full duty with no restrictions, no treatment administered by Occ Med provider, precautionary evaluation only.  Dow TXO SWP was closed out by Wood EE2.
OtherHazardSource: polyol (not classified as a hazardous substance)

Actual (B1): First aid measures recommended to IP by Axiom; Potential (B1): Not expected to go beyond a first aid.
ImmediateAction: Axiom was contacted and advised IP to apply first aid measures to the injured area.

ShortDescription: While climbing the scaffolding a WGS boilermaker lost his balance and fell from a height of one meter.
FullDescription: assigned to the Fertial Annaba port facilities level had an incident related to scaffolding fall from a height of approximately 01 metter (according to the statement of the IP), The IP came down to drink while returning to the scaffolding platform while climbing the ladder he lost his balance fell on his back.
ImmediateAction: the IP was immediately evacuated to the IBN ROCHD hospital to have the clinical diagnosis of his condition, after consultation (Head ,shoulder,back X-Ray) , the doctor confirmed the absence of an injury or fracture needing work off or medical treatment , but IP declared to the hospital doctor that he has an old injury at the lumbar level and following his declaration, the doctor advised him to do an external follow-up and he issued him with a work stoppage of 04 days do do further medical back old injury examination .Investigation was launched and visit to incident area was conducted by one of our HSE supervisor .

ShortDescription: Fan cover was heavily corroded and gave way resulting in Wood employee finger brushing fan
FullDescription: While erecting scaffold in the Fresh water pump area on WTN. Scaffolder placed hand on the side of the fan motor cover as he repositioned himself. Part of the fan cover was heavily corroded and gave way resulting in the employee finger brushing the fan.
ImmediateAction: Wood team immediately reported to operations, area was barricaded while repairs are carried out. Further information from Esso to follow.

ShortDescription: Non injurious incident - Individual was struck on the face by a small nut and washer
FullDescription: When taking boards off a scaffold that was being dismantled, I was struck in the face by a small nut and a washer that had been left behind from whoever was using the scaffold. No injury was sustained so the individual recorded this in the observation card system initially where it has been managed and followed up from.
ImmediateAction: Individual raised an observation card highlighting the importance of housekeeping and keeping worksites free of PDO

ShortDescription: IP stood up, rock under feet shifted, left foot turned, knee no longer straight, not weight bearing without sharp pain.
FullDescription: IP was conducting surveys for bat habitat at the base of a cliff in the Kirkland Lake area between Beaverhouse Lake and Gem Lake. IP's co-worker was 50-100m from IP. Both workers were wearing all required personal protection equipment. IP did not know that the rock under feet was unstable. IP knelt down to examine an opening in the cliff face and as stood back up, the rock under feet shifted and left foot turned so that knee was no longer straight. IP felt a sudden pain in knee and could no longer bend  leg or put weight on it without experience a sharp pain. IP's co-worker then assisted to the helicopter which was 100m from where they were. Once at the Kirland Lake airport, IP's co-worker drove to the hospital. X-rays were taken at the hospital and it was determined that the knee was not broken, but there may still be soft tissue dammage. The doctor advised IP to have an MRI taken upon returning home and that IP see family physician.
ImmediateAction: IP taken to hospital, WorkCare contacted, internal reporting initiated.

ShortDescription: Driver drove pass the vehicle barrier without ensuring the barrier has raised for vehicle access
FullDescription: Driver was mobilizing scaffold materials through security barrier access gate. Upon tapping his card key badge at security turnstile, he immediately drove pass the entrance barrier without ensuring the barrier has raised for vehicle access. Lorry bumper came in contact with the barrier causing damage to it.
ImmediateAction: Stopped work. D&A test was carried out, results were negative

ShortDescription: IP assigned to project was diagnosed of Malaria for the second time this year. IP felt chills and went to the ISOS clinic to get tested.
FullDescription: IP was working on a ceiling on a hot day and felt ill at around 4:45pm. IP went to the clinic to get checked and was diagnosed of Malaria. This is the 2nd time IP contracted Malaria this year. IP takes doxycycline every day. IP added that all symptoms are milder, and no fever was recorded. Onsite clinic provided IP with medication and vitamins. IP continues to monitor symptoms and temperature. IP will visit the ISOS clinic tomorrow for a follow up. ISOS reported the incident 23 May, but IP was seen and diagnosed 20 May. IP was given fit to work certificate today 24 May 2022.
ImmediateAction: PM called to check on the condition of IP upon getting the notification from onsite clinic. IP is in good spirit and has no significant symptoms. IP was given medication and vitamins and will be checked tomorrow for follow up.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0053 PD Wood; Minor electrical fire from outlet.

ImmediateAction: Site ERT dispatched and extinguished fire. All camp residents gathered at Muster until all clear was called at approximately 21:00 p.m.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: WGS operator exposure to drops of acid to his face and eyes after heated acid did expand when cell battery opened by client operative
FullDescription: WGS instrument operator exposure to drops of acid to his face and eyes after heated acid did expand when cell battery opened by another client GTG instrument operator. As part of the inspections of the instruments  wells located outside CPF area, two instrumentists (GTG and WGS) brought with them an 800 Ampere battery to operate the instruments wells to collect the data, the day of the incident the battery was taken to the service vehicle at the level of the well to operate the instrument after collecting the data on returning to the site, they stored the battery at the level of the store, client instrumentist operator wanted to check the level of acid in the battery, by opening one battery cell, heated acid did expand when cell battery opened touching two operators in their faces and eyes.
ImmediateAction: The two IP's were evacuated to the Adrar hospital where they received first aid (eye wash and eye drops prescriptions) after a medical observation at the hospital the same day their admission was not necessary, and their case does not require a work stoppage, the two IPs were authorized by the medical staff of the hospital to join their workstations the same day at 08:00 Pm
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

Upon leaving the fuel point the trailer 27.20.9981 struck the buddy fuel pump with the passenger side of the trailer.Unknown damage cost to the pump at this time. ShortDescription: A Wood employee hit an antelope on his morning commute to the work site causing damage to a Wood truck.
FullDescription: On Thursday, May 19, 2022, at approximately 05:30, before sunrise, the Wood employee was commuting to his work site at the North Shore Energy Painter Plant. As he was driving unit #13119 on the Painter road, an antelope ran out from borrow ditch and onto the roadway in front of the Wood truck.  The EE did not have time to stop or slow down and hit the animal with the front of the truck.  The vehicle grill was damaged.  The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: The EE reported the incident to the HSSES Advisor.

ShortDescription: IP presented with a 3 day history of right knee swelling and inflammation which he self treated
FullDescription: IP presented with a 3 day history of right knee swelling and inflammation which he self treated with non-prescription medication. IP has no recollection of any precipitating or contributing occupational event or injury that may have led to current condition.  This is classified as a NWR Medical Treatment Case as prescription medication for treatment (B2) with a potential if left untreated or not following medical advice to progress to a Restricted Work Case (B2)
ImmediateAction: On call physician consulted continue with non-prescription medication at non-prescription dosage for pain, will require prescription medication for treatment. Apply ice or heat and work limitations. Demob on May 24th assessed by onshore Physician (AOMS) who noted that this worker has been managed for an injury / illness which is not reported to be work related by the worker.

ShortDescription: Foreman was attempting to move a plate compactor inside the conex and smashed his finger between the compactor and the conex wall
FullDescription: At approximately 11:15am on Thursday 5/19/2021 The foreman was assisting another co-worker to get a pump out of the conex. In doing so he had to move a plate compactor over to the side to allow room for the other person to remove the pump. As he slid the compactor over and released it he smashed his right ring finger between the compactor and the wall.
ImmediateAction: Foreman contacted Safety for direction. Safety proceeded to site to assess injury, take witness statements and photos. Safety contacted Occucare for first-aid direction and it was determined that stitches were not required. Wound was cleaned, bandaged and wrapped.

ShortDescription: Mud buggy teetered in to a vertical position.
FullDescription: May 19th at approximately 9:00AM an employee was tasked with removing mud from Basin 35 with a Mud Buggy.  As the operator was exiting the basin it traversed an incline.  As the equipment went down the incline the weight of the mud caused it to slowly teeter forward until the tub made contact with the ground. The operator held on to equipment until it came to a stop. Then was helped down by co-workers.  The actual severity rating is listed as B1 because one person was involved but no injury or asset damage occurred.  The potential severity rating is a B2 because if the operator jumped off the equipment as it teetered there is the possibility of incurring a significant injury and a first aid.
ImmediateAction: Operator was helped down by co-workers and the scene was froze.  Foreman contacted the GF and Site Manager.  Safety was notified and investigation protocols were initiated.

ShortDescription: EE was installing a 3 inch hose into a cam lock. When closing an ear of the lock, then EE felt sudden pain in the neck that radiated.
FullDescription: EE was installing a 3 inch hose into a cam lock. When closing an ear of the lock, then EE felt sudden pain in the neck that radiated.
ImmediateAction: Stopped work, contacted WorkCare. WorkCare suggested self-directed first aid and monitoring. EE returned to work for the next scheduled shift.

ShortDescription: An employee leaving the SP building via the automatic doors in the underground car park, higher level, Core H, I was nearly run over.
FullDescription: An employee leaving the SP building via the automatic doors in the underground car park, higher level, Core H, I was nearly run over. The car was parked immediately on the right hand side (as one is coming out of the door into the car park) of the exit.  The car was obscured from view by the wall. Although its engine was running, there were other cars moving around in the car park and it was not easy to distinguish the noise. They became aware of the car because of the light from the car’s headlights shining across my path before they sighted the car. Therefore, they was cautious. However, the car immediately crossed the path and through the red area with yellow hatching. The driver did not seem to be aware that a person was there and continued to drive out of the car park.
ImmediateAction: Adding cones to the area to act as a visual safety barrier and also in similar areas around the car park.

ShortDescription: Broken glass on subcontractor fork lift telehandler equipment, no injuries
FullDescription: Driller was moving equipment and supplies when the wind blew the side access door open and it slammed against the  back of the telehandler frame. The glass shattered. There was no one in the line of fire and no one was injured.
ImmediateAction: Client was notified, incident investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: Non preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury.

ShortDescription: Sub drilled ~4ft when gear oil began spraying from head. Drain plug for top head vibrated out.
FullDescription: Driller began drilling, He drilled approximately 4 feet when gear oil began spraying from the top head. The rig geologist notified the Wood Site Safety Officer. The driller tripped two rods in order to lower the top head to the rig break out table. The driller discovered that the drain plug for the top head had vibrated out. Approx. 3 gallons of gear oil had released.
ImmediateAction: Cleint notified, contaminated material was cleaned up.

ShortDescription: IP was exposed to bear spray (0.98% Capsaicin – Pepper spray) while loading equipment into work truck.

ShortDescription: Client (Chevron) was approached by a man on the west side of the parking garage near the Thoroughbred building when was arriving
FullDescription: On Wednesday morning a Wood's  client ( Chevron)  was approached in its car by a man on the  west  side of the parking garage near  the Thoroughbred building. The man  banged on the window of the car, apparently asking for  something or wanting to roll the window down  to talk  with the client. Client waved him off and  the man backed away a few feet from the door. Once the man  was clear. Client drove around to park in another spot further east. Client was  understandably a bit shaken up, and did report this incident to the security guard sitting at the front desk immediately.
ImmediateAction: Project Manager contacted the HSSE team and reported the situation. HSSE contacted facilities team to inform about  the incident and recorded the case into CAIRS. Facilities Team is reevaluating the security protocols to mitigate the potential risks.

FullDescription: An employee who was working from home tested positive for COVID-19.

ShortDescription: one of 2 man crew  left site to accept a delivery- resulting in one man lone working for a short period of time.
FullDescription: Compartment Fire Ltd had a 2 man crew working on the Bustleholm-Nechells project at bridge 3, installing steel channels on to the bridge to fit the flame resistant paneling. Whilst undertaking this work, one of the team needed to go to the Bustleholm main yard to accept a delivery. during this period of time, the one person left on site wrongly decided to carry on fitting a channel piece by himself -which required two holes to be drilled and the channel screwed on to the side of the bridge. The National Grid project Engineer passed by the cable bridge at this time and proceeded to the main yard where she challenged the other operative accepting the delivery and asked him to call the person at bridge 3 and asked them to stop him with immediate effect.
ImmediateAction: Working party were immediately stopped from working. the National Grid engineer has placed the incident in to their IMS system as a low level incident. NG contacted Wood Senior Project manager to inform him of the incident and explained it will be input to their IMS system. Incident location has been visited by the Wood HSSE advisor in order to take statements and gather information as to what has happened/what is the task and to assess if any immediate improvements can be undertaken or suggested for the task -initiate the investigation.

There are no Wood personnel in the chain of contact.
ImmediateAction: The infected Wood staff notifies their discipline leader and HSSE leader, according to procedure, the infected staff is treated by a health specialist, He is isolated in quarantine at home, there is no chain of contact, the staff work at home, due pandemic situation.

ShortDescription: IP received first aid treatment for an insect bite.
FullDescription: An employee (IP) received first aid treatment for an insect bite to the face. IP states that while pulling the crew's tool wagon, they saw and felt an insect on their nose bridge. IP reacted by pulling off their safety glasses and attempting to swat the insect. Moments later IP felt and saw a second raised area on their cheek. IP is unable to confirm what type of insect it was. The Actual Severity is B1 indicating first aid treatment was administered. The Potential Severity is also B1.
ImmediateAction: The employee immediately stopped work and notified their supervisor. HSSE was called and the IP received first aid.

ShortDescription: A New Zealand Defence Force Staff member suffered a personal medical event whilst undertaking training
IncidentAssignedTo: Visitor (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: During a New Zealand Defence Force Ground hire, whilst undertaking a work exercise using Breathing Apparatus, one of the wearers suffered a personal medical event at the finish of the rotation. He exited the Realistic Fire Training Building (RFTB) at the near completion of the drill, and fell to his knees removing his mask and PPE. Wood safety watch staff and NZDF personnel went to his immediate aid and the main concern was his difficulty to breathe. Immediate first aid was administered by NZDF and Wood staff, and the individual's senior contacted his commanders and the call was made to transfer him to hospital. After various tests at hospital he was released, and advised to consult his personal doctor for further tests.
ImmediateAction: On-site First Aid provided and transport arranged to take him to hospital for further tests

ShortDescription: IP received a laceration on his hands.
FullDescription: On May 18, 2022 at 8:40 am, a Wood IP was observing two other employees pull a brush pig off a shelf at the Plains Oil CDP in Carlsbad, NM when it fell off and bounced on the ground. The IP attempted to avoid contact with the brush pig; however, when it bounced on the ground the brush pig struck his hands. As a result, the IP received laceration to both of his hands. First aid measures were applied to the injured area. Actual (B1): First aid measures applied to the injured area; Potential (B1): Not expected to go beyond a first aid.
ImmediateAction: First aid measures applied to the injured area.

ShortDescription: Excavator windshield was broken while smashing the pallets inside dumpster
FullDescription: On Wednesday May 18th, 2022, around 0830, crew was task to smash the pallets inside the dumpster to create and increase space. During this operation, the operator was using the boom and excavator bucket to reach inside the dumpster. While the operator was smashing the pallets a piece of wood hit the windshield. The contact caused front tempered glass to break. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor (less than 10K) and spotter was in a safe distance behind the exclusion area.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the incident were gathered. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: A Babcock subcontractor (Masedi E&I) was found doing cable pulling, termination and glanding on a DB without the necessary documentation
FullDescription: During his normal site rounds, the Wood construction manager observed a team of personnel from Masedi E&I a subcontractor to Babcock working on a construction power distribution board. Upon approaching the team and engaging with them he discovered that they required daily checks and documentation to perform the work was not completed by the supervisor or discussed with the team. The work was stopped and the management of the Masedi E&I was instructed to come to the site. The Wood HSSE advisor and HSSE Manager also attended the site. The distribution board was previously isolated and locked out by the client's electrical department to allow for the installation of the cabling needed to supply the site offices for the project, so no potential for electrical energy was present in the DB at the time of the event, however, the deviation from the procedure was considered as a near miss in order to ensure that the same type of event is not repeated under different circumstances and the rules for Preparing for all work even if it is not within an operational area are always maintained.
ImmediateAction: The Masedi team was stood down for the day, with commitment from the operations manager that he would personally ensure that the learnings for the event are entrenched within the team.The Masedi team with their supervisor were tasked with ensuring that all the documentation needed to perform the work are completed and approved by the Wood construction manager before work would be allowed to continueMasedi operational manager committed to conducting an internal investigation and presenting their findings to Wood for reviewBabcock management was informed that they needed to take primary responsibility to ensure that all critical activities and tasks related to key undesirable events are checked daily and 100% assurance on critical tasks can be givenThe event was loaded onto the Wood CAIRS SystemAn immediate stand down was held at the site with the Masedi team by the HSSE manager for Wood and the construction manager for Wood and the importance of applying the rules for all work even in the laydown areas stressed again with the teamThe event was not loaded as a high potential event due to the DB being isolated and locked out pre-taskAll tasks involving critical activities and potential life-saving rule applications will be controlled and assurance will given irrespective of where it is being done

ShortDescription: No personal injury; No vehicle damage: When initiating a 3-point turn in an Ampol utility, the front drivers side wheel slipped into drain
FullDescription: On the 18th of May at approximately 07:50am a WOOD mechanical crew person was returning from the stores to the waste-water treatment plant, on Jetty Road, South-East end.  The driver was attempting to carry out a 3-point turn. He moved the vehicle to the long grass area near the entrance to the waste-water treatment plant.The driver braked about one foot into the grass.As he put the car into reverse and eased his foot off the clutch to reverse, the vehicle slipped forward into the ditch. He felt the rear wheels raise up and so engaged the handbrake and left the vehicle in gear. He got out of the ute safely incurring no injury.The mechanical fitter came down from the Water Treatment Plant platform to see if his colleague was ok. He had witnessed the whole event. They had not radioed the event as within about two minutes, two emergency response personnel had pulled up on their way to another location. They called up Ampol Safety Specialist and organized to have the vehicle pulled out by site emergency services.Two Movement Operators were driving past. They stopped and chatted to both WOOD personnel to see if they were ok.It is noted in witness statements taken from WOOD personnel that one of the Movement Operators commented that the area near the culvert was quite narrow and should be barricaded.Emergency response used 4WD and snatch-strap to safely pull out the Ampol ute. The vehicle was checked for damage. No damage was noted.
ImmediateAction: It was agreed the WOOD HSE Lead would take down both Witness Statements on WOOD format and upload to Cintellate and CAIRS. She then escorted both WOOD personnel to the Security Gate so the driver of the vehicle could undergo both D&A routine testing. At no time was the driver of the vehicle involved in the event alone and did not consume any food of liquid.The third-party tester informed the WOOD HSE Lead that the D&A result was satisfactory (negative) and would be reported Ampol as per protocol.After the D&A test, the WOOD HSE lead recorded the Witness Statements on WOOD stationery. The Ampol Senior Safety Specialist emailed the WOOD HSE Lead photos of the ute in the ditch x 4.In the meantime, The Ampol Safety Specialist carried out an investigation into the root cause of the event and noted bollards highlighting similar conditions. the hazard where the event occurred had no controls in place and no warning of soft edge.The Ampol Safety Specialist reported the roadside hazard (long grass concealing soft edges on the side of the drain and culvert at the entrance to the waste-water treatment plant). He noted it was in close proximately to a man-box posing further risk to any mobile plant which may be used to move the man-box later. He informed the WOOD Crane Coordinator about the hazard. He contacted the Ampol Movement group and he organized a fence to be placed at the site of the soft edges and long grass near the culvert see photo 006.

ShortDescription: First Aid case -  IP got burns on his right hand.
FullDescription: We were installing spades at all six burners on the fuel oil and steam lines. One of the burners were complete and we were starting on the second of six. Operative released the flange and installed the spade and was in the process of tightening the joint when a shot of  steam or hot water came out and struck the back of his hand. He took his glove off and went to the toilets to rinse under a cold tap. Informed ops about the release nothing at the time was found.The operative continued to work but later during the shift he was feeling slight pain on the back of his hand. He went to the Equinor first aid and received gel on the back of his hand and painkillers. He then returned to work. On checking in with the operative our supervisor made the decision to send him home for the rest of his shift.
ImmediateAction: IP rinsed hand with cold water. Got to Medic, and got GEL on his hand. Sent home for the rest of his shift.  Client notified, case entered in Equinor reporting system, "Synergi". Site inspection Wood and Equinor, identified the actual line we were working on. Equinor will investigate why this line was filled with hot water/steam.  Wood will make this a topic in TBT,  we will not open steam lines until further notice.

ShortDescription: IP twinge he felt down his Left leg while attempting to bend over cleaning up his work front
FullDescription: IP went to bend over to pick up a scaffold clip when he felt a slight twinge in his lower back which shot pain down his left leg to his achiles.IP identified the sensation as like an electric current running down his leg.
ImmediateAction: Post incident IPs stated the sensation dissipated almost immediately, although on the way up from the plant to report he did get a few other Twinges of the same feeling.  Again down his left leg.

ShortDescription: A survey employee leaned a GPS Rover and rod against the truck ending in it sliding to the side and contacting the ground breaking the scree
FullDescription: The survey employee was leaning the rod and GPS rover against the field pickup.  The weight of the GPS rover is on the top of the rod, which caused the rover and rod to slide sideways along the pickup.  The GPS Rover contacted the ground resulting in damage to the screen.
ImmediateAction: It was reported to supervision and safety.

ShortDescription: EE1 sustained a hand injury when struck by hammer being used on a hammer wrench.
FullDescription: EE1 and EE2 were tasked with installing a 10inch 600lb slip blind. Blinding was being done in support of a boiler entry. The top two bolts on the flange are in a difficult and restrictive position. The workers determined the best available tool for this situation would be a 2inch hammer wrench. The wrench was fitted onto the nut and EE1 states he was holding it with a tool holder. EE2 began swinging the hammer at the wrench. On the third swing EE1 states he was struck in the thumb by the hammer. He felt some numbness and tingling in the thumb. He reported this to EE2 and then his foreman. The situation was reported to client supervision, WOOD Safety, and WOOD Supervision. EE1 was taken for medical treatment at offsite facility.  Potential - employee received first aid, potential for medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: Employee contacted Wood Foreman and Wood HSSE and FPC/PIC FPC/HSP.

ImmediateAction: Reported it to senior management and secured the glass with tape to prevent it from breaking more until replaced.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee caused minor damage to their front driver side panel wile reversing.
FullDescription: On Monday, May 16, 2022, at approximately 20:30, an operator was tasked with restarting heaters inside a fuel building.  While attempting to maneuverer truck to the front of the building to hook up the cables the EE needed to reverse to reposition.  As he was reversing, and he hooked a metal guardrail with the front driver side grill guard. This pulled the truck into the metal guard damaging the front driver side panel.  The EE was able to pull forward and no other damage was sustained. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Contacted HSE & Supervisor

ShortDescription: IP Sustained a bite/sting on left forearm from unknown insect

IP felt itch so he started to scratch his forearm noticing a welt, the insect was un-identified. The actual severity rating is B1 as the employee received first aid. The potential severity rating is B2 as IP has no insect allergies from previous encounters with bite/sting, but medical treatment could have been a possibility.
ImmediateAction: IP was evaluated by onsite medic; first aid treatment was provided (sting relief swab) and was released to return to work. JSA was closed and a new one issued. Investigation is on process.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee hit a deer on his morning commute causing minor damage.
FullDescription: On Monday, May 16, 2022, at approximately 0530, The Wood employee was on his commute to work. Driving northbound on highway 87 a deer run into the back driver side of the truck hitting the taillight and rear bumper. The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: Pulled over then called HSE and supervisor.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee hit a deer on his morning commute to the work site causing damage to the Wood truck.
FullDescription: On Monday, May 16, 2022, at approximately 05:15, before sunrise, the Wood employee was commuting to his work site. As he was driving unit #14193 at 45 mph on Chalk Creek road, seven miles east of Coalville, Utah, a deer ran out from behind a guard rail and onto the roadway in front of the Wood truck.  The EE did not have enough time to stop and hit the deer.  The vehicle grill, headlight assembly, front bumper and fender were damaged.  The Actual Severity is A1 because the damage caused to the truck is less than $10,000. The Potential Severity is A1 because it is unlikely that the damage caused to the truck is more than $10,000.
ImmediateAction: The EE contacted his Supervisor and HSSES Advisor.

ShortDescription: IP fell from beam while moving in work area
FullDescription: IP (involved person) was going down from the C24 Mezzanine to start grinding a structure in connection with a welding job. IP went on some beams / pipes to get further down to where the job should start. The area was cramped and IP had to go with bent knees due to tarpaulin and low roof, among other things. To get further down to the workplace, IP used a stepladder that stood supportively up to a pipe. As the IP steps on the stepladder (which was not correctly set up and secured according to requirements), the ladder slip and the IP falls between the structure down to the level below (1,5m down). IP lands and hits the cable gate with the back head. A colleague arrived and they immediately go to the nurse for a check-up. A small cut in the back of the head was cleaned. IP was back to work the same day.
ImmediateAction: - IP stopped the job and secured the workplace.- IP consulted a nurse for a check. A small cut in the back of the head was cleaned. - The incident was reviewed with the person / persons involved to uncover causes, measures, and learning.- The incident was reviewed with mobilized personnel and informed to operations / platform management. Comment: Experience sharing when using a ladder / stepladder; comply with requirement R-19085. Made known in the various departments, HSE meeting across shifts. Mentioned in «Daily newspaper».

ShortDescription: the worker receives a blow to the right hand due to handling 16mm rods

FullDescription: An employee received first aid treatment for ant bites to the right hand. The incident occurred when the IP used their gloved hand to clear dirt while installing silt fence. While removing dirt, ants crawled into their glove, upon feeling the bites, the IP stopped work and removed their gloves and saw ants on the hand. But, upon returning to their truck they noticed that the second tester had left the Travel Container open as there was a chance for rain, employee closed the travel container for the second tester. Having closed the travel container, employee missed putting their device away, leaving it on the passenger side of the vehicle. The Employee then left that location to perform density testing at another location on the site. The contractor working nearby immediatley notified the second tester who was in proximity of the device and took possesion of the densometer. The second tester then called the Employee who promplty returned to that site and reaquired the device.
ImmediateAction: The contractor notified the other tester on site who immediately took possesion of the nuclear densometer.

ShortDescription: IP applied sunscreen borrowed from another employee and had a reaction.
FullDescription: IP borrowed sunscreen and applied the sunscreen only to his face. IP went back to work, and co workers noticed IP’s face was red, inflamed, and was experiencing a rash.
ImmediateAction: IP proceeded to wash hands and face with soap and water. It was suggested IP further treat the reaction and to follow up with Work Care. IP went to sit in truck and took an oral antihistamine (Benadryl), and applied ice to face. He called Work Care at 2:00pm, maintaining the ice on face. IP also took a picture of face at this time to document the incident. Face symptoms abated during time in the truck. IP was on the phone until 3:15pm with Work Care. During conversation with the nurse and doctor, they suggested that if the rash had gone, then it would be okay to return to work, that IP should limit sun exposure, and continue to take antihistamines.

ShortDescription: Laceration to left thumb
FullDescription: The IP was using a pair of scissors to remove zip ties from Bird Nesting signs which were being removed as nesting geese were no longer present.  While attempting to cut through a zip tie, the scissors released suddenly forwards and resulted in contact with their left thumb, resulting in a laceration. The IP’s left hand was being used to hold the sign and the scissors were in the right hand. The worker was not wearing gloves at the time, but they were available.  Immediately after the incident the IP reported to the PHSO. The cut was rinsed with clean water and dressed. WorkCare, Wood’s third party incident management contractor was contacted. Based on photos supplied to WorkCare, the consulting physician recommended that the IP attend a medical facility to have the laceration evaluated.The IP was taken to local hospital for assessment and three stitches were applied to close the wound.  The IP was also provided with a preventative tetanus shot.  The worker was back to site and has no restrictions to their work.
ImmediateAction: The IP was taken to local emergency department on advice from WorkCare.  The IP was later supplied with proper tool for the task and a discussion around the use of hand protection, which was available but not used.

ShortDescription: Operative received a Foreign Body in their Right Eye, during a Scaffolding Erection Operation.
FullDescription: An Operative was assisting in the Erection of a Scaffolding Access Platform, During the hoisting of a Ladder to an elevated position, the Ladder has collided with the Scaffold and as a result some small debris has become dislodged and fell to grade. As the IP was looking up at the time, the Debris has fell onto the Operatives face and the wind has blew the debris into the Operatives Right Eye (09:30). (NOTE) The Operative was wearing Light Eye Protection (LEP) at the time of the event. The IP immediately stopped work and reported to the Sabic Site Control Room, The IP Reported the Incident to the Control Room and Kaefer Supervision. The Sabic Control Room, contacted the Site Emergency Contractor (Falck) (09:35) Falck were attending to an alternative Incident onsite, with a greater severity, the Kaefer IP was asked to wait in the Control Room for First Aid Treatment. Due to waiting for the Site Emergency Contractor, the Operative has obtained an Eye Wash Bottle, that was available in the Control Room and self irrigated their eye, to which the Operative has reported a Foreign Body was removed. (09:45). At around (10:30) The Site Emergency Contractor attended the Control Room and Inspected the Operatives Eye, to which they could not identify any Foreign Bodies and deemed the Operative Fit, to Return to Work.
ImmediateAction: The Operative Stopped Work and Reported to the Sabic Site Control Room on Olefins 6 - The IP Self Irrigated their Eye and was Assessed by the Site Emergency Contractor (Falck).

ShortDescription: Delivering Trackway, the delivery wagon has come off the lane and is in a  position requiring a recovery-loaded with trackway panels.
FullDescription: A subcontractors Trackway delivery wagon was travelling along the access from tower AE27 on route to tower AE29 to lay panels for Wood. The vehicle has managed to come off the lane on site and has resulted in the vehicle being in a position, requiring recovery . No one was hurt as part of this incident -any asset damage to the subcontractors wagon is unknown at this time - no environmental damage known at the moment although on both accounts this will be the subcontractors responsibility and not Wood.
ImmediateAction: The 2 man crew stayed in their vehicle and contacted their own company - one of the Wood supervisors came upon the incident by chance ,and the Wood supervisor informed the Wood Construction manager who was at tower AE18. The wood Construction manager told the 2 man crew to disembark from the wagon and to keep a safe distance from the wagon. The wood Construction manager informed the Trackway crew to arrange a professional recovery company to attend site -assess the situation and with our approval undertake recovery of the wagon. No one is hurt as part of the incident and environmental damage is expected to be low-nothing. The project is keeping all personnel away from the incident area and awaiting the professional recovery personnel to site. Client informed by Wood Construction manager. Wood have enacted the "for cause" D&A test for the 2-man team. The D&A result is negative and statements have been taken from the crew members. The Subcontractor Live Trackway have been asked to undertake an investigation.

ShortDescription: Stuck accelerator on Truck 928
FullDescription: Wood employee was driving truck #928 and Wood employee (witness) was riding as a passenger. The driver was traveling approximately 67 miles per hour in the far-left lane and began to merge into the carpool lane. After merging in the carpool lane, the driver let her foot off the gas pedal and found the accelerator "punched down on its own and would not release." Truck #928 continued to accelerate, reaching approximately 90+ miles per hour. Attempting to slow the vehicle down, the driver applied the brake and kept her foot on the brake peddle. The driver immediately informed the passenger the accelerator was stuck. The passenger reached over and attempted to pull the accelerator peddle up. The accelerator peddle fell back into place and the vehicle would not slow down. The driver then turned the vehicle hazard lights on and began to merge back to the right in order to try and safely exit the highway. The driver reports having to use both feet on the brake in an effort to slow the vehicle down. She reported the brakes did not seem responsive, feeling as though they were going to give out. In the mean time, the passenger did a quick google search and informed the driver to put the vehicle in neutral. The driver put the vehicle in neutral and continued to keep both feet on the brakes as she merged across five lanes of traffic. The driver reports the brakes for truck #928 felt like they were slowly giving out and the engine was still revving at high rpm. However the vehicle did slowly decrease speed. The driver exited the highway at Manchester Avenue, turned right and looked for a safe spot to pull over.  The driver parked the truck at the intersection of Manchester Avenue and Ocean Cove Drive. The driver reports she had her feet on the brakes at all times. The vehicle was placed in park, the ignition turned off, and the emergency brake engaged.
ImmediateAction: Internal notification

ShortDescription: Non preventable, rental vehicle, medium damage, no injury.
FullDescription: EE was driving a rental vehicle from Salt Lake City, UT to Rock Springs, WY when some concrete bricks fell off of the bed of a tractor/trailer (flatbed) vehicle.  Rental vehicle ran over the bricks causing damage to the rim and flattened both tires on the driver’s side.  Two other vehicles also ran over the concrete bricks.  Driver of the flat bed stopped.
ImmediateAction: Wood employee helped driver of flat bed remove concrete from the road.  The state police showed up, asked questions, had all the drivers write statements and wrote a police report. The state trooper also gave a ticket to the flat bed driver for not securing the load.

ShortDescription: Other contractor was moving excavator underneath an overhead power line, power line arced, no injuries, minor damage.
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: At aproximatly 7:30 pm (end of shift), operator was smoothing ground with a PC 490 excavator back to staging area.  Operator thought he was clear of OH line and swung boom of excavator too close to the 14,000 volt OH line causing an arc from the OH line to the excavator.  After the arc occurred the operator grounded bucket of machine and tracked away from the line and shut machine down.  Operator indicated that he knew the line was there but misjudged the distance to the line when he swung the bucket.  Operator was evaluated for health concerns, none reported.  Operator left site with remiander of crew. Utility was contacted (Consumers Energy).  Consumers Energy came to site.  It was determined that the weather cover of the OH line was damaged but not presenting a safety hazard.  OH line needed repair to the weatherproofing and sheething.  Line itself (conductor) was undammaged.
ImmediateAction: Machine moved away from line and grounded.  Employee evaluated for injuries, utility contacted.
OtherIncidentAssignedTo: Other Contractor, not sub to Wood.

ShortDescription: IP experienced what is suspected to be a absence seizure
FullDescription: While in conversation with another Hexagon / Wood employee the IP experienced what is suspected to be an absence seizure, the IP became distant and non responsive.
ImmediateAction: 1.  The medic took the IP to the clinic and performed a medical check.2.	After the evaluation, the Medic informed the Production Supervisor and the OIM.3.	All agreed to the following immediate actions:a.	To have somebody with the IP during the night shift.b.	To take the daily the medicine in front of the doctor.c.	To change the IP to day shifts for the rest of the rotation so they can be around people / not alone.d.	OIM also requested to have a medical check when the IP goes for vacation and get a fit to work report.4.	A conversation with the IP at the clinic where they agreed to follow the above actions. The IP also mentioned that what was described above they experienced a similar behavior around 1 year ago when the IP  was having a discussion with their father about a personal matter.The IP has conducted multiple evaluations, however, no final report issued stating that the IP is fit to return to normal duties.19 September 2022:  The PM has requested medical reports from the IP on a regular basis but to no avail.5 October 2022: Medical report submitted to Client Doctor for evaluation.*NOTE: No person may work offshore if they have experienced any form of seizure within the last 6 months.

ShortDescription: Employee found working on yellow tag scaffold without fall arrest lanyards attached to anchor point.
FullDescription: On Tuesday, May 10 of 2022, a boiler maintenance crew was working inside the Unit 1 Air Heater. To reach the work, a yellow-tag scaffold had been installed at a 5-foot elevation inside the heater.  The platform was designed to span the walls of the heater, a gap of under 6 inches between the deck and the outer walls, except on the front end where the ladder access was located. The front end had handrail and midrail in place, but due to the shape of the heater there was no swing gate at the top of the ladder, hence the yellow tag.  At ~12:30 PM, a Wood welder was observed by client safety to be working from the scaffold while not tied off to an appropriate anchor point. The welder was wearing a harness and twin lanyards, but neither lanyard was secured to an anchor point.  The welder was 9 feet from the front-edge scaffold handrail and 11 feet from the gap in the handrail for ladder access. There was also a horizontal 6-inch structural beam 40" above the scaffold deck between the welder and the gap in handrail.  An Actual Severity of A1 was selected as this was a near-miss incident with no resulting injuries.  Potential Severity was also determined to be A1 as there was no direct fall exposure to the welder.
ImmediateAction: Work was stopped and confined space permit closed. Wood safety and supervision notified. Welder terminated for breeching client scaffold policy. Safety Stand-down held with crew.

ShortDescription: Minor first aid incident caused by falling shop sign
FullDescription: IP was travelling to a client meeting in Manchester, he was having a pre-meet (about 12:30) with a couple of people from another supplier to the client outside LEON at Manchester Station when one of the signs outside the shop was caught by the wind and hit him on the forehead causing a cut about 3-4” inches long.

ShortDescription: A Wood truck driven by a Wood EE (IP) was traveling North on HWY 288 when it collided with a privately owned vehicle at the intersection.
FullDescription: On Monday 5/9/22 at ~ 4:37pm, A Wood company truck being driven by a Wood EE (IP) was traveling North on Highway 288 when it collided with a privately owned vehicle at the intersection of Hwy 288 North and Chlorine Road. As the Wood company truck entered the intersection traveling north, the privately owned vehicle, which was traveling southbound on Hwy 288 was attempting to make a left hand turn onto Chlorine Road. The Wood company truck struck the privately owned vehicle in the front center with the front left corner of the Wood company truck.  Potential - damage to Wood truck was minor, damage to other vehicle involved was moderate the potential was slightly higher but unlikely for significant damage.
ImmediateAction: Both vehicles were stopped in place.  911 was called by a bystander, Freeport Police, DPS and Freeport EMS responded to the scene. Law enforcement began an traffic crash report investigation. Notifications were made to Wood Supervision and HSSES. Wood EE was taken to Wood Occ Med provider for evaluation and post-MVA UDS, and evaluated and released to full duty with no restrictions.

ShortDescription: Turbine Enclosure Door frame bent during Crane Lift.
FullDescription: While attempting to remove turbine enclosure doors the Banksman (Wood Employee) was directing Crane Operator (Wood Employee) on a blind lift via radio. The radio malfunctioned during lift while Banksman attempted to radio an “All Stop”. Crane Operator continued lift until he observed weight load indicator and stopped. The incident resulted in bending of door frame on the top and bottom where slings were positioned. No potential injuries or other damage to equipment reported. Actual severity was identified as an A1 as the damage was minor loss, less than $10K, with no injuries.  The potential selected was an A2 as the damage could have resulted in a moderate loss between $10K - $100K.
ImmediateAction: Incident was reported immediately to HESS OIM and EHS Leadership. Initial pictures and investigation determined that the radio mic was not working properly. Initial HESS Report was sent to Wood Account Manager. RCA Investigation is being conducted by HESS EHS and Leadership.

ShortDescription: Vehicle struck stored, pre-assembled steelwork
FullDescription: A Sub- Contractors vehicle had been successfully reversed into position ready to be loaded with spoil.  After loading was completed the driver  moved his vehicle forward to leave site.  During this manoeuvre his front nearside tyre struck some pre-assembled steelwork which was stored on the ground in a coned-off area, resulting in a burst tyre and unrepairable damage to the steelwork.This was the 4th time on 09/05/2022 that same driver had visited site to carry out the same task without any incidents and was aware of the position of the steelwork in relation to the area of spoil being removed.
ImmediateAction: Site Engineer checked to see if the driver had not sustained any injuries, which he confirmed, he had not.  The site Engineer then checked the damage to the steelwork, this was found to be a back-to-back raker section.  The site Engineer conducted an assessment  and deemed the section of Steelwork struck by the vehicle tyre to be unrepairable and reported his findings to his Project Manager.  The incident was raised through the reporting channels, and the driver reported the incident to his Business Manager.  Additional Steelwork has been put on order by the Project Manager and the driver contacted a Tyre replacement specialist.

ShortDescription: Fingers pinced beween two sieves, causing a laceration. Gloves were worn at time of incident.
FullDescription: While carrying the sieves from the shaker to the table, where they would be analyzed, the IP felt the sieves shift in their hands.  The IP attempted to shift their postiion to prevent the sieves from falling over and contacted the table pinching their right index finger between the sieves and the table surface.  The sieves were estimated at 15Kg in weight.  WorkCare was contacted after first aid was applied and they gave the reccomendation of going to a medical clinic to ensure there was nothing broken.  This was confirmed by x-rays taken at a clinic and the clinic gave IP a WSIB Form 8 that with functional abilites indicated.  The indicated abilities did not prevent IP from completing regular duties so IP was able to continue working.
ImmediateAction: First aid applied, WorkCare contacted.

ShortDescription: Projectile from zero turn mower hit a panel.
FullDescription: May 5th, 2022 at approximately 12:50PM a zero turn lawnmower was cutting grass in the arrays when it came across a rut that was hidden due to heavy vegetation.  As the mower crossed over the hidden rut its mowing deck came in contact with the peak of said rut causing flying debris to damage a panel.  The actual severity rating is an A1 due to the damage of the module being less than $10K. The potential severity rating also was an A1 as there was no potential for further damage, nor risk of injury to personnel as there was no one in the area when the damage occurred.
ImmediateAction: Operator immediately notified the General Foreman.  The General Foreman notified site safety and Strata.  Investigation protocols were initiated.

ShortDescription: IP tripped up going up a set of stairs to work trailer
FullDescription: During clean-up efforts for a chemical leak at the north dosing trailer late in the day of 05 May 2022, it was identified that additional supplies were needed. A Wood Environmental Technician, returning to their office trailer for the needed supplies went up the western wooden stairway of the trailer quickly. They report using the handrail.  The worker was wearing rubber boots. While going up the stairs, the worker started reaching out with their left hand to grab the door knob to open the door and as they did so their right hand came off the handrail. The rubber boot of the right foot gripped onto the grip strips mounted to the steps and resulted in the worker falling forward up the steps. The worker lost their balance due to the fact they were moving so quickly and were over reaching for the door knob. As a result of the loss of balance, the workers right knee made contact with the wooden nosing of the second last step going up. The worker got up and continued to support the efforts of the cleanup by bringing the supplies to the leak location. The event was reported to the Environmental Lead on-site.  First aid was applied through application of a cold ice pack due to pain experienced.  The event was reported to the PHSO the next morning at 0720. The worker is able to continue with work.
ImmediateAction: The worker was counseled to take their time, step carefully, Practice the Essential "Always Take Care".

ShortDescription: Module damaged by trench roller strobe light.
FullDescription: On May 5th, 2022 at approximately 8:25AM a crew was in the process of rotating panels so that they could dump dirt and commence rill repair.  While doing so, an operator realized the trench roller was to close to the panels.  In the process of moving the trench roller the operator bumped the remote in the wrong direction causing the strobe light on top of the equipment to make contact with the bottom of the panel causing a small dent in the frame.  The actual severity rating is an A1 due to the damage of the module being less than $10K. The potential severity rating also was an A1 as there was no potential for further damage, nor risk of injury to personnel as there was no one in the area when the damage occurred.
ImmediateAction: Operator immediately notified the foreman.  The foreman immediately notified the GF and site safety.  Strata was also notified and stated the panel did not need to be replaced.  Investigation protocols were initiated.

ShortDescription: IP was badging into the building when employee felt a pain in their back in the upper right quadrant.
FullDescription: Employee was badging into the building when felt a back pain in the upper right quadrant. IP is fairly tall and the badge reader is mounted lower than was convenient to swipe the badge without either removing the badge lanyard or bending slightly.  IP chose to bend slightly to swipe the badge.  When IP bent and reached out toward the reader IP felt a back pain which persisted.
ImmediateAction: IP entered the building and reported the pain to a Wood site safety person who works in the same office space.  IP also reported the situation to the Wood lead who reported it to the Wood Manager.  The Wood Manager met with IP and the Wood Safety Person at the Celanese site medical clinic where the Celanese nurse examined the IP. The nurse applied ice in the back area and prescribed Advil.  The nurse released IP to work and asked IP to report to Wood Manager if condition changed and to check in with Wood Manager the next day before coming on site. The nurse will examine IP and report back to Wood Manager on medical condition and return to work status. IP reported, feeling much better with just an occasional “pinch”. On Friday May 6, Wood Manager reported that IP applied heat and ice on 20 min intervals during night and the next morning could “barely tell any discomfort”.  IP has been cleared to return to work by Celanese.

ShortDescription: A cable pit cover gave rotated while stepped on allowing the foot of a Wood employee to fall inside.
FullDescription: During a site inspection to develop the engineering of a project a Wood employee was walking along the existing pipe rack of the “Movements and Mixing Unit” located in the CEPSA refinery, Huelva, Spain. While walking along the existing rack the worker reached the V10 section. When the worker stepped on a cable pit cover with the left fot the cover rotated allowing the foot to fall inside the cable pit. The dimension of the cable pit cover is 60cm by 60m and the cable pit depth is 50 cm The Worker managed to maintain the equilibrium and therefore avoided a more serious fall.
ImmediateAction: Worker accompanied first to Refinery medical center and later to external first aid center to be review. Worker was given first aid treatment and released back to work.

ShortDescription: While decommissioning the Evans City, PA laydown yard.  Logistics coordinator notified HSSE and Operations of oil staining from dormant tank
FullDescription: A team of Wood employees were dispatched to set up straw and hay bales, and other spill prevention booms.  A local environmental cleanup vendor has been notified and is on site assisting with cleanup. HSSE and Operations are in close contact with Logistics on investigation details and plans forward. This has been classified as an A1 actual with an A3 Potential.
ImmediateAction: A team of Wood employees were dispatched to set up straw and hay bales, and other spill prevention booms.  A local environmental cleanup vendor has been notified and is on site assisting with cleanup. HSSE and Operations are in close contact with Logisitcs on investigation details and plans forward.

ShortDescription: The davit pulley counterweight dropped during maintenance activity, hitting the seamen right hand causing small fracture on 5th finger.
FullDescription: Wood employees were performing preventative maintenance tasks in the lifeboat area.  During a routine test of the cable and remote trigger system which was located at the starboard side, the bosun pulled the cable to eliminate the slack.  While the bosun was making the adjustment, the assembly of pulley and counterweight was dropped from the davit support hitting the IP's right hand which was inside the lifeboat doing preventive maintenance with his hand supported on the upper hatch that was open.  (2.7 kilos / 5.9 lbs. dropped 1.5 meters, 4.9 feet).  As a result of the dropped object, the IP was referred for medical treatment, assessed a small fracture was found on 5th finger of his right hand.   The IP was released to work with restrictions.  Due the Drops calculation simulated, considering the weight and distance is showing a result a slight impact as consequence we can assume B2 as actual and potential effect.
ImmediateAction: The IP was assisted at offshore hospital and was prescript Ibuprofen 400mg each 8 hours+ Paracetamol 500 mg each 8 hours+ Ice compress for 30 minutes each 4 hours.After the disembark, the IP was assessed by orthopedist who recommended immobilization a with aluminum splint for 10 days.

ShortDescription: Electrical grid failure which affected the Thoroughbred building for nearly 2 hours prompting evacuation of the building
FullDescription: Power failed at the Thoroughbred Building, when maintenance looked for the cause it was determined that it was a full grid failure from CenterPoint in the area. Centerpoint web site mentioned that power could be restored at around 3:45 pm. following Houston campus Emergency procedure after 45 minutes of no power the decision to evacuate the building was taken.  Emergency lights and generator did activate however batteries started to fail after 15 minutes of use.
ImmediateAction: Elevators where checked for occupants.Maintenance staff was posted on staircases to support staff leaving the building as Emergency lights started to fail. Security guards stopped the entrance of visitors and Wood personnel where only allowed to enter (returning from Lunch) to pick up there laptops. HSSE&S walked each floor requesting personnel to leave, verifying that their was no issue.

ShortDescription: Concrete saw operator severed buried earth bonding cable
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: During the afternoon of 4th May 2022 at approximately 11:30am, a concrete saw operator was cutting the existing concrete underneath the existing Piperack within finger 4. The area that the operator was cutting had been approved by the client electrical and operations team. The weather conditions were sunny with the ground condition being good and no lighting issues being identified. The operator was cutting the concrete and identified a red cable within the saw blade. Operator stopped work immediately, ensured the saw was made safe and informed his supervisor. The supervisor informed the Client operations team and also Wood team. Area made safe and initial investigation works by client began. Client electrical department confirmed it was an earth bonding cable.
ImmediateAction: Operator stopped work immediately, ensured the concrete saw was made safe and informed his supervisor. The supervisor informed the Client operations team and also Wood team. Area made safe and initial investigation works by Client began.

ShortDescription: Employee was walking through the parking lot to the FHR Building when a contractor driving vehicle came in contact with employee.
FullDescription: Wood Manager received a notification from supervisor that an A/C contractor driving vehicle came in contact with a Wood employee. Employee was walking through the parking lot going to the Flint Hills Field Services building when the vehicle had just started backing out (had only moved about 2 feet) of a parking spot and came into contact with employee's right elbow. The contractor vehicle that made contact with Wood employee was not a FHR contractor but a temporary A/C contractor at the site. Employee reported no injuries. Wood employee is seconded to the client site that is owned and operated building by FHR.
ImmediateAction: Wood Team contacted employee to verify employee was ok and did not require any medical assistance. Employee confirmed doing fine, no need for first aid or any other medical treatment. Employee just wanted to report this near miss to increase situational awareness with other employees and contractors. FHR does not have reverse parking policy at this site since they utilize diagonal parking design and it is not conducive to reverse parking.  HSSE collected information and submitted a near miss report as category B2 for potential outcome of the incident given the vehicle just came in contact with employee.

ShortDescription: While boarding a plane for a business trip, employee collapsed due to natural causes and was pronounced dead at the scene.
FullDescription: While boarding a  Southwest Flight at Hobby Airport in Houston, TX  for a business trip to Savannah, GA Where the employee scheduled to be the keynote speaker at the API Conference.  Employee collapsed was attended by Airport First Responders.  Resuscitation efforts failed and employee was pronounced dead at the scene.  Employee's spouse who is a retired Wood Employee called the VP of Applied Intelligence informing her of what had occurred.
ImmediateAction: Vice President of Applied Intelligence informed HSE department and together activated the AI Leadership EMT.  Notifications were sent out to Wood Senior Management, API Conference was informed that employee would not be able to attend.  P & O commenced benefits procedures.   AI leadership commenced communications to all employees and clients.

ShortDescription: Nip to finger while ascending stair case
FullDescription: Individual was demobilising from the platform for his normal crew change.Whilst walking up the stairs to the helideck their left hand was on the lower section of the handrail when it caught a piece of the insulation banding that is used to secure the mesh panel.Individual alerted the heli-deck assistant to what had happened and asked that the area be checked to ensure the hazard was dealt with.Once the helicopter had departed the incident was reported to the radio op and observation card was raised before the area was checked out by platform personnel.
ImmediateAction: Heli-deck informed and observation card raised.Insulation banding was checked and re-covered with insulation tape to make the area safe.Further action to check all other mesh areas within handrails to ensure similar hazard does not exist, all other areas with similar bands were re-covered with insulating tape.Follow up call with the individual while at home to ensure all was OK, with no issues reported and feedback that they were glad that the information has been received and actioned upon.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

ShortDescription: Indian expat tested positive for COVID-19.  Experiencing mild symptoms and is fully vaccinated.
FullDescription: •27th Apr – IP arrived EG via ET with Negative PCR Certificate from home country, overnight in Malabo Hilton (he was off for 5 weeks)•28th Apr – Transferred to Bata for Ibis Quarantine via Cronos Chartered Flight. Pax was negative on antigen test conducted by MoH prior to Cronos Flight to Bata•1st May – Transferred to Offshore (Okume E). Pax was negative on C19 from TE Doctor Test and MoH, prior to mobilization to Offshore•3rd May – another antigen test was done due to mild symptoms (headache and body pain) and the result came out positive* IP is experiencing mild symptoms and has been fully vaccinated.
ImmediateAction: * IP will be transferred onshore on the afternoon of 3 May 2022 for isolation in Hotel Plaza where the Client Doctor    will conduct another PCR test upon arrival. The result of this PCR test yielded a positive result.  IP will remain in    quarantine and will be released upon yielding a negative result.* Client tested everyone on the boat that went along with IP and all results are negative.* Okume E is isolated from other assets and they will do another test after 3 days to make sure there are no other    cases.* All have been advised to practice COVID protocols (use of masks, social distancing, sanitizing etc.)

ShortDescription: While using handle of the shovel to guide cables into cable tray, shovel slipped, contacted and broke sprinkler head.
FullDescription: Workers were tasked with guiding and dressing the new 500 MCM cable from mill 1 circuit 3 to the truck loadout into the loadout cable trays. Two workers were positioned on top of the scaffold north of the conveyor gallery. Worker 1 was using the handle of a shovel vertically to help to bend the large cable and place into East/West cable tray for dressing. The shovel slipped and made contact with the fire water sprinkler. The sprinkler end broke off causing a water pressure release.
ImmediateAction: Workers evacuated the area and notified the supervisor. Scene was secured, Investigation and post incident protocols initiated. Canadian Model followed.

ShortDescription: Dumpster truck leaked hydraulic fluid onto ground.
FullDescription: At approximately 1515 on May 02, 2022, a vendor finished dropping off a dumpster when a hydraulic connection failed causing less than 1 gallon of hydraulic fluid to leak onto the ground. The leak was immediately noticed, and the machine was stopped. Environmental (SWPPP) was notified and clean up procedures began. The actual and potential severity ratings were selected as an A1 due to minimal reversible environmental impact.
ImmediateAction: The equipment was shut down. Environmental was notified. Clean up procedures immediately took place. All contaminated soil and diapers were picked up and disposed of into proper containments.

ShortDescription: EE climbed to top of fixed ladder. Crescent wrench slipped out of EE's pocket falling 16.5' to deck missing co-worker by 1'.
FullDescription: Wood employee ascending a fix ladder on to the roof top of the MCC Building reached the top and a crescent wrench dropped from his back pocket. The wrench is .45kg in weight and fell at a height of 5.03 meters impacting the deck. The wrench missed a co-worker by .03 meters.  Actual A1 Near Miss Event no injury or damage. Potential B2, potential medical treatment if wrench would have struck co-worker.
ImmediateAction: EE and employee stopped work and reported incident in accordance with HESS and Wood "Near Miss" protocols. Wood in conjunction with Hess HSE personnel are in the process of investigating the details of the "Near Miss" Incident/dropped object. Results of the investigation and recommendations of corrective actions will be shared with Wood and Client to prevent reoccurrence.
