ShortDescription: One employee threatened another employee in the breakroom during a lightning storm stand down.
FullDescription: On April 30th, 2022, at approximately 2:30 PM, all personnel were brought down from the unit bravo, to seek shelter due to lighting.  At approximately 3:15 PM, during a lighting stand down, an argument broke out between 3 team members (TMs) inside the breakroom.  At approximately 3:30 PM, one of the TMs involved in the argument reported to Safety and Supervision on site, that one of the TMs also involved in the argument threated to meet him outside the parking lot to fight.  The actual severity was an A1 as no personnel were injured, only threatened.  The potential severity was a B2, as one TM was threatened, and depending on the threat, may have resulted in a medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: TM who made the threat was pulled to the side, spoken to by the site Supervisor and admitted the threat. Site Superintendent defused the incident by having TM whom made threat removed from site, due to admitting the threat. Incident investigation protocols were initiated.

ShortDescription: Port side Crane boom handrail damaged
FullDescription: The crane driver was parking the port side crane boom into its rest, when the boom handrail came into contact with the wooden rest cushion, resulting in damage to the handrail. The parking method for the boom is to slew until the limit is reached and then lower the boom into the rest. The procedure was carried out as normal, but unfortunately the handrail, which is bolted onto the side of the boom, caught on the wooden rest cushion.
ImmediateAction: Crane boom secured in cradle. Incident reported, pictures and witness statements taken. OIE inspected handrail damage and reported findings. Lead electrical technician inspected crane boom for cable damage, no damage reported to the cables for lighting, camera and limit switched, however cable trays were found to be needing replaced. Damaged handrail and cable trays safely removed.

ShortDescription: Jar felt in shoulder
FullDescription: While pushing a jacking trolley frame under the roof in Tank 8, the frame struck one of the legs which bought the jacking frame to a sudden halt and jarred the left shoulder of the IP.
ImmediateAction: The IP reported discomfort in his left shoulder, no first aid applied, and has returned to work and we will monitor during the day and report back at end of shift.

ShortDescription: WOOD Rigger awoke with swelling to left eye
FullDescription: Reported to first aid, offshore nurse consulted, eye drops given.
ImmediateAction: Rigger has returned to normal duties and to be monitored. No foreign body visible in the eye or activities the previous day that could of contributed to the swelling.

ShortDescription: Driver of Wood vehicle rear ended another vehicle.
FullDescription: IP (involved person) was driving to work (Harbour Project, Port Hope ON) from their home in North York, ON in a company supplied vehicle (Chev Equinox #20154).  The IP was travelling eastbound on Highway 401 in the centre lane of three when they rear ended another vehicle that reportedly stopped suddenly in front of them.  The collision occurred approximately 300 m to the west of East Townline Rd, Newtonville, ON. They were travelling at around 110 km/hr (posted 100 km/hr) and reportedly braked just before impact.  The force of impact deployed the air bag system of the vehicle and it stopped approx. 10 m further on from the point of impact, slightly angled towards the right lane.  The IP reports they just sat in the vehicle not moving for approx. 2 minutes right after impact.  The other vehicle hit continued on for approx. 200 m and pulled over onto the median of the left side of the highway and stopped.  At the time of the incident, the PHSO for the Harbour Project was driving by in the same direction on their way to work and pulled off to assist the Wood driver and report the incident.There was a pre-existing incident to this one.  A transport truck (tractor with 53’ trailer) was into the guardrail on the south side of the highway just before the East Townline Road bridge crossing (no interchange), approx. 200 m ahead of this incident.  There was a heavy-duty wrecker truck on scene working on removing the transport.  There was a crash truck belonging to the local road maintenance company providing traffic control as the right lane was blocked at the location of work.
ImmediateAction: Wood H&S Manager attended the scene, investigation/photos started, IP to Hospital for check as the air bags deployed, A&D Testing

ShortDescription: Oxy-Acetylene Hose Failure during Calm Buoy PM Activities
FullDescription: The incident occurred at around 1000H 29April2022 during cutting of mooring pad eye shackle pin with Oxy-Acetylene torch. While the torch is being ignited, the oxygen hose failed. The hose failure resulted to a small flame which was immediately extinguished with water allocated to wet the habitat area. Personnel inside the habitat vacated the habitat and isolated the Oxygen and Acetylene pressure regulators.  All other hotwork controls are in place at the time of the incident. ncident is currently being investigated.
ImmediateAction: The fire watcher inside the habitat immediately pour water on the small flame and simultaneously signaled the personnel assigned to the gas bottles area to shut off the gas supply. All personnel on CALM buoy went out the work area to reassess . They took a Safety 5x5 to re-evaluate the task. The oxy-acetylene hose was also replaced with a new one as well.

ShortDescription: The side door of bus was damaged, as it was backing  of the work area.
FullDescription: At approximately 1715,  a wood employee was tasked with driving a bus to block 3 to pick up workers. The driver went to the end of block 3, and as they proceeded to leave the block, they asked an employee to get off the bus spot to for them.  The spotter walked to the left rear side of the bus, made eye contact with the driver, and then signaled the driver to backup. As the driver began backing the bus, the side door of the bus came in contact with rip rap rock resulting in a broken bus door window. There were 4 people on the bus and there were no injuries. The actual severity rating selected was a A1 as there were no injuries and the vehicle damage was less than 10k. The potential rating selected was a A1, as there was no potential for injury and vehicle damage could not exceed 10k.
ImmediateAction: The General Foreman and Safety was notified. The incident is currently under investigation.

ShortDescription: IP received an injury to his ankle and knee of his left leg whist transferring from a lifeboat to SSE Ronelle Tugboat.
FullDescription: On Thursday 28th April, the IP and 2 of his colleagues were to transfer from a lifeboat to the SSE Ronelle Tugboat. The agreed method of transferring from one vessel to another was:1.	The employees were to stand on a platform based at the stern of the lifeboat2.	The Ronelle would arrive at the stern on the lifeboat bow facing3.	The individuals were then to utilize the tires placed at the bow of  the Ronelle to pull themselves up from the lifeboatThe stern of the lifeboat where the platform was located is 2ft high and the bow of the Ronelle is 8ft high from sea level.As the bow of the Ronelle approached the platform where the indiviudals were standing the IP was pushed backwards against the main body of the lifeboat. As the Ronelle then came to a halt it lowered pinching the IPs left leg between the back of the lifeboat and the tires on the Ronelle.This resulted in significant swelling and pain of the IPs ankle and knee of his left leg.
ImmediateAction: The IP was assessed by the medic who strapped up his leg. He was then transferred onshore by Singapore Police Launch & onwards to Changi Hospital.

ShortDescription: Wood EE slowly bumped into a 3rd party vehicle while driving in traffic.
FullDescription: On April 28, 2022 at 1:36 pm, a Wood EE was traveling on state highway 128 in Jal, NM when he came to complete stop in traffic. As he gradually progressed his speed, he slightly bumped a 3rd party vehicle in front of him. This caused minor damage to the plastic grill on the front of the Wood vehicle; no injuries reported. Actual (A1): minor damage to the Wood vehicle with cost to repair not expected to exceed 10k; Potential (A1): Wood EE was traveling at a slow speed which would not likely cause a severe impact.
ImmediateAction: EE was taken in for a UA and incident was reported to his manager.

Gastrologist consulted with the IP and provisionally diagnosed to be experiencing acid reflux / indigestion and appropriate medication prescribed.  As a precautionary measure the IP is to provide a stool sample on 29 April 2022 for further diagnostics.Once diagnosed and treated , RTW timeline will be assessed

ShortDescription: While erecting scaffold, EE#1 felt a burning sensation to his back shoulder, then noticed the flange dripping.
FullDescription: Brevard EE#1 was erecting scaffold when he felt a burning sensation to his back shoulder, he noticed the flange dripping by.  EE# 1 notified others and immediately drenched himself in a safety shower.  Notifications were made and ES&S responded for medical attention.  EE# 1 was taken to outside care for an evaluation.  Wood and DOW were notified.  All work was immediately stopped until further investigation is done. Potential - EE stopped immediately and followed procedures. no health effect.
ImmediateAction: All work was stopped. Permit Writers notified to close out SWP. Notifications were made to Wood Supervision and Wood Safety. A Safety Stand Down was held with all scaffold builders and insulators and their Supervision. Wood EE 1 was sent to Safety Council to update his badge for DOW ALT training. A Safety Stand Down was conducted by Brevard.

ShortDescription: right leg contusion due to of a melanin table that the wind moved
FullDescription: THE WORKER WAS PERFORMING CARPENTRY TASKS ON THE WORK FRONT OF THE HMU SECTOR.A PHENOLIC 1.22 M X 242 M, WHICH WAS SUPPORTED HORIZONTALLY ON A WOOD POST BEHIND THE WORKER FALLS BECAUSE IT WAS PUSHED BY THE WIND. IMPACTING ON HES RIGHT TWIN, CAUSING A CONCUSION.HE IMMEDIATELY REPORTS WHAT HAPPENED TO THE SECTOR FOREMAN, WHO INFORMS THE RIVA EHS AREA.

ShortDescription: Driver damaged vehicle driving on a mine haul road
FullDescription: Individual was driving well over the speed limit of 25 mph as can be seen by the tire marks.  He was returning to the RipRap area to get his wallet he left behind.  High Mark Construction will follow their company policy so he will be drug & alcohol tested.  The individual was not injured and was wearing his seatbelt.  They will be towing the vehicle to their yard so it is off site for tomorrows visit.  The front end damage it is well over $500.00.  Client has been notified and will be entered into the BP IRIS system following investigation.
ImmediateAction: Vehicle will be towed, IP required to take Drug and Alcohol test.

FullDescription: Fuel spill to ground after damage to fueling truck tank. see attached Contractor IAR.  Ladder struck a valve on the side of the tank releasing fuel to the bed of the truck that overflowed to the ground.  Spill was immediately recognized and cleaned up.
ImmediateAction: Spill reported and cleaned up with proper disposal

ShortDescription: While driving back from site, a tire blew out on a corporate vehicle, forcing the team to stop. No injuries reported.
FullDescription: At approximately 20:00, on the way back to the office from a site visit 150 miles away, while within 10 miles to the office, a noise was heard in the passenger cabin while driving at the speed limit (100 km/h-63mph), after which the speed was  immediately reduced and it was noted that maneuverability was compromised, with severe vibrations. A decision was made to exit the highway and stop at a gas station, where the vehicle was inspected and the left rear tire was found already destroyed. The tire was changed and a quick inspection of the other tires revealed apparent damage to the front right tire's sidewall. The failed tire did not seem to have any unusual wear on the tread surface. Tire pressures were rechecked and vehicle driven back safely to the office at a reduced speed as limited by the spare tire.
ImmediateAction: Vehicle reduced speed and went to gas station to switch tire out of highway in safe area. Vehicle driven back to office and stopped until further mechanical review. Corporate vehicle assignment suspended until further review of the fleet

ShortDescription: Employee was drilling into a Metal Pipe Culvert with a DeWalt electric 1/2" drill when it bound and twisted his finger
FullDescription: Employee was drilling 1/2" holes into a Metal Pipe Culvert with a DeWalt electric 1/2" drill when the bit bound in the hole, caught his glove and twisted his right ring finger.  The area below his second knuckle was swollen and sore with limited motion.  Occucare was consulted for treatment and care.  They recommended ice for 24 hours and then heat, with Ibuprofen as needed.Due to additional swelling and bruising the injured party was referred for x-rays by Occucare.  The x-rays confirmed that the metacarpal bone of the ring finger on the right hand is broken.  The hand was splinted and employee referred to a hand specialist (two week expected until specialist will see him). Ice and ibuprofen recommended as continuing care.
ImmediateAction: Employee contacted his supervisor immediately and an ice pack was applied. Occucare was consulted for treatment.  Employee was taken for drug/alcohol testing.This task was not on the JSA signed by the injured employee.  The entire crew will receive extra JSA writing training during the morning safety meeting on 4/27/2022.

ShortDescription: IP was moving pontoon boat between ponds when the trailer broke and began to lean against the shin of a Benchmark employee, bruising shin.
FullDescription: As a pontoon boat was loaded onto it's trailer a person was attemting to get off the boat before another person pulled the "unloaded" boat out via an ATV (the trailer was stationary at the time ov the incident). As the person was stepping off the boat, IP stepped on the tongue of the trailer for support. When the person stepped onto the tongue of the trailer the weld that holds the tongue to the actual frame of the trailer broke causing the person to have right lower leg wedged in between the boat and the rubber trailer bow roller for a brief time (aproximately 5 seconds) before IP was able to get it unlodged.
ImmediateAction: Medic responded. IP treated as first aid incident and declined to go to a clinic for further evaluation.

ShortDescription: IP was watching TV before their shift was due to start and felt some discomfort in their eye
FullDescription: IP was watching TV before their shift was due to start and felt some discomfort in their eye.They attempted to irrigate their eye and then decided to report to the Medic.The Medic flushed the IP's eye but couldn't see any FB that could have been causing irritation.The IP carried out their shift.The following morning the IP could still feel some discomfort so the Medic decided to MEDEVAC them so onshore could look more closely and remove any FB.IP was seen by an onshore Doctor who managed to remove the FB that had been causing the discomfort (a magnifier was required because the FB was so small).Although the IP is a Plater by trade and had been wearing goggles the previous day to remove handrails, because there was no discomfort felt that day we can not say that the FB went into their eye while at work.
ImmediateAction: IP attempted to flush their own eye.IP then visited the Medic and they attempted the same flushing.IP felt some discomfort the following day so the IP was MEDEVAC'd.IP had a tiny FB removed using tweezers by an onshore Doctor
OtherHazardSource: FB in eye while watching TV

ShortDescription: Small laceration on knuckle approx 1mm x 1mm
IncidentAssignedTo: Other Person (Will not count on Statistical Reporting)
FullDescription: Whilst on a height course the IP climbed a ladder and "knicked" his knuckle against some steel resulting in a 1mm x 1mm cut. The cut, although small bled profusely. Instructor stopped training and carried out immediate first aid. Student applied pressure with paper towel. When the instructor asked the IP if he knew of any reason he was bleeding badly, the IP advised he was on blood thinning medication. Bleeding was eventually stemmed and wound dressed. The IP failed to advise of his medical condition at tool-box talk (when asked).
ImmediateAction: The IP climbed down and the trainer immediately stopped training. Moved with IP to the sick bay and cleaned the cut applied pressure until the bleed stopped and dressed.

Whilst busy with the pipe wrench he accidently bumped the adjustable wrench that fell approximately 1.8 meters to the floor.
ImmediateAction: Work stopped and incident reported to the Supervisor and Safety Manager. An investigation was started.

ShortDescription: IP Felt Discomfort on right eye after welding debris hit safety glasses
FullDescription: On Monday, April 25, 2022, around 1:50pm IP was tasked to stick weld steel plates on PCS 24. After completing the weld IP needs to accomplish a slag removal using a manual chipping hammer before adding more welds. When IP was manually chipping at the weld, he felt debris hit safety glasses causing discomforted on right eye. IP reported the incident to foreman which brought IP to be evaluated by onsite medic. Actual incident is rated as a B1 as First Aid treatment was provided by medical professional. Potential incident is rated as a B2 as there could be a potential for medical treatment/restricted duties if proper case management is not followed.
ImmediateAction: Supervisor took IP to onsite EMT for evaluation. Work was stopped, JSA closed, and witness statements were captured. Right eye was immediately rinse and IP discomfort was resolved. IP has returned to work. Investigation has been initiated.

The Wood employee scheduled a COVID 19 test on 4/24/2022, and was informed on 4/24/2022 the employee is positive for COV19. The employee was last on site on 4/22/2022. Contact Tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.
ImmediateAction: Employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  Wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

ShortDescription: Solar panels broken after being struck by skid steer
FullDescription: At approximately 0945, a civil team was in the process of starting to load a dump truck with soil using a skid steer. After the dump truck was parked the spotter began spotting for the skid steer to get the soil to be loaded. As the skid steer proceeded to get the soil, the operator turned and struck two solar panels with the left side lift arm upright, causing damage to both panels. There was no damage to the skid steer. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor, the replacement of panels is (less than 10k), and there were no other team members in the vicinity.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent and the safety department. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, photos of the incident were gathered, and the panels were barricaded by the safety team to eliminate hazard to other team members. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

ShortDescription: Foreign body in eye after tank maintenance activities
FullDescription: Works ongoing at tank P-3 on Sunday 24th April included the installation of the tank wind-girder and handrails.  The IP was installing the handrail sections with a welder which included grinding activities. The IP was wearing safety glasses and also wore a full face visor when grinding. He walked home after his work in windy conditions with no eye protection. On Sunday night at approximately 19:00, the IP felt discomfort in his left eye.The IP advised his supervisor on Monday 26th April at approx. 14.00 that he had discomfort in his eye. He confirmed he had used eyewash prior to reporting. He felt fit to return to work.On Tuesday 26th April at 13.30 the IP again reported to his supervisor that he still had discomfort in his eye. At this time the supervisor brought the IP to the onsite medical facility for further checks. The onsite nurse confirmed she could see a foreign body in the eye.
ImmediateAction: The onsite nurse informed the supervisor that a film was covering the object and instructed the supervisor to escort the IP to the nearest A&E where they have a dedicated eye clinic where the foreign body was removed at 17.00 using a cotton bud and eyewash. The IP was fit for work and returned to work the following day.

ShortDescription: The IP was assisting in the installation of handrail sections when later that evening he felt discomfort in his Left Eye.
FullDescription: On Sunday 24th April A steel erector (IP) working on the tank wind girder handrail installation was assisting a welder onsite. This was being carried out from a scaffold platform located on shell course 7. The activity consisted of lifting the handrails into place to ensure the correct measurement was taken, the handrails were then lowered down onto the scaffold where it was cut to suit, after this the handrail was re-positioned and held in place for the welder to tack weld in position. The IP was wearing safety glasses during the welding, the IP also wore a safety shield when grinding. While back at his accommodation the IP felt discomfort in his left eye at approximately 21.00 the same evening. The following day Monday the 26th April at approx. 14:00 the IP's left eye was still causing discomfort where he reported it to his supervisor who suggested he was to rinse with eye wash which he did. The following day the IP's eye was still causing a discomfort where he was advised to attend the on site nurse who confirmed the IP had foreign body lodged in his eye.
ImmediateAction: The onsite nurse informed the supervisor that a film was covering the object and instructed the supervisor to bring the IP to the nearest A&E where they have a dedicated eye clinic where the foreign body could be removed safely. An appointment was made for 15.30 for the IP to be seen. A co-worker was instructed to drive the IP to this clinic. Upon arrival the IP was seen and at approx. at 17.00, a foreign body was removed from the IP’s left eye. The IP was fit for work and returned to work the following day.

ShortDescription: Wood rig welder's left foot contacted a 2"x12"x12" mud sill board causing them to roll their ankle.
FullDescription: On Saturday 4/23/2022,(2) Wood employees were assigned to roll blinds on ST20 6" 1500# steam line in the FPC Utilities CoGen Unit. Once the task was completed they lowered the tools to ground level and Wood EE1 (IP) told Wood EE2 he was descending the scaffold to ground level. The IP began descending the ladder of the 10ft scaffold. Being careful to maintain 3 point contact on the ladder, the IP attempted to dismount the scaffold ladder and step to ground.  The IP's left foot made contact with a 2"x12"x12" mud sill board causing their left ankle to roll. The IP immediately summoned his foreman, client supervision, client site safety, and Wood HSSES. Wood HSE Coordinator evaluated the injury and determined that the IP needed to be taken to off site Occ Med provider for evaluation.  Potential - First aid received, could have potentially been slightly worse but unlikely to result in a medical treatment.
ImmediateAction: Employee notified Wood Foreman and Wood HSSE and Client PIC, Client EHS. Employee was taken to off site Occ Med provider for evaluation, and was released to full duty with no restrictions.

ShortDescription: Wood rig welder descended a scaffold and attempted to dismount the scaffold ladder to ground level their left foot contacted a mud sill boar
FullDescription: On Saturday 4/23/2022,(2) Wood employees were assigned to roll blinds on ST20 6" 1500# steam line in the FPC Utilities CoGen Unit. Once the task was completed they lowered the tools to ground level and Wood EE1 (IP) told Wood EE2 he was descending the scaffold to ground level. The IP began descending the ladder of the 10ft scaffold. Being careful to maintain 3 point contact on the ladder, the IP attempted to dismount the scaffold ladder and step to ground.  The IP's left foot made contact with a 2"x12"x12" mud sill board causing their left ankle to roll. The IP immediately summoned his foreman, client supervision, client site safety, and Wood HSSES. Wood HSE Coordinator evaluated the injury and determined that the IP needed to be taken to off site Occ Med provider for evaluation.
ImmediateAction: Employee notified Wood Foreman and Wood HSSE and Client PIC, Client EHS. Employee was taken to off site Occ Med provider for evaluation, and was released to full duty with no restrictions.

ShortDescription: Deer strike to the front of a Wood vehicle.
FullDescription: On April 23, 2022 at 5:15 am, a Wood EE was traveling home from work in Gail, TX when a deer ran onto the road and struck the front of his Wood vehicle. Impact caused damage to the right front fender and headlight. No injuries reported. Actual (A1): Damages not expected to exceed 10k; Potential (A1): Deer strikes typically do not cause severe damage to our vehicles.
ImmediateAction: Wood EE notified his account manager.

ShortDescription: Dropped object from Co2 removal train - scaffold fitting
FullDescription: During blasting operations, the team heard a 'thud' next to where they were working and noticed that a scaffold fitting had fallen from an unknown location to grade. There were no personnel working above the area and no scaffold operations in the vicinity.
ImmediateAction: Job stoppedAccess to area restricted with barriersPDO sweep of locations above worksite carried out with no PDO's found. Area above the site was very well kept with no materials stored in the area.Spirit Energy investigation started.Preliminary slide briefed at all TBT's.

ShortDescription: IP received a small puncture wound into his left hand.

ImmediateAction: Supervisor/HSE notified. Employee taken to paramedic. Investigation commenced.

ShortDescription: A 3rd party vehicle's trailer struck the front end of a Wood vehicle as EE was traveling home.
FullDescription: On April 22, 2022 at 4:30 pm; As a Wood EE was traveling home from work near Tinsley, MS, a 3rd party vehicle with a trailer attached went into the Wood driver’s lane and struck the front end of the Wood vehicle. This also caused another 3rd party driver that was driving behind the trailer to come in contact with the front of the Wood vehicle. Impact caused damage to the driver side of the Wood vehicle. Police was called out to the scene, but no citations were given. Actual (A1): Repairs not expected to exceed 10k; Potential (A2): Impact could have been more severe causing damages to exceed 10k.
ImmediateAction: Police were notified and EE reported the incident to his Wood manager.

ShortDescription: Volvo A45G  (2881)  Articulating Haul Truck stuck in Mud
FullDescription: Operator (Ronnie Steed) was following the traffic pattern when the previously traveled ground reached saturation from thawing and runoff water.  This resulted in the right rear tires of the truck sinking into the mud.  The operator stopped immediately and contacted his supervisor.  The truck was able to drive out of the area without towing after an excavator cleared around the truck and cleaned out the bed.The possibility of a first aid injury occurring would have been a result of the truck having tipped onto it's side more causing the operator to hit their head or an object striking them that was loose in the cab (i.e. lunch pail, radio).  It would have been more hazardous trying to get out of the vehicle.
ImmediateAction: The operator stopped immediately and contacted his supervisor.  The truck was able to drive out of the area without towing after an excavator cleared around the truck and cleaned out the bed.

ShortDescription: An EG national tested positive for Typhoid
FullDescription: 21 April 2022 - An EG national reported to the offshore clinic with rectorrhagia (rectal bleeding) which they had been experiencing for 3 days prior.  The IP was examined and their symptoms were a mild headache and a lax / soft abdomen.  A digital rectal exam showed no active bleeding and was normal.  The IP reported that they had experienced rectal bleeding 3 years ago which was treated.  The IP was administered suppositories and their vital signs monitored.  Further diagnostic tests were conducted which all came back negative.22 April 2022 -  The IP was taken onshore to La Paz in Bata for further medical evaluation where a blood test yielded a positive Typhoid result and is being treated accordingly.  The surgeon examined the IP and did not note any abnormalities.A gastroenterologist is not available in La Paz Bata and the IP may need to be transferred to La Paz in Malabo where the specialist is available.  If required this would take place upon completion of treatment for Typhoid.NOTE:  The IP reported for quarantine on 29 March 2022 prior to going offshore on 3 April 2022.25 April 2022 - Follow up medical report received stating that the IP picked up roundworm.  Arrangements to be made to go to La Paz in Malabo to consult a gastroenterologist.26 April 2022 - No Gastrologist available in Malabo.  IP advised to complete prescribed medication.  Follow up scheduled for 29 April 2022 in order to be issued with fit to work certificate after which they would go into quarantine to return offshore.
ImmediateAction: IP was taken to La Paz in Bata where they will undergo treatment for Typhoid.  If required the IP will be transferred to La Paz in Malabo for consultation with gastroenterologist.25 April 2022 - Follow up medical report received stating that the IP picked up roundworm.  Arrangements to be made to go to La Paz in Malabo to consult a gastroenterologist.26 April 2022 - No Gastrologist available in Malabo.  IP advised to complete prescribed medication.  Follow up scheduled for 29 April 2022 in order to be issued with fit to work certificate after which they would go into quarantine to return offshore.

ShortDescription: Crowbar slipped and hit IP in the face when adjusting support
FullDescription: In connection with installation of Mud kill hang off station, involved person (IP) used a crowbar when mounting/adjusting the support. IP tried to adjust on the support which was well above head level when the crowbar slipped, which led to IP hitting the face with the hand and the end of the crowbar. This resulted in a small cut above the lip next to the nose. IP notified the manager and contacted nurse for a check. IP received a patch on the injury and could then return to work.
ImmediateAction: IP stopped the job, secured the workplace, and then notified the managerIP consulted nurse for check. (Slight cuts over the lip next to the nose were plastered. Back to work immediately afterwards).A scaffolding stool was built to avoid work above head levelThe incident was reviewed with the person / persons involved to uncover causes, measures, and learningThe incident was reviewed with mobilized personnel and informed to operations / platform managementSafety message is established

ShortDescription: Contractor Employee suffered finger injury
FullDescription: Whilst changing drill bit in a battery powered hand held drill the IP was applying force with the chuck key to release the chuck to change the drill bit. As he was doing this he inadvertently energized the tool causing his right hand to rotate with the chuck key and his fingers struck the body of the drill resulting in a fracture to his little finger on his right hand. Fracture was diagnosed at local hospital and non rigid support used to imobilise finger, after which IP returned to the worksite. On this basis, currently classified as first aid in accordance HSE-PRO-100001 and no reportable under RIDDOR, however this will be reviewed as facts are gathered.
ImmediateAction: The job was stopped immediately. Drill was quarantined and inspected. This identified general 'wear and tear' to the chuck assembly which has now been replaced with a keyless chuck.Stand down for safety delivered to the construction team involving Tolent management to share initial learning and reiterate our expectation around power tool use.Tolent requested to carry out formal inspection of all power tools on site.Investigation Initiated

ShortDescription: Underground electrical line struck by trencher
FullDescription: While trenching along-side the roadway an operator on a Vermeer ride on trencher struck an underground power line. Actual- A2, Due to Damage expected to be well over 10k and no injuries. Potential- B5 Since there was an arc from live electric line there was potential of fatality.
ImmediateAction: Operator immediately retracted the trencher and Management/Safety of both Whiting-Turner and Kelchner were notified. Location was secured and power company was called to come out and de-energize and repair lines. Witness statements were taken and operator was taken for a post incident drug/alcohol test.

ShortDescription: Rear pickup truck window broken after mishandling of a spade shovel
FullDescription: On Thursday, 04/21/2022, at approximately 2:30pm, EE was finished with the task of installing a pile and was loading tools into the bed of the company pickup truck. As he was loading a spade shovel into the bed of the truck, the metal tip of the shovel made contact with the left side of the rear window. The force of the contact was enough to break the rear window. The actual and potential severity rating is an A1 since damage is minor, the replacement of glass is (less than 10k), and there were no other team members in the vicinity.
ImmediateAction: The incident was immediately reported to the superintendent and the safety department. Incident investigation protocols were put in place by Operations and HSSE site team. The JSA was closed, photos of the incident were gathered, the vehicle was tagged “Do Not Use” by logistics, and the window has been covered to eliminate hazard to personnel. The employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and UA screening collected.

Potential - based on damage to Wood truck was minor <$10K and no injuries.

ShortDescription: An engineer step on a small cut grating. It tilted, and the foot slightly went through.
FullDescription: Arkema and Wood team carried out a walk down (inspection) at the R1190 tank top grating level. During the walk down, one of the Arkema personnel stepped on a small piece of unsecured metal grating (220mm X 700mm) and his foot went slightly down through the grating. The grating was not secured properly after modification work. No barricades either to prevent unauthorized access to personnel. The gap between the grating and the top of the tank surface was about 250mm.
ImmediateAction: Hard barricade was installed immediately. A dedicated team was assigned to inspect the secureness of all gratings at the roof top platform level, that they are secured. They did not find any other loose gratings that may create danger to people. Briefing was also conducted to all personnel working in the area to prevent a similar occurrence.

FullDescription: Local male (Perpetrator) from the community accompanied with some local teenagers were observed standing in front of the newly constructed airlock at the entrance to WPC.Perpetrator insisted that the driver of said Tipper Truck (Tipper Truck is not a project  or Wood asset) be advised to remove the tipper truck from the WPC site.Two Wood supervisors contacted the client Community Affairs(CA) team to come and discuss the matter.Perpetrator became impatient after waiting for approximately 10 mins, for the CA team and walked past the main gate and toward the Tipper Truck carrying a bush knife(Tipper truck driver was not in the truck).Perpetrator then proceeded to damage the Tipper Truck using the bush knife.Client security on site escorted  perpetrator offsite.

ShortDescription: H2O2 release during initial storage tank fill - No injuries.
FullDescription: USP hooked up hose from H2O2 supply truck to a fitting on the fill line on the Site's H2O2 storage tank and began to fill. Filled ~100-200 gallons and Wood and USP noticed a small leak (drips) coming from the fill line at the 45 degree elbow, below the check valve. USP stopped the fill. A fitting on the fill line disconnected at the 45 degree elbow, just below/upstream of the check valve and released/sprayed ~1-2 gallons of H2O2 in the vicinity. It was then noticed that the ball valve above/downstream of the leak/check valve/elbow had been closed (causing a trap for pressure buildup in the fill line below/upstream of the ball valve). Upon investigation, nobody onsite witnessed who closed the ball valve and everyone onsite claim they had not closed it.
ImmediateAction: Spill kit absorbent was applied to H2O2 on the ground and absorbent was swept up - USP contained spent absorbent and removed from Site.  Sump in containment pad was filled with water and tank and impacted containment pad surface was rinsed with potable water and rinseate water drained to sump.

ShortDescription: NWR foreign particle found in IP right eye
FullDescription: At approximately 05:30hrs in the morning, IP has just ended his night shift and proceeded to DP2 to change his PPE at the locker room prior to having his meal at the galley as per his normal routine. After he has completed his meal, he went straight to his cabin and while washing his face in the washroom, he felt something entered his right eye and paid no attention to it. Afterwards, when trying to sleep, he felt discomfort & irritation in his right eye in which he immediately proceeded to consult the vessel medic.
ImmediateAction: Vessel Medic perform eye wash with eye lotion and wipe it out under tetracaine eye drop. 2 drops of Neomycin & DEXAMETHASONE (Cadexcin-N) eye drops were also administered. The IP was subsequently send onshore via FSIV for further medical consultation with SSB eye specialist, followed by BSP PHC for review.

ShortDescription: Two Wood employees were probing hole so Wood backhoe operatoer could dig out area to replace 8 inch valve.  Wood backhoe operator began movi
FullDescription: On April 18th 2022 at ~1:30 p.m. a Wood backhoe operator working at Dow OCD-900 was tasked with digging an excavation down to a depth of ~4' to expose a previously damaged and possibly leaking 8 inch valve to verify it's condition and replace it if needed.  About halfway through the dig the Wood backhoe operator got the ok from Wood probers 1 and 2 that the area was clear.  Wood backhoe operator began moving the underground dirt when he started seeing water coming up from the ground.  Wood backhoe then stopped the equipment and reported it to operations.  Potential - Work was immediately stop, minor loss, business impact <10K.
ImmediateAction: Wood backhoe operator saw water coming up so he reported it to Dow operation and Wood supervision to start evaluating the situation and to try to stop the water from leaking. All work immediately stopped and incident reported.

ShortDescription: Skidsteer sliding front window shatter when material fell out and impacted the window.
FullDescription: At approximately 0730 on 04/18/22, a Team Member (TM) was operating a skid steer in Block 2 area. TM was removing ground material (broken mud mats) with a bucket attachment and disposing of into a dumpster when a piece of the material fell out of the bucket and hit the sliding front windshield causing it to shatter due impact of debris. An actual rating of A1 was selected due to the property damage being minimal (<10k). A potential rating of A1 was selected as there was no potential for the driver to be injured.
ImmediateAction: TM reported the incident to the Supervisor and HSSES. Witness statement was collected, and investigation initiated, Rental company notified to begin repair, and O&M contractor notified.

In the process of sliding down the treads of the stairs, the IP believes he has impacted his own cheek, with what he believes was the EX tablet he was carrying, but he can't be sure. The IP was wearing full PPE at the time. The IP immediately reported to the on-board medic and received over the counter strength anti-inflammatory medication and antiseptic cream. The IP returned to work, no further issues reported.
ImmediateAction: IP reported incident to line supervision and reported to the medic for FA treatment. IP returned to work.

FullDescription: A 240 SGT employee who was in the office Wednesday tested positive for COVID-19.

ShortDescription: Excavator hydraulic hose broke causing less than 1 gallon of hydraulic fluid to leak onto the ground
FullDescription: At approximately 1615 on April 15, 2022, Electrical operator was backfilling the A/C excavation at south PCS 6. When the top hydraulic hose on the boom of the Excavator broke causing less than 1 gallon of hydraulic fluid to leak onto the ground. The leak was immediately noticed, and the machine was stop. Environmental (SWPPP) was notified and clean up procedures began. The actual severity and potential ratings were selected as an A1 due to minimal reversible environmental impact.
ImmediateAction: The equipment was shut down and tagout. Environmental was notified. Clean up procedures immediately took place. All contaminated soil and diapers were picked up and disposed of into proper containments.

ShortDescription: Seven Wood employees tested positive to COVID-19
FullDescription: During the week 16, seven Wood employees tested positive to COVID-19.
ImmediateAction: Employees are in quarantine as per local legislation.Negative swab is requested before returning in office.No more action required.

ShortDescription: 4x Covid Positive cases
FullDescription: 4x Positive covid cases in isolation. Diagnosed from 15th April - 27th April.
ImmediateAction: In Isolation

ShortDescription: Laborer cut their gloved finger resulting in a 1" laceration to the end of Left middle finger.
FullDescription: On April 14th, at approximately 11:15 AM, a laborer was working "A" side of the Air Heaters at an elevation approx. 4' below the open manway on the 4th floor.  The laborer was in the process of getting set up to weld in pieces of pre-cut all thread rod into place. The laborer felt that they would lose their footing in the position that they were in so they repositioned themselves for better stability. In doing so, the laborer used both hands to help push themselves upward using the two side seals to gain a better foot hold. Upon repositioning, the laborer noticed when they removed their hand from the seals, there was a cut in their leather glove. The IP removed their glove and observed that there was a 1" laceration to end of the left middle finger. The actual severity of the incident is a B2 as medical treatment was provided (7 stitches) on the laceration.  The potential severity was classified as a B3 as the incident could have resulted in an LTI had the laceration been more severe.
ImmediateAction: IP removed themselves from the work area and immediately notified Superintendent.  IP was taken to the safety office, wound was cleaned and evaluated closer. laceration identified as to be severe beyond any local first aid measures. IP was transported to local urgent care center in which was then sent to the ER for further evaluation. Upon arrival at the ER Laceration was cleaned, evaluated as stiches only. IP was discharged and awaiting follow up appointment.

ShortDescription: Person in camp tested positive to Covid 19.
FullDescription: Person in camp tested positive to Covid 19. Required to isolate for at least 5 days.
ImmediateAction: Required to isolate for at least 5 days.

ShortDescription: Tech undertaking fan service removed fan cover and identified what could be Asbestos
FullDescription: On 14 April 2022 two Technicians had been assigned a Preventive Maintenance task to inspect and grease air supply fans at the Brooklyn Pump Station (BPS) in the South Well Pump Plant room.  To inspect the fans, a cover has to be removed which exposes a gasket and the fan internals to be inspected and serviced.  In the past, the cover gaskets had been identified to contain asbestos which had resulted in a project to inspect all the fans at BPS to have the asbestos containing gaskets removed and replaced with new gaskets.  During this fan inspection, a rubber like looking material had been identified protruding from underneath the fan cover.  This had been assumed as safe as the Technicians had understood all the gaskets had been replaced.  On removal of the inspection cover, the Technicians had identified a fibrous looking material which they had assumed could potentially contain asbestos material.  The task had then been ceased by the Technicians until further notice.   A licensed Industrial Hygienist had taken a sample of the gasket for testing.  The gasket had been identified as containing Organic Fiber and not to contain asbestos.
ImmediateAction: •	The Technicians had reported the potential find to the Supervisor.  The Supervisor had given approval to take a sample for testing as per the Asbestos Management Procedure MALRC-HSQ-PRC-002•	A Technician had donned a P2 Mask, gloves and wet down the sample area with WD-40.  •	The Technician took a small sample of the gasket and had placed it in a labelled plastic bag.•	A licensed asbestos removalist had attended the site to remove the suspect gasket material and make safe the work area.  The gasket material had then been handed over to a licensed Industrial Hygienist for testing.  •	The Industrial Hygienist had completed an inspection of the work area and then provided to Wood a clearance certificate for the fan works to continue safely.  •	BPS Supervisor had brought together all the team members for a Toolbox Talk to discuss the potential find and actions going forward.   o	Any inspection cover plates with gaskets that cannot be identified as asbestos free, must be treated as if asbestos containing material.  Asbestos management Procedure MALRC-HSQ-PRC-002 to be followed.

ShortDescription: A Wood employee received small lacerations to his hand after falling on some expanded metal.  First aid only.
FullDescription: On Thursday, April 14, 2022 at approximately 9:45 am CST, the IP was tasked with throwing pallets into a trash trailer.  While he performed this task, he stopped to use the restroom.  As the IP was stepping up on the port o potty platform, he missed one of the steps, fell forward and reached out his right hand to catch himself on the expanded metal platform.  The palm of the IP right hand received three small lacerations from the expanded metal that required first aid treatment.The Actual Severity is B1 because the injury only required first aid treatment.  The Potential Severity is a B2 because the injury could have required medical treatment and sutures.
ImmediateAction: IP reported incident to the client crew lead.  The client crew lead reported incident to the Wood project manager.  The Wood project manager reported the incident to the Wood HSSES Advisor.  An Axiom nurse was contacted and advised the IP to go to a nearby clinic to get the lacerations properly cleaned.

ImmediateAction: Work stopped and supervisor contacted. IP was taken to onsite PA who assessed, bandaged, and gave ice. IP returned to work. Onsite PA recommended IP go to Timmins for further assessment. Following assessment, IP returned to work. Investigation initiated.

ShortDescription: CP-2022-0043 ENV NANJV; release of silt laden water into Chester Lake
FullDescription: Discovered run-off with high sediment from the Overburden dump area flowed through a rock-built road into the channel resulting in a release of silt laden water into Chester Lake (fish bearing water body). No quantity of release can be determined and duration of the release to be determined after field reading.
ImmediateAction: NANJV installed a nightshift tilt plug and ESC controls in channel to mitigate more runoff with high turbidity towards the lake. Investigation underway to identify further remediation and actions to be implemented.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident

FullDescription: Individual was ascending staircase on the South external staircase heading to level 6.During the ascend their foot slipped off the tread as they placed weight on it causing their shin to hit the edge of the step above.First reaction was it was just a knock and thought no more of it until reaching his work area he took a closer look and found there to be a cut with some bleeding.Individual then make their way to the medic who checked it over applied a dressing and individual then returned to work with no issues.
ImmediateAction: Individual visited the medic where the wound was cleaned and dressing applied before returning to normal working duties.
WorkActivities: No work activity being carried out at the time of the incident
